number of helpful: 27 of 36 people (75%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												My Review for Wargame: Red DragonI have always been a lover for strategy games. I loved playing Empire and Napoleon Total War ( Which I highly recommend playing aswell). But there was a very limited amount of modern war type strategy games. And then I found the Wargame Series. Gameplay:Warning: There is a HUGE learning curve for this game. You just can't start off and know how to play well. I recommend reading the 200 page guide(By SandyGunfox) about how to play the game. I remember starting off without reading the 200 page guide and my army got streamrolled. I didn't know what to do. But after the reading the guide I got the hang of the game a bit. But just reading the 200 page guide is not enough , experience is vital for this game. Every game is different, no games are the same. You need to learn how to defend your flanks, how to assault enemy positions and other strategy's for turning the battle into your teams favour. You also need to learn the strength and weaknesses of the unit's you command on the battlefield. It also takes a LONG time to win your first game , this is because EVERYONE on the team is vital to the outcome of the battle, so expect many defeats at first, but when you get more experience and training the wins will come rolling in. Overall this game has a difficult learning curve BUT after learning to play properly the gameplay is amazing. Gameplay Verdict: 9 / 10Graphics:One of the best graphics for a Real-time strategy game I've ever seen. Of course you need a good computer to run it on high settings, but even not on high settings it looks good. The tank battles and Infantry battles in towns look good too. It's also great to see an enemy heavy tank go up in flames as your Spec Ops infantry sneaks up and blows it up, or watch as an artillery barrage kills a vast amount of charging infantry.Graphics verdict: 8 / 10Audio:The game sounds great! The gunshots of infantry battles in towns sound really realistic and going close up on an airplane and hearing the engine as it is getting ready to drop napalm on a load of infantry in a town is amazing!Audio Verdict: 8 / 10Overall: This game barely has any flaws , except that it has a large learning curve, you just can't pick up this game and start playing. But after that the game start's getting better and better as you win more and more battles.This game is amazing and a must buy for any strategy game fan.Final Verdict: 9 / 10

content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												This game right now is imbalanced, broken, buggy and kind of a♥♥♥♥♥♥show.  It pains me to say it because I genuinely love this game and it's predecessors, but I would not recommend buying it.There's several reasons and I will bullet point them (feel free to convo me for a more thorough analysis)1: Community: the general chat is some of the worst people you will ever talk to in life.  (yes it's really that bad, think nazi apologists, excessive trolls, people with 0 games who sit in the chat all day deterring newcomers)2: Community (dev/"marshall" perspective) the devs and their chosen few (Marshalls), ignore reasonable player input in terms of balance, ridicule people who disagree with them openly, and generally break the game every time they get a chance to suit their view.  Sure, they're the devs, they can do whatever they want.  Does this make the game better?  No.3: Balance: This game is terribly imbalanced and despite many many user threads detailing very reasonable steps to start the balancing process it has remained so.  As a amatter of fact they continue to introduce half baked mechanics that break the game further such as "stealth infantry" who were bugged and invisible for weeks.4: playerbase: This game is rapidly dying.  A few weeks ago there would be about 900 people on during a weeknight.  This week it has fallen to about 600, and it's been decreasing prior to a few weeks ago.  The chat trolls and high learning curve don't help.  Neither does the pompous attitudes of the devs and players.5: Naval: it's broken, it sucks, and no one uses it.  They should have just patched ALB (the previous game) and stayed away from naval entirely.  There's about 15 ships for each side, and none of them balance at all with the rest of the game.  It's literally a folly.I actually have a guide on this game where I go through a few play throughs.  I won't be wasting my time on it anymore because basically this game is done.  It's a real shame because it used to be my go-to and really did scratch that tactical/strategic itch.  Now it's more just a spam/click fest with very little tactical thikning or strategy involved.  Basically you spam OP units or planes or artillery.  I know that sounds trite, but that's what's it's moved to.  It used to be a game based on positioning and tactical movment of limited forces.  Now it's more of an APM/creep game.

Posted: April 6
												Only 8 hours played, and it's clear that this game is absolutely mind-blowing. It's basically Total War: Modern Warfare. But way more in-depth and complex than anything in Total War. Hundreds of real world units, and you have to manage your actions down to tiny details like making sure your tanks face forwards, and retreat in reverse etc. Units have weak spots on their armour (such as the back of a tank) etc, and using smart tactics can turn a battle around in seconds. There is far too much to explain here, but I highly recommend this to any fan of strategy games, this is absolutely one of the best I've played.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2015
												(THis is like a review but is kinda not like a review. Well maybe like a rant or advices or whatever. Up to you people to decide, i just don't care)This game is definitely not for everyone, I tried forcing..ahem...i mean advised 2 of my friends to play this game and it didn't work. It is a 'dog eat dog' world out there and only the strongest will survive. Only the most willing and determine can survive in the multiplayer realm of Wargame: Red Dragon. ...... OR just play the damn game longer and learn the basics, there's a damn 200 page guide for this game and almost no one bothers to read it. And stop talking on the damn wargame:chat, YOU FOOLS!! (unless you like the chat.it's a very interesting place where you can talk about politics, rage at people, discuss about fetishes and other crap.)After fighting your first 100 battles or less while losing about 3/4 of them or all of it, you soon will be at the point where you say "Why am I playing this game??", "JEEBUS F@#K this Game!", " WHy did I buy this game?" Don't quit. DON"T F##King quit. Everybody has experience this point of time at least once in this game. This event is inevitable, hundreds of new players quit at this point of time. SO I advise to you to not give up!This game has a very high learning curve and THERE is player stacking or pub stomping in this game which is the biggest reason why alot of newcomers quit this game but there is a somewhat-valid reason for this....YOU are suppose to make a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Team or join up with veteran players.the main reason why you keep losing is that veteran players will team up together and pub stomp new players. There is no proper matchmaking system. EUGEN puts too much faith into the wargame community to make one. Nobody likes to lose, so these veteran players have friends who are at the same skill level and call upon them to join in their battles. They will then proceed to rain down hellfire (LOL hellfire missiles if you know what I mean)  upon their unsuspecting foes. Generally, the strongest and most skilled players are those who have played the game the longest and have a high victory ratio and also rank. (victory ratio is overrated, gametime experience is all that matters. Nobody plays rank anyways). (This part is just a estimation so might not be true)60-150+ hours players are mainbulk of the community. Anything above that range makes up a larger minority compare to the number of beginner players, these players are considered quite good as they have played long enough to handle tough situations ingame and have a good understanding of the mechanics and unit stats.  There are 1000+ hour players, these guys are the most dangerous of foes but luckily there is only a few of them. Making friends or apprentice under any players from 100+ hours and above is already good enough to teach you tips and tricks of the game. There is alot of notable players in this game, so you get to meet them on a regular basis depending on timezone. The best time to play wargame is usually when it is from morning and night time in the US, this is where most players from all around the world are on. Amount of players flactuate between 400 to 1000 plyaers depending on time.This game is not a singleplayer game, it is a multiplayer game. Like Battlefield 3, there is singleplayer campaign but it is not satisfying. it only serves to be a place to just practise abit. TUTORIAL IS USELESS!! There is no tutorial, it's just some pages on the menu that call itself a tutorial. Read the 200-pg guide or find veteran players to show you the ropes. Just randomly go into lobbies, look at their stats then add them to your friends list. Seriously find someone to teach you, or you will have to do it the hardway like like how I did. So many defeats... so, so many defeats...Naval combat is what most people are dissapointed about. If you are like me, who is okay or fine with it then don't bother reading this part. Opinions on the naval combat is like a mixed basket, people complain that naval combat is useless or is not what they wanted. Eugen tried its best to make it right but people still don't like it. Perfecting naval combat is not easy, especially in this type of game considering the mechanics to how this game works. Let's face it, this is not the first game that have tried to implement naval combat and it didn't work out. For example , the total war series' naval combat is boring as hell and most other games with naval combat are clunky or broken. Trying to fix naval combat for a rts/rtt game is like trying to fix the entire game genre. Atleast wargame's naval combat was not like in its beta/alpha version, oh god the HORROR!?Lastly even after playing this game for quite sometime, I still find alot of moments ingame which surprise me. The TRUE satisfaction of this is not about winning or losing, it is about experienceing the craftiness and usefulness of tactics implemented by players. Fighting battles against foes who are equally match with you or, holding your ground against a foe who have numerical or have tactical superiority over you, or managing to repel a massive unexpected infantry BANZAI charge with the help of close air support and artillery from your teammates, or working together with your friends to attack a heavily defended sector or so on. 10v 10 Battles are massive and intense. Even the tactical matches where you only control a tiny amount of troops are just as mind taxing. This is a game which will test your skills in controlling your units and your teamwork with other players. You will realise the true values of this game only after putting your heart and time in to it. These values are why there a still many players playing this game since its beta/alpha stage.

												I played as North Korea.I bombed my own peasant infantry when the Americans attacked my lines.I sent new troops to replace them.My housemate sat dumbfounded as he had just lost 2 squads of high-end American infantry in Bradley IFVs, an M1 Abrams and a fancy AA piece; 100s of points of high quality men and equipment, while I lost about 30 peasants.---------------------------------Then I assualted my housemate's lines..He had a few pieces of expensive tow along a distant treeline, a very dangerous attack helicopter, more fancy AA, and a single M1 Abrams which was parked in the middle of the road at prime range from a river crossing.... I sent 64 T-34s ... straight across the bridge ...Albiet, I had a bit of mortar support to take out the tow, and I somehow bombed the helicopter out of the air.But the T-34s had to close into near point-blank range to even score a chance at penetrating the M1 Abrams, so it sorta ended with about 5 or 6 of my T-34s surviving, while the M1 Abram's carcass was literally surrounded on all sides by near 60 destroyed T-34s. (fyi, I believe the T-34 must be stationary to fire)--------------------------------------------------In every case that I play as a 2nd rate power, I give the enemy a bloody nose, no matter whether I win or lose.My only wish was that there was a WW2 version of this game - with a few changes to account for infantry without transports, brigade / regiment structuring, fortifications (in attack  / defend scenarios), and fixed or towed guns.Oh, but there is a hilarious learning cliff. My housemate didn't know was SEAD was, and kept wondering what was blowing up his RADAR AA.

												I've played the Wargame series since the beginning with European Escalation. It is immensly complex and has a tough learning curve, but is definitely the best stratgy game on the market. I was excited to see there would be a third game, and immediately preordered it and started playing the beta. There is a lot of balacing to be done, but that is not the reason I'm giving this a negative review. The game was advertised as incorporating navies for each country and naval combat mechanics. There are a grand total of 30 ships for 17 nations, yes 30. Blufor and Redfor each get a pool of ships from their nations' navies, and some major navies such as the United State's and the UK's are sorely underrepresesnted. Naval fights are blobs to see who can mass the most ships with CIWS and missiles, and there are no tactics at all. I love the wargame series, but I cannot in good conscience advise you to buy this game. Buy Airland Battle, which is far more balanced and doesnt lie to consumers about its features. Really dissapointed with Eugen, I had very high hopes for this game.

number of helpful: 17 of 21 people (81%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2016
												One of the best strategy games I have ever played. It takes a while to get into the game, but once you understand the subtle differences between the units you will find that this game can be played for hundreds of hours without getting boring.Each unit has several key metrics (e. g. range (air/heli/ground), speed, size, surpression, rate of fire, armour piercing & high-explosive damage, amount (e. g. 10 soldiers in a squad)) and up to 3 weapons. For anti-air tanks this can mean that the vehicle will boast anti air missiles (infrared) and a dual 25mm canon based on a radar targetting system. As long as the 25mm canon is activated, enemy ECM planes can snipe your AA, however, if you turn off the radar they won't be able to spot your unit. Another factor adding to the longevity of the game is the deck system. You choose a block (PACT/NATO), a Nation (I believe about 15 on the NATO side and 10-12 on the PACT side at the moment) and a specialisation (support, marines, air, armour, motorised). Each nation has a plethora of units (about 80 I believe).The community isn't the largest one due to the sophisticated nature of the game, but there's still sufficient lobbies to find a game at all times.Eugen recently starting releasing new nation decks, which keeps the game alive and inserts fresh content from time to time.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2015
												Warfare on a large scale. There is so much to keep up with. So many tactical options. One of the most realistic stratagy games there is. The unit roster is huge. block to block infantry battles. Tank warfare over planes. Ambushes coming from forests. AA hiding in rubble. Long range artillary strikes to lay down smoke for advancing troops. Bombers, Fighters and SEAD planes. Tons of naval warfare which I am still working on understanding. You have to take so much into account that is just not present in other games. Like fuel consumption, terrain for vehicle speed, whether to land or keep your helicopter in the air, To napalm objectives and sacrafice future cover, What transports to use as they cost differnt amounts, the veterancy of troops to bring, what time period of weaponry they should have. This is the most intense large scale modern warfare game to date.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
												One word for this game would be: "Amazing".Before you read the whole wall of text Ill give a tl'dr for lazy people: Great game, hard to get into, good community, ask for help get help, even better game if you know more about what you're doing.I entered this game expecting an rts I could spend days on. Boy I did, but not with what I was expecting from the start.Which would be playing the game. Now what I did my first few hours after playing one singleplayer mission and noticing that I got shrekt, was reading and watching, alot of reading and watching.What was I watching? Youtube videos of the game being played, and help with deckbuilding.What was I reading? A huge guide, of 200 pages covering the basics. Sadly, I didn't get past 20 pages of the guide, because I'm lazy and play a game to play the game, not to read about how to play the game. Thus I started playing the game. I found a subreddit, (www.reddit.com/r/wargame ), and a great post on there ( http://www.reddit.com/r/wargame/comments/2futc3/announcing_the_wargame_learning_program/ ) So joined these guys's teamspeak, and asked if some could help me. They could, I got help in deckbuilding, and unit control, and they played some games with me explaining things, while kicking♥♥♥♥♥Im in love with the game now, I now know a bit about NATO and PACT, know the basics and feel confident enough to join random multiplayer games. And whenever I do, it's amazing, wheter it's a wellfought loss, or a hardfought victory, you always learn.Pro's  Incredibly in depth  (IMO) good balancing  You can create your own fighting force with deckbuilding  Loads of units  Lots of unit diversity. Tanks, AA, APC, infantry, Helis, jets, Artillery, even logistics!  A lot of maps  A lot of support for new players from the community, not so much the game itself  Fun and open communityCon's  Really hard to get into (but you can overcome this, if you just keep playing, and ask for help)  A lot of maps but some maps feel like they are the same with just a few small changes  REALLY HARD TO GET INTO  Hard to find other newbies to play games with, but possible.   ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ingame tutorials, you have to watch everything on youtube, and really ask for help.That was it, buy it, and play it. Its fun and amazing and great and hard and challenging!

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												It was poorly delivered...Firstly,When the game was first announced, there was a lot of talk of naval been added, which is the biggest feature of the game aside from the fact that it now focuses on the Korean Peninsula and has the Asian nations in the fight.Sadly during the Alpha, navel was horrible... The OPFOR (now called REDFOR) was overpowered in terms of the naval aspect of the game forcing NATO players to try to ditch naval altoghter and try to win by land. This can be seen in some of the early videos of the game during beta.In the game current state, the naval feature is still looked down upon by players because it still involves the same way to win as it did in Alpha, although there seems to be somewhat less blobbing of the ships.  But to a beginner, he would come to think that blobbing his ships together is a good thing.Which there is nothing wrong with that thought, because the only way or the main way your ships will be destroyed are by missiles.  They can fend off the incoming missiles using a Close-in weapon system or CIWS.  While one ship that has the CIWS can stop (at best) two missiles, a second ship will stop a third.  So following that pattern you can see why players tend to “blob” their ships.The same thing can be said for the player who is doing the attack.  More missiles means you’ll need a better defense and if your opponent defense is not strong enough, some missiles will punch through.  Which in terms... leads to the spamming.So, during my entire time of playing this game (which was a total of 300 hours) I can honestly say that I tried to avoid any games that involved naval, because it seemed like a stupid feature to play. So if your looking into buying this game for the naval warfare, don't because it feels like a taked on feature that doesn't introduce anything new after your first 2-4 battles. It's nothing more but who can shot more missiles at once will win...Now my second biggest problem which is that new deck system, or the number of limitations they now have on it.  For me, that deck system ALB (Wargame: AirLand Battle) had was perfect.  Comparing it to this game it now feels like I can no longer put a specific nation to fight in various ways, because of the newly added five card limit to a section for standard deck. This newly added limitation was strongly noticeable for me when putting together the infantry for my decks.  The first limitation I had to get over was the five card limit for a standard deck, while the second limitation I have to get over was the number of specific transports I was allowed to have for my infantry.The second limitation was strongly noticeable when I created my decks for the SSSR. (USSR or the Soviet Union) The number of the BMP3’s I was able to use in this game was laughable compared to the number I was able to have in ALB.  Which was odd because in that game the BMP3 was a prototype but mind you, it no longer is in this game. So oddly enough the word "prototype" means you can have more according to this game.  But ignoring that and talking about the fact that they're the BMP3's only comes with one of the weakest infantry in the game. This helps illustrates that the added deck limitations makes more units useless than others and also shows something I hated most about this series. It’s that units and the things they come with aren’t very modular…Now my last problem with the game is the community.  The number of “pub-stomps” has increased dramatically in this game to the point where you’ll see game lobbies named “randoms only”.  Your chances of coming across a game that is not a “pub-stomp” are like 1 in 10.But here's the kicker of this problem... When players ask for help the on the forums.  Typically I’ve seen a number of responses that state, “Play with friends”.  Which if you think about it, that’s what “pub-stomps” are made of.  Players playing with friends or clan mates against randomly teamed up players. Basically the number one solution is also cause of the problem…Then the typical attitude of the community...  Typically when one loses the match in this game, chances are they will leave.  Which puts you at further disadvantage making it nearly impossible to win. (But really it’s not like you have a chance when you’re paired with un-coordinated team members. So you’re better off quitting yourself…)To make even worse, sometimes you’ll come across ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s that will taunt you and your team while you’re losing to them.So because of this issue I literally limited myself to only playing the “10v10” matches, which oddly enough is something everybody is beginning to do because of the issue.  Basically the game is really only fun if you’re playing in those 10vs10 matches or 1v1’s. This issue with the community was a huge blow to me for this game because I primarily played this game with random players in the 2v2’s 3v3’ 6v6’s etc…Sadly the last thing I retreated to (the 10v10's) also is suspected of pub-stomps acts also. I can even recall me being kicked from a few servers to make room for friends…Speaking of being kicked from games... Because of eugene’s GENIUS idea of adding a view profile button for others to see the stats of players has also caused me to be kicked or even banned from some people’s games all because of my low "victory ratio" due to me playing with randoms all the time. Then you have morons in the game that will judge other players based on their victory ratio... Just note this, if you have a victory ratio anything less than 40%, You might be considered a retard that doesn't know how to unistall the game, nor exit out of it...I have yet to see a response from the developers themselves on why they added that button. If you played the first game of the series (WarGame: European Escalation) you should remember that you had a number that was large next to your avatar. It signified what level you were. They basically added that feature back just disguised as a button...Since we're on the topic of features needed to be removed or added, I’ve also have yet to see a response from the developers on why they remove the visibility of the deck names...  Which is something most players took pride in during the second installation of the series.So now that I’ve said all the bad things what are the good?Well, you now have the Asian nations in this series and the game now takes place on the Korean Peninsula.  You also have more units!  Also because of the crappy implementation of naval, your units can finally cross Rivers, which adds more dynamics to game also getting rid of or minimizing “chokepoints”.But honestly these are the only things I can think of that are good.  Overall I will say that as far as multiplayer goes, the game deliver"s" poorly and was deliver"ed" poorly.  Since that first launch, the game was horribly imbalanced, forcing a number of players to wait for a balancing patch or what has been called "DLC" which took two months... Why not make this an expansion to Airland Battle? Because all it really does is add a few new features, units and maps. This is something I've been seening happening a lot lately with games. Before what was called "expansion packs" are now becoming Yearly "re-releases" of the game you've already bought. EE:2012 | ALB:2013 | RD:2014Then you have a fragmented community amoung your three different games that really are the same thing, just with more stuff.The series is great, but this game was the worst of them all…

number of helpful: 13 of 14 people (93%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 10, 2015
												First of all, this is a very under rated quality game. Massive battles, wide variety of strategies and units, good single player experience (though the computer does cheat) and a multiplayer experience that deserves to be in the professional gaming leagues. This is an absolute gem of a game for any strategy game player.One of the great aspects about the game is that it makes losing troops very difficult for me, but just like real war, sometimes you have to push your troops in order to take an objective even though you know you'll take losses. As a commander, it is your job to make those losses worth the effort.While I am mostly praising this game, there are some big drawbacks that can potentially be patched with a hotfix. #1 There are several hidden stats in the game. Units with silenced weapons are not clearly marked and neither are units with auto-loaders. In the forums it has been stated that there will be a stat indicating auto-loaders with a proper description if I remember right, so this is likely to be fixed in the future but I wonder if they will reveal all the hidden stats and abilities in a clear defining manor.#2 The multiplayer community can be quite toxic. For a game that focuses on its multiplayer aspect, it is the biggest detriment to the game since you will have people who leave the game just because their initial push failed or even if they lose one unit. This often causes a cascade effect where people leave  one after another and while there are bonuses for the remaining team members and it is quite possible for the remaining members to win on their own, it often means that there are too many fronts for so few people to deal with and there is nothing that can be done. In addition to this, team killing is a potential problem. Luckily the team killing problem is rare, but when you're waiting in a lobby for a 10v10 map for about half an hour just to begin, it is quite disheartening when one of your team mates decides to bomb the spawning location killing most of the allied troops then proceed to bomb all of the supply bases and command vehicles before leaving.#3 Artillery is very prevelant and there are few counters. This is somewhat a reality of war that I mostly don't mind in this game, but this is bad in a few ways. One of which is that it just becomes an annoyance when you're constantly getting spammed by arty even when you take little to no losses since it often isn't used properly. Another way is that you'll often have team mates on your own team that don't know how to use artillery properly, then they waste all of their supplies achieving almost nothing, and then they start taking from allied supplies which deprives front line troops with repairs, ammo, and fuel. The final way that the artillery spam is a bad thing is because people neglect to mark the locations they are sending artillery shells (or bombing runs from airplanes) and thus there becomes friendly fire issues.My suggestion for avoiding the pit falls that somewhat plague this game is to manage to get some friends in the game that you know are reliable, or even better yet, bring friends with you to buy the game and play with you. It's the best way to play and provides a lot of enjoyment for anyone who can work together as a team.Update as of 11/28/2016: With the new nation packs being required to pay for unlocking there is a slight feeling that things are turning to "pay to win" and this is a legitimate concern in a game like this. I can say that the nations that have been released so far are actually pretty balanced and they finally give bluefor a couple of capabilities that Redfor players have had all along. That being said, since these capabilities are so strong and made Redfor nations superior before, it also gives the feeling that the older Bluefor countries are obsolete in many ways and not only should these capabilities not be held behind a pay wall, but the older countries that are more limited could use a facelift.

number of helpful: 12 of 13 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14
												"War never changes." Is a quote thrown around often.  While philosophically it may not, strategically it sure as hell does.  Wargame: Red Dragon is a lesson in that.  Each multiplayer game contains lots of stress and nail biting maneuvers when player skill is balanced, but for the inexperienced it’s a dredge.  The learning curve is much of a curve, but more of a vertical line, when passed you can hold your own against another experienced player.  This is a target that I am still trying to hit, while I pride myself as a quick learner every map, every game, and every encounter is a mix between luck, recon, and unit composition, which I haven't quite nailed down yet.  A huge variety of units is at your discretion, from the absurd to the very practical, and all of them are worth giving a shot, provided that they are utilized properly.  The controls are simple and endlessly customizable.  The UI is a bit big by default but you can change the size to fit your preference in the options.  The game allows you to make everything just as you like it, which is great for someone who is moving from another game and wants their hot-keys to be the same or someone like me who wants less clutter on the screen.The AI that you can fight is not a very good opponent, it makes stupid decisions but it's a great way to learn the controls, and test performance (which unless you play on a potato is great).  Take a quick run through a campaign that is intrigues to you and then try the multiplayer.  I also suggest sticking with the default decks, or if you are so inclined building your own, be warned every unit has a ton of info, and some aren't as good as the prices suggest, read each stat and use the compare button as needed, also check out the competition through the armory, it lets you see every vehicle you could ever want to know about or kill, also hover over icons if you don’t know what they mean, sometimes they have multiple definitions that change between units even if they look the same, they can also give hints to the role of the unit.  Alternately if you tire of the provided decks but don't trust your building skills, you can import them, all it requires is a simple copy and paste and there are great resources online.This game is a wonderfully strategic, if you have the cash pick it up now with the Israel DLC, otherwise wait for a sale.  Any new players would be a great help in revitalizing the player base, and I can promise that this is the best realistic strategy game you can buy.  This game offers hours of endless–admittedly stressful–fun which I personally love, while games can run long, on a weekend it's a great way to break boredom.A couple of quick tips:RECON EVERYWHERE- there is no sense in charging blindCHEAP UNITS FIRST- when advancing it makes no sense to put your valuable units first, let the replaceable stuff take the hit, it can save you from a bad advanceDO NOT FORCE UNFAVORABLE ENGAGMENTS- unless you’ve been forced back to your spawn there is no reason to keep throwing units at a wall, you can always retreat, reorganize, and then soften your enemy with artillery or airstrikesIF YOU LIKE IT HIDDEN DISABLE ITS GUNS- if you want to keep a unit hidden in a forest or some other type of cover, make sure that their guns aren’t on, they stop being hidden when shooting, this is especially important for forward recon that doesn’t really have a need to fight, if you want it to fire just turn them back on.COMMUNICATE- if you are doing an air heavy rollout tell your team, so that they don’t waste points on their own aircraft, or if you want to take a specific point, call it out, so that your allies can focus efforts elsewhere.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												In a NutshellThis is hands down probably the best RTS I have ever played. If you like Strategy Games, Wargaming or RTS: you should give this gem a try.GameplayWargame Red Dragon is a Cold War RTS. Actually it is a mix between RTS and Wargaming (meant as a category of games). Instead of building a base you will create a "Deck" which symbolises your army. In each battle you can call in units from your deck, but every unit is limited. Depending on your choices in the deck creation, your army has only a limeted number of units. This gives this game a quite realistic approach in terms of resource management. You don't want to loose your men. The combat itself is again, a mix between realism and gameplay features. Although this game is not a full simulation, the battle evolves quite realistic. terrain, recognisance, supplies, weapon technology, morale - everything comes to account.GamestylesThere are 5 campaigns to play which involve a strategy map and the normal battles. The core of the game is mulitplayer and skrimish. You can also play this against the AI (alone or with your friends).As mentioned above: I can only recommend this game. The developpers made several free DLCs (Map Packs and Faction updates). If you are going to buy this game, I suggest the "200-Page Guide to Wargame: Rad Dragon" by SandyGunfox. 


200-Page Guide to Wargame: Red Dragon

number of helpful: 11 of 12 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
												The Good:Wargame Red Dragon provides a unique RTS experience that is plenty challenging, and frequently rewarding. The playable units are beautifully detailed, in both form and function. I loved learning the difference between semi-active and f&f air-to-air missiles, and the paint jobs on the Leopard-2 models look phenomenal. Players who value detail and authenticity will be in for a real treat. Each individual unit has its own set of statistics and abilities that a good Commander should be well familiar with. What level of optics are your recon infantry equipped with? What is the dispersion rating of your long-range artillery? How much armor penetration can you get with your anti-tank guided missiles? Are your APCs amphibious? Are your surface-to-air missiles radar-guided? What's the turning radius for the F-15 Eagle? Do your main battle tanks have enough top armor to withstand enemy artillery bombardment? What may seem like an overwhelming array of available choices to a novice player is actually a true tacticians dream. There are a dizzying number of play styles, but it's up to you to make your tactic successful.The Bad:The learning curve. Everyone complains about it, and rightfully so. With each new Steam Sale comes an army of new players who insist on throwing units at the enemy, Starcraft style. The instant gratification type players typically choose the most expensive units to feed the other team, and it's not uncommon to see fighter jets casually sailing over the enemy lines, only to be effortlessly swatted out of the sky by enemy AA. Worse, is that after the novice player has squandered all of the state-of-the-art units in his arsenal, he will promptly quit, leaving teammates to pick up the slack for the rest of the battle. Since the game has no form of quit penalty, this behavior often goes uncorrected.The Ugly:To this day, the game is punctuated by occasional bugs and crashes that the developers do not seem to have any intention of fixing. Units get caught on bridges, planes will clump up inside each other so they are destroyed by a single missile, sometimes selecting multiple units also selects a random unit on the other side of the map. And a match can be ruined at any time by a single team killer. Bomber aircraft can drop bombs on friendly units, but there is no way to target that bomber in response. Vote kick? Report player? Nope. The game has nothing of the sort. Players must visit the developer's official forum site and post a complaint. So instead of fixing glitches, and adding critical game features, the developers seem content with rolling out a new DLC every now and then, to rake in more money. I bought 0 of them.Conclusion:In spite of these shortcomings, I'm glad to say that I own and still play this game. I can't believe how much I've learned about battle tactics and modern war from the detail offered here. If you have more patience than a twelve-year-old, go ahead and pick this up the next Steam Sale. Be patient, have good Recon, take smart positions, and read the unit stats! See you on the battlefield.

It runs well if you let it auto-detect settings, even though it won't look pretty when zoomed in. It's quite fluid with a 650 Ti BOOST and doesn't appear to want more than 2GB VRAM at 1080p.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2016
												If you liked European Escalation then I suggest skipping Airland Battle and getting this one instantly instead.If you have no experience with the franchise yet I still suggest getting European Escalation and then this one.Airland Battle is cool, just... Red Dragon does everything it did, just more and better. European Escalation has a cool singleplayer campaign (it doesn't look as good with the two sequels) and it's just way simplier than the other two, making it a good game to learn how things work before engulfing yourself in Red Dragon, which has approximately one billion units from what I can tell.Honestly, if you're an RTS fan this is one of the best titles there are in my opinion. Since there are so many units the amount of strategies is really vast, every unit is a counter to some other unit and every unit has a unit that is its counter etc. It's like if the world had a great war of rock paper scissors, just with cool explosions and infantry destroying your♥♥♥♥♥in cities.-there's field of vision/scouting system, which means your units need to have a clear view of the enemy units in order for them to appear on your map, and there are special recon units that can spot the enemy more easily, so they're essential in your army and an essential target to destroy,-there's cover system in the forests and buildings, so it's harder to see your units while they're in there,-there's morale system that affects your units' aim when they're under pressure and eventually they might even flee,-there's size system, which means that the smaller the unit is the harder it is to hit it,-there's detailed armor plating system that forces you to position your units in such a way that they have the most amount of armor facing the danger, and if you can get your enemy from behind that's an easy kill,-there are random events like ammo explosion upon getting hit, or getting stuck on uneven terrain, which can often screw one over,-THERE'S JUST SO MUCH COOL STUFF OKAYThe graphics look absolutely gorgeous, which you could have not expected at first. Since you can zoom out literally into the freaking stratosphere and overlook the whole map at once, you may think the developers probably didn't bother with putting in a lot of details, but nope. You can then zoom in so close that you can take a look at the driver of your little jeep. Everything looks great and shiny, from water and terrain to the units themselves. Special effects such as shooting and explosions are also very pleasing to look at.Like I said, the singleplayer campaign is "ok". If you're in only for that then you'll be disappointed. The game focuses more on actual battles between players, but if you like playing skimrishes against the AI then it's there as well. You can now even team up with the AI, which wasn't a thing in EE. Depending on how you match your skills with other players the match can take from 15 minutes of absolute devastation of the unprepared party to about two hours, where your decks are exhausted and supplies dry, fighting with your damaged tanks without ammo and the most crap reserve units you had. You can also set the time limit artiffically if you wish, or make the match shorter or longer by taking a map of the appropriate size. Commanding your units on a large landscape and capturing areas one after one when there's still so much ahead of you really makes you feel like if you were a part of some great war.Overall it's just so good, I love it to bits. I don't have too many hours in it simply because European Escalation had me covered for the longest time... but man. This is the kind of game I always wanted to have.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												This is quite lengthy but I've basically split it into FAQs which I see new players often ask in the game chat (this is mainly for people who have never played any of the Wargame series before instead of people coming to this from EE and ALB):Q: Is the game hard to learn?Yes and no. It's easy to learn how to play; it's very hard to learn how to play well (which in my opinion is where a lot of the fun lies).Q: Is it a bit overwhelming to new players?It was for me, and I think that can be what puts some people off this game before they've really gotten into it. The huge number of units is quite scary if you've never played any of the Wargame series before (I hadn't). Perseverance is key at the start, but once you get used to the game, you'll find this a joy rather than something to be afraid of.Q: Should I play the tutorials first?There are actually no playable tutorials in RD. The tutorials are basically just text with instructions on what to do. It is worth giving these a read to start with, but I appreciate that this is likely to be quite boring for some players (although if you really dislike this idea, I'm not sure if this is really the game for you).Do not despair, however. There are plenty of people who have made Youtube vids to give you instruction not only on the mechanics of the game but also on deck-building (which is important to this game but not something you need to spend tonnes of time on if you don't want to). I can highly recommend ICBMRaptor (I love his tutorials and other Wargame vids, it's worth watching them if you're new since watching someone else play multiplayer games can be a good way of learning), Bubblebox (nice, clear explanantions of stuff), Boltsauce and VulcanHDGaming.Q: What's the community like?When I first started out and was resorting to the general chat for questions, my experience was pretty good (and I maintain that the community is better than a fair number of other multiplayer games I've played).However, recently the game has obviously been on sale and it seems that lots of people have picked it up while it's cheap. This has led to quite a few - how can I put this - "not-so-nice/mature" people entering the game and general chat. My mute list has been filling up a bit recently :( (prepare for spam sometimes)On the upside, two things: 1)  you can just close the chat window if you don't want to see this, and 2) a lot of the people who helped me and people who are good players are still around and willing to help out :)Q: What's the gameplay like?Sometimes intense, sometimes slow-paced. It depends who you're playing against and what your opponent's play style is like. I won't say a lot more than that because it is quite hard to generalise due to the vast amount of unit combos/deck types you can have combined with the different play styles of different people.However, one thing I will add: beware of spammers and stacked games. If you enter a lobby and you see 3 people on, say, the BLUFOR team and RED is empty, check their stats immediately. This will help you decide whether these are just 3 friends who want to play together (and maybe aren't that good) or if they're 3 pro players who want to ROFL-stomp some newbies. Spammers can also be an issue, especially in 10 v 10 or 20 v 20 games. Some players will just chuck tonnes of helos/artillery at you, which can be frustrating if you're not ready for it and they crush you. However, if you and your team are ready for it - and act accordingly (i.e. making sure you deploy enough AA to keep yourselves covered and not taking predictable routes to avoid arty, as well as coordinating) - the boot will be on the other foot when you smash their spam and then utterly wreck them ;)Q: Is the AI any good?In general, it's fine. Sometimes it will do smart things (i.e. try to flank you, change its attack approach according to what you bring against it, especially if you thwart it once, etc.) but often it will also do some stupid things (e.g. advance infantry across open ground towards tanks).I would always recommend when starting out that you go into Skirmish mode and play lots of games against the CPU, as this will let you become familiar with the various maps and gameplay. The CPU will punish you if you make mistakes, so this will also teach you some good if basic things to be aware of when playing and basic tactics. Contrary to what some may think, I would NOT recommend immediately jumping into the single-player campaigns - you will likely just get frustrated unless you learn the game mechanics in Skirmish mode first.I have spent a lot of hours in this game just playing against the CPU because it is good fun :) if you find it boring by yourself, team up with a friend and go comp-stomping. If you have general chat open, you might see some good players also opening comp-stomp lobbies for games vs the CPU.Q: Does the AI cheat?Yes. As far as I know, Easy mode AI gets the same number of deployment points as you (you'll learn what these are when you start the game) but it gets a slight bonus to how fast it receives them during a battle. Medium gets more of a bonus to this and gets c. 1,000 extra points to start with (don't quote me on that, I just remember seeing it somewhere), and so on. This might put some people off playing against the CPU.However, it really isn't that bad for the most part. The CPU, while making mistakes, is sensible and plays well enough that it can be a challenge, even without resorting to spam (which it can do on higher difficulties). It can also be fun sometimes to face off against a vastly superior force than you and be able to defeat them with the right defensive tactics (or offensive if you're particularly good/bold/brave/stupid :P).Q: I hear the naval combat sucks. Is this true?There are definitely some issues with it. It isn't as varied as land combat, that's for sure. However, saying it "sucks" would be too harsh. Naval combat is fun, especially on maps with mixed land/naval action! Playing against the CPU can prevent issues with spam which may occur when facing players - otherwise I actually enjoy it and don't find it "imbalanced" as some sayQ: Am I good at it?Hehehehehehehehehhehehehehehehehehe no. Q: Do you care?Nope! :DTHE FOLLOWING TWO QUESTIONS AREN'T SPECIFICALLY FOR THOSE CONSIDERING BUYING THE GAME, BUT QUITE OFTEN APPEAR IN GENERAL CHAT FROM PLAYERS STARTING OUT:Q: I see people in chat using flags/coloured text. How do I do that?


How to Flag! v2.0 
A Guide for Wargame: Red Dragon
By: MobilizedPanda

			All zeh flags you need to spam the Wargame main chat! (v2.0 Now in technicolor!)		


There you go ;) (but please don't spam. Don't want my mute list getting any bigger! :P)Q: When I try to join games, it says that I have the "wrong version" (or something similar). Why is that?Make sure you read the Steam news feed for this game - recently, Eugen (the developers) released a beta version of their latest DLC for this game (coming out officially in January). If you try to access most servers without using beta (unless it is a specific non-beta server), you likely won't be able to join. Joing is easy, though. Simply right click on the game in your Steam library, select "Properties", then select "Beta" and choose "Opt in" on the right-hand side of the window.If you are any sort of RTS fan, I can highly recommend this game! :) come and join us for some great fun! I hope people found this helpful.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												Tl:dr; It's epic, intense, extremely detailed and takes a while to learn.Do you cringe to see your RTS tanks and helicopters move at the same speed? Do you want a modern style RTS on a big scale? Do you want semi-realistic ranges, strength and fighting power for anti-air, vehicles, tanks, infantry? Look no further. Wargame has (to me) been the breath of fresh air the RTS genre sorely needed. It's on a massive scale, and allows you to zoom out to see the entire map, but you can also zoom in to follow a particular unit in incredible detail. This game has been around for a while, but thanks to the community, the devs are still working on putting new nations out. Next to the positive things mentioned above, here are a few things you should consider before buying:-The scale works both ways, it's easy (as a beginner) to get stomped by something you didn't know existed.-The learning curve is very steep in the beginning, know that you need to make your own unit deck, since the default ones are useless.-Don't read the chat if you're easily offended.-(in my opinion) There's little GOOD wargame footage on youtube etc. from which you can learn as a beginner, reach out to the community to get some good decks at the start!

content:
Posted: November 20, 2015
												Solid game. Having 16 years of gaming experience (across all platforms, genres, etc) I can easily say this is one of the best games I've ever played. It really is just a well rounded game. People who enjoy intense strategy will most likely enjoy this game. The learning curve is relatively steep. So my advice is player multiplayer, with the expectation you will be defeated constantly for your first month. But instead of quitting out of games, learn from the better players. Once you start getting a few key aspects down, it is not difficult to become a competent player. Matchmaking can be a little one sided at times. But remain positive... it is through failing and learning that'll you'll become a very good player. People don't master this over night. That all being said though, the game is still massively better then alot of other strategy games out there. And it is very easy to become absorbed by it. Community online is healthy. Id like to think after the disappointment I've seen around Act of Aggression, the developers will return to make another one of these games. Only time will tell - until then I'll keep enjoying this game. I highly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: April 24
												This is hands-down the finest RTS ever made.  The level of detail and sheer complexity (and associated learning curve) are unmatched.  Other reviews cover this well though so I won't elaborate on this.After playing 700+ games (on a different Steam account), I must say though that it suffers from a horribly fatal flaw -- you can see the statistics of other players in the lobbies.  Why is this a problem?  Team stacking.  It's horrendous -- I might have played one game in ten that was balanced.  With all the others, the "smart" players (myself included), click around to see which team is better, then go to that team.  And the cycle repeats until you get a team of noobs against a team with 5000+ games of experience between them.  This leads to other problems.  It can sometimes take 30+ minutes to fill a lobby, as skilled players join the team destined to lose, realize it, and quit.  Or they linger hoping a spot on the to-win team opens up, then quit en masse right before the game starts.  Or anonymous lobby hosts will kick newer players and people they aren't buddies with off of the stacked team.If Eugen simply removed this option -- the ability to see the win ratios and game counts of other players -- this game would be very near perfect.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												As opposed to normal categories such as visuals, gameplay etc, I shall address this game as its individual parts and mechanics (specific mechanics and additions), primarily how the game is different from past entries. This review is for people who are familiar with wargame to an extent and may contain jargon, my apologies. For those who are not familiar with the wargame series, it is a military simulation (to a degree) of Communist aligned nations fighting NATO and capitalist aligned nations. Each side, and the subdivisions (coalitions and nations) have their own strengths and weaknesses, and most importantly their own varieties of units. According to the game's files, there are around 1500 unique deployable units in wargame, and this is part of the series' appeal. Battles are fought in real time, with emphasis on tactics and positioning, as opposed to base building and unit micro and the pace is slower than many RTS games out there. Think ARMA, appropriated as an RTS with the vehicle damage modelling of Company of Heroes with the map scale of Supreme Commander and the UI and setting of World in Conflict mishmashed with some of the atmosphere of EndWar. Or something. Its probably better to watch a video of the game to see what is is like. Wargame: Red Dragon is in many ways a series of steps forward as opposed to a leap and a bound from AirLand Battle. The foremost change is the addition of naval and new units that accomodate this new mechanic. Unfortunately - to put it bluntly  -the naval gameplay is quite broken. However, it is not the black pit of despair that trawling the forums and boards would lead you to believe. While inherently flawed in its execution, there are redeeming features. NAVAL:Well, like I said, its quite broken, but not for the reasons many people seem to think. The biggest issue that impacts immersion and gameplay is the scale. It is simply out of scale entirely to have Soveremeny destroyers and Arleigh Burke (oops I mean "Kongo") destroyers duking it out 5 kilometres from shore and 2 kilometres from each other. Ships in real life almost never meet to exchange cannon fire. This means for balance, the ships in wargame are nerfed to hell, and even then, they are very powerful. The scale should have been increased or naval should not have been included. Naval pathfinding is an issue, with collisions and whats become "balls of death", ugly bunched masses so that CIWS reaches critical mass. Redfor definitely has an advantage with not one, but TWO 500 point heavy ship options. But, the general strat in naval is clustered ships potshotting with missiles until inevitably, Blu air inflicts unsustainible losses or Red destroyers close with the Blu fleet. River boats, on the other hand, work fine, if a teensy bit overpowered vs land. Then again, I've seen a T34/85 Obr 55 kill a Kongo, so go figure. GAMEPLAY GENERAL: For the most part, it works fine, there is a measured sense of balance in asymmetry. There seems to always be overbuffing of the recipient nations following a DLC release, but that is a minor issue. The gameplay remains largely the same since AirLand Battle, with the inclusion of naval not matching the revolutionary change that the inclusion of jets was. Air has been nerfed slightly with better AA options across the board and tanks are less viable as well, with seemingly every single unit being geared to kill tanks - a hyperbole, but an apt one. Artillery has been buffed significantly since  The battles are fast and hectic, with 10v10s a sight to behold. The most popular modes in public multiplayer are Destruction-kill more of the enemy, and Conquest-capture points and gain victory points to win. Both modes have their pros and cons, with Destruction boiling down into static trench warfare, artillery slugging  being the decider and Conquest seemingly being an excuse for most people to "suicide their entire bloody deck in the first five minutes". However, with competent teams on both sides, Wargame multiplayer is an enjoyable affair, but inevitably, with unpleasant people in public games. This cannot be helped.SINGLEPLAYER:SP exists in the form of offlien skirmish with the AI and dynamic "Theatre of War" style campaigns. Both are marred horrendously by the laughably bad AI. The extent of the AI is grouping a bunch of ground offensive units and fast moving them down the nearest road straight into your defenses. As a stopgap solution to the bad AI, Eugen upped the availiblity, income rate and starting income of the AI's forces, meaning, most skirmish matches are zombie wave modes. Custom decks make skirmishes bearable, but still needs work. The "dynamic" campaign unfolds on a Total War style grand campaign map, with turn based gameplay. While better in quality than ALB's campaign in terms of AI and presentation, it loses some of the freedom and scale of ALB, in exchange for a more scripted affair. The actual battles are disappointing to say the least. The campaign map basically serves as a connector for a series of skirmishes against a zerg rush AI. We'll see if the "Second Korean War" DLC improves things.DECKS AND UNITS: The deck builder remains largely unchanged. In Wargame, starting forces are chosen from a pool of units in a deck you have constructed. Everthing comes in cards, with limited availiblity, both of the cards and the units themselves, which fill up slots in a grid, categorised into various unit roles. This is where the meat of the game is IMO and makes the 1500~ units a legitimate feature that makes sense as opposed to filler. Deckbuidling is one of the most fun and involved processes in wargame, with a single slot, card or activation point (How many slots you can fill with cards) making a world of difference on the battlefield. The armory is wonderfully presented with every unit rendered in high detail and with stats, however one must be aware that the armory LIES. Also, Category B and Category C (time period restricted) decks are functionally useless now, with the availiblity bonus gone and more activation points which you likely don't need. Eugen has always been fast and loose with regards to their period accuracy and scale (A Rafale with early 2000s' aams? Really?), and while the game ostensibly has units up until the mid 1990s, this is skirted around a bit. There also appears to be a somewhat prevalent French bias to the game, but its not really an issue for me.PRESENTATION:Wargame is slick in its menus and user interface, albeit a bit cluttered at times in game. The game looks and sounds much better than ALB and textures have had a noticeable improvement. Voice work is a bit iffy, with accents ranging from well done to comic. The game scales well too, with graphics that will burn out your GPU down to European Escalation era textures and rendering. In short, Wargame: Red Dragon is a fine offering from Eugen Systems and a good step forward in the series. However, naval has some severe flaws and the single player experience leaves a lot to be desired.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												Great game. You play as one of the many modern factions like America, Russia, China, Japan, Korea, British, Germany, etc and you build a 'deck' which is basically something you stuff with vehicles, infantry, naval units or air from that said faction or multiple factions. (Bonus to sticking to a single faction, and there is prebuilt decks for beginners)There is land, air and naval combat. The vehicles are realistic. There is fuel, detracking, getting your rotor shot out and your copter crashing into a tank column and blowing it up. There is ways to get fuel again, because you start with a FoB (or Forward Operations Base) which supplies your troops with ammo, fuel, repairs, etc. The jets come in off-map from an air field and do what they do, and can retreat back to the air field (if they make it) for repairs and ammo restocking.The maps are absolutely gigantic. The enviorment feels alive. You can hide your troops in the foliage, secure and use buildings, craters are left as permanent scars in maps from your wars (Just for the duration of the game, you won't go back into a map filled with craters from previous games) there are mountains, forests, plains, plateaus, rivers, lakes, oceans, you name it, it's there.It's balanced. Yes, factions may favor one type of unit over another, like (example only, not true) USA may favor Infantry and have better infantry than the French, but the French have better air support, etc. Everything has a counter. Air has anti air and other air units like fighters and attack helicopters. Bazookas and RPGs and jets and other helicopters for ground and naval and air for other naval. There is objectives, you get command vehicles to secure sectors in a map usually codenamed something like a military term such as Alpha, Bravo, Charlie, Delta. The more zones you control the more advantages you get such as new ways to bring in units to that zone instead of your FoB's location. The graphics are superb. Extremely realistic, and you can zoom in on ongoing battles and see from almost a 3rd person perspective.I definitely recommend it whole heartedly, it's a great game extremely addicting and very fun. 9.9/10

content:
Posted: January 3
												330 hours played. RTS at its best. The good:This is the most detailed, tactical RTS you've ever played. It is quite well balanced even for multiplayer, with no single team holding advantages that can't be counteracted by other teams. The community is generally pretty good. You do occasionally find people surrendering too early in multiplayer games, especially 10v10, but if you're playing 10v10 you're not taking advantage of how tactical the game can be. Micro is somewhat important but not to the same degree as in other RTS - tactics is at least as important. The wide variety of nations and coalitions to play and the variety of units within them will see you not get bored. This game rewards attention to detail, well-planed logistics, knowledge of each army and general tactics, and dedication bordering on study. The multiplayer community is still active several years after release. The bad:There is a steep learning curve to this game. It is likely more complex than other RTS you have played before. There is no build queue so preserving your units, accomplishing actual objectives and getting your logistics right will be unfamiliar to someone coming from other games. However, you can download other people's decks (army composition), watch replays online and there are extensive beginner and advanced guides out there. Buy this game. You will come to judge all other RTS by it.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												I do and I don't recommend this game.  If you have Airland battle already then really all you are paying £30 for is some more units and a few maps, basically it's an expansion pack. The trouble is so many people have migrated to red dragon that it is almost necessary to get it in order to get a game as servers seem to have got real quiet in airland battle.Red dragon needs much more work, there are various balance issues, naval combat whilst a great idea is awful and brings little or nothing to the game.  It is of course a Beta, to be fair but still not worth £30 notes, £15 perhaps.You can at last ignore people on the chat so all the racist/jew haters out there are forever silenced which is lovely.  AI is still at times frustratingly annoying, the number of times I have sent jets on a bombing run for instance that fail to drop on their target and instead carrying on flying merrily deep into enemy territory to be shot down by the 4 million pieces of AA waiting for them.  And this is depsite clicking madly to get the bloody thing to turn around.  When you are playing as Redfor(pact essentially) you get to buy 3 or 4 planes if you are lucky whilst Blufor(nato essentially) seem to have endless jets at their disposal.  The same applies to the navy, again balance issues.  That said Redfor seems to attract a more tactical player so they do seem to win equally as often.I also do not like the points limit per deck, whereas in airland battle it was 40 or 45 maybe? so you had to really thick about your deck purchases - now it sits at 60 and you can buy everything thus making deck specialties utterly pointless.  Perhaps this will change - I hope so.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												Been playing since the orignial European Escalation.  I've loved and played RTS's since the original C&C.  Times then were simpler.  However, just like everything, times have evolved.  This game is a perfect example of RTS evolution.  It's top of it's class and frong runner for RTS.  This game does have a learning curve, and a steep one at that especially when playing online.  However, once you get the hang of it and start to understand how fragile even the most powerful units are,  Its very rewarding!  So rewarding I cant put the game down, I've literally been playing it for YEARS, and even when i stop playing it for a couple months to try something new... I come running back!  The graphics and sounds are decent, the base building doesn't exsist, however unit authenticity and reward for being tactically sound are rewarded 10 fold!  Best feeling in the game is killing an expensive unit with a cheap crappy one just because I made the better decisions.  I would love to see another sequel to this explosive game.  FOCUS did a great job with this game.

content:
Posted: January 27
												'Wargame: Red Dragon' created by Eugen Systems for their game series titled 'Wargame' is a real-time strategy game where the player commands a military unit that comprises of everything from logisitic assests to naval assests. The game or more correctly the entire 'Wargame' series has the player either play as a country or coalition from NATO or the Warsaw Pact, as the game takes place during the Cold War era. Specifically for this release of the 'Wargame' series the developers have you be in East Asia, focusing mainly on the relations NATO and the Warsaw Pact through the Korean Peninsula. In the several months that I had played 'Wargame: Red Dragon', I found that the game has an amazing assortion of different units from both sides and from many countries, inside that assortion were tanks like the Centurion to the M1A2 and infantry equipment ranging the early L1A1 to the modern C7. Playing the game I also found that it has your brain working and improving overtime, this is the case because the game expecially in multiplayer where you're pitched against expierenced strategists, has you thinking critically on where you would or could be moving your assests you, where could that enemy mortar be, what would the enemy throw at me this time. Like these questions I have just said even if they sound vague to you right now is something that has you seriously thinking and probably in-game could possibly have you panic depending on the situation. This is an even more accurate statement as even though there are a few assortion of maps that people actually play, the maps themselves could even if you have a superior force could have you play yourself, everything from difficult terrain to forests, strange terrain angles and small towns, perfect for an ambush or an artillery bombardment or aerial strike.However playing the game, I have found that the naval assests no matter how amazing that sounds like, is utterly bland there is variation of naval units strangly from 9-12 different nations on the NATO side and there is also no variation of units from the 6 nations of the Warsaw PACT side. In addition to that I have also found that the ships on the PACt side are utterly overpowered, you would find it impossible to kill their ships compared to those on NATO. Nonetheless, I find that 'Wargame: Red Dragon' is a highly enjoyable game especially once you actually put yourself into it. It has it's flaws but overall a really good build and on a side note if the developers of the game actually read reviews from the community "FIX THE NAVAL AND ADD MORE NAVAL". Overall I rate the game out of 10 a 7.5.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												The best real-time strategy game I have played in my life. Takes a bit of decking around to figure out what all the stats mean and how to abuse them in a nice deck, but when you beat your friend in a 1vs1 its oh so sweet. Try reading The Art of War by Sun Tzu if you're having problems, its in audiobook form. And I suggest you get some friends to play with you, the ones that roam the public multiplayer games can be very good. Whereas if you have friends that are as noob as you are, then you can win some, then they win some as they adjust their approach, then you win some because you adjusted your approach, etc. This is very rewarding gameplay. The game is known for being as close to realism as possible, and strategically it actually is. You have to supply your troops and ships with ammo and rockets if you have a prolonged engagement (so your ships in naval battles need supply ships as a part of your deck). You also have to use infrantry in forests and buildings to spot and sneak up on the enemy (you can't shoot what you can't see, though you can shoot artillery at suspected locations). The battles are very intriguing. You can't just rush ahead, because to win you have to kill a certain number of points worth of units, but if too many of your own units die then the enemy wins because they killed enough units before you killed enough units. This gives a very real feeling, because you have to take care of your troops as you would in real life. Each unit you get killed is another set of points for the enemy. The trick is to make each exchange worth it, so you take more points than you lose in the engagement. This is tricky, but very rewarding gameplay. Pros: Everything, the only thing missing is a pure city map (unless I missed it). Just about every military asset in the world worth its paint is in the game, and there's endless replayability because no two engagements are the same. No base setup, no tedious setup of power-stations and resource harvesters, no tech-tree to worry about, no real unit cap that you'll ever approach (except in naval battles), there's a counter for everything if you only have the presence of mind to get it out when you need it (and managed to fit it into your deck).  Cons: It can be overwhelming, because there's so much to figure out. But this can be negated by playing with someone who begins playing at the same time as you, then you're on equal ground and will win every other match against each other as you figure things out.

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
												This is a good game which you should definitely get, but I would actually recommend Wargame: AirLand Battle over this game, which has several flaws. A few key points about the game:1. The maps are beautiful and are well-balanced for the most part. Maps manage to feel unique even though there are very many of them, all for different numbers of players.2. Naval combat, while it sounds cool, is underwhelming. It's basically like a downgraded version of land combat and the naval maps aren't very imaginatively designed. 3. The developers seem to have trimmed a game mode or two from the previous game which, in all honesty, isn't the end of the world since we still have the most important game modes, but when you get a new game, you expect it to take what was present in the previous game and expand upon it, not remove from it.4. The campaigns are pretty mediocre and are gimmicky. The AI is extremely stupid even on the hardest difficulty, and you can bait it easily. To counteract this, the AI gets a handicap in that it gets extra units at the start of the game, which isn't that big of a deal. The AI's basic strategy is to send waves of vehicles at you in hopes that you will just give up. The only thing that interrupts this is the constant artillery bombardments against your command units which, by all accounts, should be hidden to the enemy. The campaigns themselves are interesting and based in history, but they get old because, when it comes down to it, there is generally either one solid strategy or two solid strategies which allow you to complete the campaign successfully, and there isn't any room for strategic creativity.Multiplayer is super fun.Score: 83/100: If there were as many people playing ALB as there are people playing this, I would just play ALB, but this game is still worth your time.

number of helpful: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												This is not a review of the single player campaign but of the online multiplayer.After play 200 hours of this game I feel as though I have earned the right to write a review. The first thing to say is this is a  spectacular game. The game has so many good points I cannot list them all but here are some.Firstly the number of units is incredible. There are over 1,450 units spanning 17 nations. This gives a huge variety in game play and no two games are ever the same. The second point is the maps. These are huge, covering vast areas of terrain, oceans and rivers. This allows players to use the terrain to their advantage (for example sneaking through forests with tanks or going over mountians with infantry). Thirdly all DLC (at time of writing) is free. This goes back all the way to European Escalation where DLC was also free. Another point about this game is that although the devs had said it needs a 2.5 GHz processor it doesn't. My computer is very low end and can still run this at 15-30 FPS.A word of warning though! This game it not a layed back RTS where you don't have to do much accept order where units go. There is a lot to micro manage and if you don't micro manage then you stand not hope in winning. There is also a steep learning curve and from my understanding no tutorial though i'm sure YouTube will have the answers.All in all this is a great RTS and in my opinion the best out on the market at the moment and certianly the best in the series so far. Don't be put off by the price in my opinion to get your monies worth you should play at least the same number of hours as pounds you paid and its certainly done that!10/10

number of helpful: 14 of 22 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2016
												TL;DR: It could be the best real-time strategy game ever released, but it is just game which has so much lost potential. So, what's the story. When you starting this game for the first time your reaction is "Wow! A lot of units! A lot of paremeters! A lot of different armies!" Yeah, but... It is not super-realistic or thought-out game as it seems to be at the first glance. This game trying to be realistic sometimes, here is no tanks shooting each other on 30 meters like in CoH or whatever, but a lot of things are sacrificed to "balance" and it doesn't make game balance better. If you think that you can get multiple different experiences playing different types of armies, you are wrong. There is a few optimal choices while most of armies unable to achieve anything but hurt you. Eugen made the basic parts of the game long time ago. And they did really good job! But they stopped driving this game to make it better. Currently, only one guy is continuing to work on this game and oh man... that would be better if they stopped touching this game. That guy doesn't even play his game or play it very occasionally on very low level. It seems like once a quarter he's drinking something, opens excel file and doing balance changes randomly. Today german regular infantry dominate over against anything, tomorrow they are not even usable. Today Eastern Block and Commonwealth are the worst, tomorrow they are the best. Why? Because f*** you, players, that's why. Pros- Unique gameplay;- Decent replayability;- Decent number of strategies and tactics (but it's gotten repetitive and formularic at this point);- Matchmaking and rating system for 1v1.Cons- Poor support;- Poor balance (in multiple acpests, not just between Red and Blue forces);- A lot of mechanics that should be in the game are missing;- Lack of content (like online campaign, different game modes, different theatres, etc);- No map-generator or map-editor and existing maps are mediocre;- No matchmaking for team games + smallish community size = lobby sim;- Huge amount of minor faults (some of them are not very "minor").So, playing this game is a quite specific experience. It is fun to play through the first time and explore the game, but once you have gotten experienced enough there is nothing to catch up to here. It is too unfinished to play it competitively and too complicated and noob unfriendly to play it casually. I wouldn't recommend to waste your time on it.
