content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												Pretty fun game if you have an interest in larger scale military strategy, with a combined arms approach rather than just spamming your high cost tank. Alot of units have their utility, so cheaper units are not always directly inferior and have their use - aswell as cheaper units will give you more numbers. If you have for example a 180 cost tank, you will only get 1 or 2, where as a 90 point tank will give you maybe 8 or 7, allowing you to capitalize on numbers at a cost of a more powerful unit.Not too easy to learn, so it's good to have a friend who is good at the game to teach you the ins and outs.Alot of people complain about balance and there is a balance issue in certain places with the game. Depending on who you are, this is either a good or bad thing:  You may like a game balanced away from realism to make it slightly more 'fair', or you may prefer that the game lets both sides/individual nations have their strong and weak points. Personally, I prefer to play against an enemy and in the lobby see what nation they are playing as, to know what their strong points and weak points are in terms of units, to help devise a plan to counteract that. I prefer to play a game where I have to think to nullify the enemies advantage, than have everything completely balanced.At the end of the day, superior tactics will win games over just good units - Adapt and overcome. This sort of thing comes apparent when a team of 1980s North Korea beats a cocky well rounded BLU team. I've seen it happen, and no, it really isn't easy, but if you can outplan your enemy, you'll have positive kill/loss ratios in any match.If at the end of the day you really just can't get a grip on the game but are willing to learn, theres an entire 200 page 'red dragon for dummies' guide that can teach you everything you need to know, although you really just need to in most cases think realistically about things.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2016
												I think if anyone were to ask me what was the best RTS of all time, this game wouldn't come up.Not because this isn't the best RTS of all time, but because I know despite how amazing and incredible it is. How it's such a ridiculous technical marvel with the most incredible depth in an RTS to date.It's because just like Dwarf Fortress, I know that if I send regular joes into this with that impression, they'll just come out loathing it due to the sheer incredulous difficulty that comes with it. It makes TA: Spring or Forged Alliance look like Baby's First RTS. It makes Starcraft 2 look like a kid's show. It's like someone took the time to kill from modern FPSs and threw them into a super hardcore RTS so your hour long plans can get wiped out in five seconds. It's actually somewhere along the lines of Men of War, but with 10x the unit diversity.This game is only just slightly under games like Dwarf Fortress and Aurora in terms of difficulty to learn. But just like them, if you bother to actually learn all its intricacies... you will be rewarded with something truly magnificent.You'll still get your♥♥♥♥♥kicked though. All the time. Also the subreddit and forums are full of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and nothing helpful plus all the guides are outdated so don't expect anyone to hold your hand.---------By the by, you don't actually need any of the nation DLC. Maybe get them if you like the countries but other than that they're not required to be competitive at the game. I have 118 hours in Red Dragon and I don't even have a single one of the DLCs. Never felt like I needed them, though they are fun and extensive.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												This game will challenge anyone who enjoys RTS. It takes a little while at first to understand how to play as the tutorials are not helpful, but after watching several YouTube videos I figured the basics out. With regards to the Navy action, it is fun just buying a medium sized ship or two and sailing around shooting down air craft, blowing up unsuspecting land units, or sinking other ships.The land battles are very complicated, it is not easy taking over the map by just selecting a whole bunch of high end units and sending them to an area, you must move your units in a layered fashion very slowly. Sending in a tank or helicopter rush is just a waste of good units. You need infantry and artillery as well as plenty of support vehicles, otherwise your tanks and helicopters are useless. With regards to the air units, wow... not at all easy to use as they get shot down in seconds if you are not extremely careful, and those air planes are very expensive. Being Canadian, I can't help but play Canada. I like the proto types they included for Canada, but still, it is a big challenge to win (my win loss ratio is horrible) but that has not stopped me! Go Canada Go!

content:
Posted: March 25
												This game took a while for me not to suck at it. Key lesson: If you don't utilise the advantages of each unit, they will die quickly and you will lose. In a nutshell: This is a real time tactical game with over HUNDREDS of real world units to choose from. It is the perfect sandbox to employ modern millitary doctrine with said units to kill the enemy. The way you would build a British Army is different to how you would build a USSR army. How you use soviet infantry is differnt to how you would use US marines. Soviet helicopters are different to the US helicopters. The key to this game is building a deck that is optimal for your tactics, and understanding your units pros/cons. If you are unsure the nature of this game - watch some pro replays and see how the macro/micro mechanics of this RTS works. It is quite unique. TO ease into it I recommend playing some solo skirmishes before playing some 4v4 online battles.One of the most satisfying games to learn to play, with a competative multiplayer community. As an RTS fan, this is one of the deepest games out there that has captured my attention. If you are looking to get into some deep strategy with a steep learning curve: Red dragon will reward you.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												Pros : This game is a very advanced strategy game set in and around the fall of the Soviet Union. Unlike other modern strategy games you aren't just looking at a black and blue map seeing missiles being dashed across the board and that's the most combat that the game ever witnesses. Wargame : Red Dragon allows you to enter the battlefield and control your units down to a single soldier. In the Air, on land and wait for it... sea. There are many powerful western and eastern countries to play that you might not expect in a video games when it's usually just US/UK against USSR. Countries like Canada and Denmark or even North and South Korea. This game offers so much with its many maps for multiplayer or singleplayer battles. Very fun Strategy gameCons : Personally. I found it very difficult to learn how to play. It's not like minesweeper where you just mess around and figure out the basics in five minutes. It takes time and even now there are still new controls and options I find out about.Other than the learning curve the only other issue I had with the game is in a multiplayer game if you, your teammate or your opponent are having bad internet connection and constantly hopping in and out of connection it pauses the game until you reconnect as opposed to having you fight against a blind General. As fair as this is to the other team it does make it hard to play a match when someone is disconnecting literally every 10 seconds. As well, after you disconnect you are given 30 seconds to reconnect and if you don't you are kicked from the game and your forces are then given to one of your allies which this could really go into the pros stage because it doesn't just make a game go from bad to great  right away if you're being destroyed by the guy with bad internet. It keeps it fair.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2016
												DO NOT BUY THIS GAME FOR SINGLE PLAYER, the AI difficulty is ridiculous.  Instead of each difficulty changing the way the AI chooses its tactical decisions, it gives the AI MASSIVE discounts on its units, effectively turning any match into a 1 unit type spam fest.  Every time I try to play, no matter what tactics I use, whether it be a tank blitzkrieg or a guerilla war, the results are always the same: the sky is blackened by the sight of dozens of attack choppers, or an entire wall of tanks.  The AI makes very little tactical plays and relies on simply zerging you down by out-pacing you with units to an ungodly level.  I've played the multiplayer and this doesn't seem to be an issue and focuses on strategy, rather than the bologna that is its single-player.

												Good game, with a lot of room for tactical play, and quite a steep learning curve. Had some problems with the graphics though, so I had to set stuff on DirectX9 and low settings.PROS:- Definitely a must-have for armchair generals. Sound tactics will get you far, weak points will be exploited, so you have to have a balanced army in the field.- Deck system is a very important element in the game. It's also fun to mess with.- Multiplayer battles with multiple players vs. multiple players could make for interesting battles.- Lots of units to choose from, although some countries have more variation (and sometimes seemingly useless units).CONS:- Problems with graphics forced me to play on medium settings.- Not a big con, but the game lacks good tutorials. To really learn the game you should just play a lot and look up youtube videos of experienced players.8/10 zones occupied

number of helpful: 11 of 17 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												Wargame Red Dragon is simply one of the best Real Time Stratigy games I have ever played. However I can tell you that it is not for all RTS players. If you like building  your massive inpenrtable bace, defened by automated turrets. Sorry but there isn't any bace building in this game. If you like having one or two sets of units wipe entire forces ten or twelve times as numerous. Again that isn't possable, because just like in real life one can only carry so much ammo and once it is out you have to go get more. Also with tanks, trucks, helicopters and transports having limited range and use up their fuel supplies that is also something you have to keep an eye on. However even if you are put off by all of that added "realisem" (remember it's a game, not a simulation so somethings aren't all that true to real life like the scale of maps and ranges of weapons for example) I would recomend you try it. If you are good at micormangement or macromanagement then this game will have a place for you. The single player campains are well scripted and interesting to play, although I would say that the AI could use some work when it comes to attacking/defending with singular type forces. As for multiplayer some people are amazingly good, however it doesn't take too long to become good enough to enjoy the game while being able to help your team. But as with every multiplayer game if you end up on a team (should you want to play on a team as you can do 1v1 if you desire) who has rocks for brains where as you are playing against some fivestar armchair geneails don't worry if you cannot carry the entire match. Also many of the very good players have reliced theory guides or have posted youtube videos showcasing what they do to win matches and generaily if you watch the replay of a game you lost or won you can usualy come up with the reasons why that happened. Which is one of the best features of this game in my mind, if you loose horably because of a break through attack on one flank that you weren't watching close enough or the player in that sector was unable to defete it you can see why they were able to beat you If you are sold now, please note that the game curently has some flaws, for example some nations do not have any upgraded infentry, where as most of the others have a basic pre 1980 form of infentry than a upgraded infentry from 1985 or 1990 with better eqipment and access to more advanced transports. However it has been confermed by the developers that some of the first DLC (which would suprise me if it cost you anything) releases will address this problem.That last paragraph has been mostly delt with, with the release of The Milionth Mile most (but not all) of the nations have had an infentry upgrade option added. Also added were land based anti ship missile systems.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												I should have written this Wargame Red Dragon review a long time ago. Better late than never I guess. I'll compensate with kind of a mega review.Wargame Red Dragon is definitely one of my top 3 real time strategy games of all time. (The other two being Supreme Commander and Starcraft II.) It's the third game in the series and it takes the franchise to a new level with the implementation of naval warfare, several new nations, graphical polish and rebalancing of old mechanics like artillery power. I don't think any RTS game offers the equivalent experience as Wargame and I believe every self-respecting RTS gamer should play Wargame.Wargame series is so deep that you could sink Mount Everest into it. And it's not just the sheer amount of units and all the simulation, but the tactical opportunities.Perhaps you should shoot smoke to cover your advance? Or would you like to do an amphibious landing behind enemy lines and cut their reinforcement route? How about sending an elite recon squad behind enemy lines to observe what kind of troops enemy is bringing in? They can also direct artillery fire on enemy supply depot and artillery battery. (Just watch out for counter-artillery) Perhaps you could open the game with an airborne assault to an important crossroads town?  Can't stop enemy advance? Try napalming the important bridges to block them and buy time.It's amazing what kind of devious evil plans human mind can come up with. I personally really enjoy this aspect of the game. When tanks get boring you can spice things up with some crazy special forces action.Realism is a big word in Wargame. Every one of the 1 500 different units have their individual statistics for weapons (type, ammunition, armor penetration, explosive power, fire rate, range, accuracy, stabilizer, targeting system...) armor (front, side, rear, top) and all sort of miscellaneous stuff like fuel, speed, size, stealth, countermeasures, operational range etc. They are all significant when you decide what units you call to battlefield.However, Wargame is no Dwarf Fortress. Even my 57-year-old dad has managed to master the game. I think it's common sense you shouldn't move your tanks through a town in which you have spotted enemy special forces moving in. Most of us also have brains to understand that an AT missile can one shot even the heaviest tank if you expose its side or rear armor, or that enemy AA will most likely shoot down your old slow bomber which doesn't have any countermeasures, or that napalm strike will paint pant's of your infantrymen brown, or that your artillery needs ammunition or that 20 is more than 10.Sure, you don't know all the tricks when you start your first match but you'll get there. There are great single player campaigns (both in Red Dragon and the previous titles) and there is also a chat window in the main menu full of people who can answer your questions and give tips. (At least when it's not full of Russians mocking Americans and Americans mocking Russians and Europeans mocking everyone.)Single player offers a lot of practice opportunities. You can either play skirmish games and adjust the difficulty the way you want or once you think you are ready you can try single player campaigns. I found the campaigns challenging (=fun) even for a Wargame veteran, not to mention the amount of interesting tactical and strategic opportunities.Addition of naval units was a big thing of Red Dragon so I guess I should say something of it. The naval units are often called unbalanced by the players and I guess they are slightly. It's also kind of unfortunate that the ships are only from few nations. I however wouldn't call it a total failure. Naval warfare is still fun and it makes the game more interesting in coastal maps as if you lose your naval presence you are in risk of amphibious landings in your rare. Ships' cannons are really powerful against ground units IF you can spot them, which the ships usually can't. On the other hand if ships move too close to shore pretty much any kind of tank platoons can make serious damage.The deck system from Wargame Airland Battle is also here and better than ever. For those who are unfamiliar with the deck system, a deck is basically a pre-defined selection of units you choose for a battle. Decks are really fun to make because you can (and you should) get bonuses by adding restrictions and specializations. For example I really like my South Korean Marine deck, Canadian motorized deck or pre-1980s REDFOR tank decks.The system has been rebalanced so all the deck types have become feasible. Especially airborne decks are really cool. Besides the five new countries there are coalitions which consist of several nations. The bonuses for coalitions are smaller but at least they get to keep their prototype units. My Commonwealth mechanized deck and South Korean-Japanese motorized deck just rock.The maps in Wargame Red Dragon are also really cool with mountains, towns, deserts, forests, coastal areas, rivers and all of those potentially in a same map! This opens a ton of possibilities and makes almost any kind of deck playable in every map. We sure have come a long way from Wargame European Escalation's never-ending plains with some occasional woods.As I said in my Wargame Airland Battle review, what makes Wargame really cool is the variety of everything that keeps the game fresh. Every player makes his own decks and chooses his own tactics. That's why every match is at least slightly different and you can never know what kind of BS enemy has in store for you.The fun factor will also get multiplied by 10 if you have a friend in your team in a voice chat to coordinate with. That's where the possibilities of teamwork rocket through the roof.Wargame Red Dragon is the ultimate peak of the evolution of Wargame franchise. It's probably the best think that has happened to RTS games for a few years and I love it just as much as I love the smell of napalm in mornings.TL;DR: Play it. Play it. Play it.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
												First, if you enjoy RTS games, this is one you will definitely enjoy whether you like campaigns or multiplayer.The first most important things in regard to first playing is that there is a learning curve, and its pretty steep. For many, few games offer the dynamics or air and land comat with the lethality and speed that WG does, and remains blanced and fair. That boils down towards, if you want a game that is slower paced, it may not be for you,Having over 400 hours, i can say i am well acquainted with the pors and cons of the games design, and firstly i'd want to ring up the campaigns. There is a few scnearies with the last two being expansive and very long. Theyre great and ultimately they turn out the way you craft your forces to tackle the problem. Every time you play it, it ill turn out somewhat differantly which makes the games replayability remarkable. The downside is that the game compensates the poor intelligence of the AI with spam, and that spam is typically utilizing superior units, and those you can match are hard to replace when lost. it's incredibly easy to lose and unfortunately i've had to reload previous saves in order to actually win. The end result overall is still a great experience well worth your money alone.Second is the multiplayer. The multiplayer is similar to the campaign with its owns ups and downs. The first most obvious and great thing is your ability to hand craft your pre-set battle group or "deck". It allows you to play however you choose. It again requires a degree of understanding the game. When that is reached though, the creative and dynamic limits are only limited by you. This paired with other players doing the same leads to games where the outcomes are wildly varied. This is where the game really is worth your money. It is the reason why i can comeback time and again over games like Fallout 4 and other titles that are immedialtely boring after only a single playthrough.There are huge negatives which i Eugen needs to address though. The first is lobby stacking. The greatest problem that turns me away is the ability for experienced players to simply stack into one side of the team and wait for the lobby to fill up essentially gauranteeing a win. This is literally game breaking, and anyone new to the game will immediately realize after a dozen loses that the game is against them. It is a terrible and unfair system and isnt fun. If this wasnt an issue, the game would easily be a 9 out of 10,Everything altogether though, this game is brilliantly designed and encourages varied strategies and dynamic mindsets to counter and succeed against real people or computer AI's. Aside from its quirks, its well worth your money.

content:
Posted: January 29
												Wargame Red Dragon, a game that can make RTS ♥♥♥♥ to♥♥♥♥♥ i can't think of any RTS game that uses the same theme as the wargame series (The Cold War), most RTS tends to take Medieval theme, the Civil War theme, WW2 theme & even Futuristic themeThe game also tries it's best into balancing units and depicting the real life counterpart's stats, and not many RTS games has this, even the so called "Realistic" ones (Men Of war series), unfortunately it still uses an HP system for the units, but that's only natural considering that making realistic damage models & system would mean that the game needs more higher specs to play, which is not really that great since i am on a Low-end Macbook Pros :+ A ♥♥♥♥ ton of playable nations+ A ♥♥♥♥ ton of deployable units+ Different nations varies in tactics and special units and they're still taken from real life+ A large variety of multiplayer maps+ Multiplayer matches are hosted everyday by players and dedicated servers alike+ Affordable Price (The summer sale Discount makes it really cheap)+ Outstanding unit control and user interface + Active developer that adds more playable nations (even if that you'll have to pay extra for it, the developer knows what   a DLC should be, unlike other game developers *cough* EA *cough*)Cons :- No Tutorial, recommended that you play the first 2 game series (European Escalation & Airland battle)- Unforgiving AI for new players- Only 5 campaigns (repetitive after a while)- No mods & no community map creator (yet)- No matchmaking system (recommend you play w/ a friend first before you plunge into a random match- Bland after battle screen (shows only stats of the game, tbh i would prefer a national anthem to play after a match w/   the current nation you're playing)yeah that's basically it, if you like to wreak people w/ the Soviet deck or just want to create a fictional battle between 2 coalition or nation then this game is definitely for you.

												I'm not generally a big RTS player, but this game has such depth (and a steep learning curve) that it has sucked me in. Great fun to plan out and build decks around a strategy or style of play you have in mind. I much prefer this style of game, in which you call in and deploy units, to the type of RTS games where you have to build and manage a base. If you're on the fence about it, there's no question that you should pick it up next time it goes on a $10 sale-- that is an absolute steal. I'm also glad I picked up the DLC nations as they are all fun to play and tinker with.

												To those who may not know me, I was a long time community figure for this game and have the good fortune to speak to the devs directly on many occasions. Simply put, this is RTS series has some of the greatest depth that I have seen in a very long time. It is fairly easy to get into and will take effort to master, but it very rewarding once you do so. Managing multiple actions, many weapon types and all kinds of tactical situations is very fun. It is also a game that rewards forethought, correct force composition and having a plan. Red Dragonj is very engaging on both a tactical and strategic level, some of the best fun I have had in the past few years has been playing this series while on VOIP with friends, fighting challenging battles.Should you need further convincing, I’ve clocked in 1038 hours into this game so far according to Steam and that number is likely to keep growing. No other game in my collection comes close to matching this.Give this game a go!

Posted: July 29, 2014
												It is a Real time strategy game, just so we are clear.At first, I believed that I made a mistake and that this game was going to be awful. I. Was. Wrong. This game is off my charts on the epic factor, I mean, just check out my screenshots. For a cold war based game, everything was accurate for the time period and has many different armies and alliances to choose from. The "Deck builder" army creation is easily mastered and allows for thousands of different combinations. The combat is breathtaking, even though the AI gets an advantage on more occasions than one, it is one of the best combat simulations I have experienced. The different camera POV system allows for both tactical and cinematic views giving the player the feel of being a general and a soldier in the field.If you're a serious RTS guy or gal who loves to cause utter annhilation to your enemies with over a thousand different ways of doing it all while in a beautiful enviroment, then look no further, you found your game.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												This. Is. A. Fantastic. Game.HOW I GOT STARTED WITH WARGAME RED DRAGONI am a die-hard Supreme Commander fanboy, and I was skeptical of this game. I had tried European Escalation and it really wasn't my jam, however my friend bought this for me (Thanks, Jack) and I decided I should give the series a second chance.GAMEPLAYThe gameplay mechanics are, well, great. If you play a great deal of RTS's within a small area of time like me, then controls can get confusing, but that's just boling down to if left click or right click assigns orders. Through my time playing this, I've found that unit placement is far more important than numbers. Having one Stinger standing in the treeline of a forest is far more useful than two stingers in the open. Unit placement is also key, because the enemy gets points for destroying your stuff on the most common gamemode. One problem I have always had is anti-ship missiles versus ships, as the missiles would get destroyed and then my plane would get shot down. I am not sure if the range of the AA on most ships is intentional, but I feel like I should get that out there. There is also a counter to everything, and make sure you cover every type of potential attack in your deck, which I will talk about next.DECKSIf you are a fan of Wargame long before Red Dragon came out, you can skip this section entirely as I want to share how decks work and how a deck with a blend of cheap/expensive units (versus all cheap / all expensive). Decks are a lot like unit designators. You design your custom deck (Or use a prebuilt one), and you have two options to start with. BLUFOR, or OPFOR. Within those choices, you have the option (But you don't have to) to pick a country within those two factions. Within THOSE choices, you can ( But you don't have to) specialize within that unit, which will restrict the use of some units, but unlock others and give you extra unlocking points towards infantry/armor/air/etc. Finally, you can restrict yourself to a time period to give you more activiation points, but you lose the avaliability of some units. I have never had to use this type of deck. Covering the blend of Cheap/Expensive units, if you have an army of crummy, cheap units, then your army will get destroyed quickly by the enemies (Presumably) superior force. If you have too many expensive units, then you will not be able to get enough units out to cover all your sides, and you will be flanked.MULTIPLAYERThe multiplayer is fantastic. But I write that with a conditional tone. The multiplayer is some of the best you'll ever experience if you have teammates that know what they are doing and support each other. However this is only 40% of your random games. I don't have much else to say about multiplayer, except it is certainly a challenge no matter what sector you're holding down.OVERVIEWThe whole bloody review was an overview. Great game.9/10.I realize that my review was a little pieced together and guide-ish, but read some other reviews and keep mine in mind and you'll see if you'll like this game or not.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												I recommend this game, but there are lot of disclaimers to note:1. There is a STEEP learning curve to the game, and there isn't a good tutorial in-game.2. While there are a few good guys who don't mind helping out a noob, the vast majority of the community will view you as prey to get an easy win. Proof? Create a multiplayer game, title it noobs only, the first 3 people will be level 15+, and won't even apologize that they tried to take advantage of you being a beginner for an easy win. 3. Lots of battles are won or lost within the first 5 mins. These are 20 minute battles, mind, so there's a good chance that you will be on cruise control for 15 minutes of it.4. Artillery units are overpowered as of now, and matches could boil down to people just shelling the crap out of each other for 10 mins.Now why do I recommend the game?1. There's no other game like it. It is like Total War on steroids, every unit has a counter-unit...It is the very basis of strategic thinking.2. Once you get over the big hump of learning the game, it is quite a lot of fun...unless you match up with one of the vast number of people who are diehard followers of the game and know every key-binding and inch of the map in the back of their head.3. There is a HUGE amount of units to select, granted some may be the exact same (but made available for different countries) but in general, you can browse through each unit with a very detailed model to boot for a while.4. Like I mentioned, there are hidden gems in the community, and some of them have written up some very comprehensive guides for the game. Whether you want to read through a 200 and 180 page guide for a game is a whole different question altogether though.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4
												I only discovered the Wargame franchise this week due to the sale.  I can't believe this one slipped under my radar.  I'd say of all the RTS games I've played over the last few decades, the one this is closest to is World in Conflict.  However, there are way more units, and the high level campaign is really well done.  It's like a game of chess, even more so than in any Total War game I've played, since you don't have an economy / research you can lean on to stack the odds in your favor.  It's all about how you set up the board.  You can recruit new units, but there are only one of each type in the end that can be used on the map.  The name "Wargame" isn't just a cool sounding title; it's very, very apt.  The simplified rock, paper, scissors approach of traditional RTS (i.e. calvary beat archers who beat infantry who beat calvary) is greatly enhanced by the variety of real-world units.  You'd need a lost more nouns than rock, paper and scissors to make that metaphor apply here.  This game is very well done.A couple very minor gripes, mostly with lack of documentation on gameplay mechanics:1) the manual doesn't explain a whole lot.  I can't figure out of there's a way to issue complex movement commands (waypoints) like you can in every other RTS game.  Maybe shift right click works, but there's no clear indicator.2) What does R&R do?  Does that give you more command units?  I think there was a pop up somewhere that migth have told me, but I can't find that online, and it's not in the manual.3) How precisely does Line of Sight Work?  How far from the edge of the woods does you scout need to be?  Do you need to zoom into the scout to see what it sees?  Does it matter which direction it faces?  I frequently find my scout units fail to find targets I would think they should see.

												Another fantastic Wargame to add to my collection. Naval battles are especially exciting as they are new and fun, but they really lack units. There are very few large ships to choose from and they seem to neglect many ships that were being used in the 1980's-90's; namely the Ticonderoga class and the Arleigh-Burke class in the US. That being said it is still extremely exciting to sneek some smaller patrol boats up rivers and take out enemy cammand vehicles and tanks. The land units are absolutely amazing. There is a huge range of vehicles, tanks, and infantry. They have put more importance on having specific infantry units than ever before. There are still some of those same annoyences with tanks sitting in the middle of a field staring at clearly seen enemy and not shooting or moving. Overall this game is great, and is a good step from the previous two titles.9/10

content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												Wargame:Red Dragon is a fantastic RTS game that is very difficult to master but is very fun to play. Wargame has always been a series that focuses on realism and fantastic graphics. However this game is very complicated and for newcomers may be quite daunting. Sandygunfox's guide  Here  is a fantastic guide that is free and gives some great tips for newcomers to the series.Things I like:-Fantastic range of units and factions to play.-Graphics are fantastic and very detailed.-Maps are very well designed and thought-out.-3 big DLC packs that were released for free.-Gameplay is very slick and the larger maps with 20players run very smooth.-Massive online maps and battles.Things I don't like:-Sometimes the AI is a tad dumb-Not enough maps possibly.-No more dlc have been announced and I feel that possibly more maps would be good.-Game can sometimes do some strange things, like planes flying through mountains.-Online can be a bit pub-stompy with higher level players dominating lower level ones. While not really a problem as you can view their wins etc and just make custom games with people around your level.Overall I think this is a fantastic game, I've put alot of hours into this and was also a beta player. During this time the game has evoled greatly. The free DLC was a great bonus but these three were the only ones planned and they plan to work on other titles. Despite this Red Dragon is a great RTS title with superb graphics/gameplay that may appear daunting at first, but is very rich and diverse once you get to grips with its style of play.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												This is quite possibly my favorite game of all-time. The game is an RTS in the same sense as the latest C&C4 (No real Base-building) Except it doesn't arbitrarily limit the number of units you can have. Maps are gigantic, battles are huge, and there are some aspects of it that everyone just loves. That being said, there are a few limitations that might drive some away. I'll address them below.Good:-Battles are gigantic-Amazing variety of Units-Free DLC-Large Map Replayability-Wide variety of countries available-Land, Air, and Sea combat-Immense experimentation possible-Challenging Campaigns-Multiplayer battles (TO THE MAX)Bad:-Sea is kind of half-baked and does not work realistically-Otomatic was never sold to Denmark (Hehe)-NO GOOD TUTORIAL!!!!    I know a lot of people complain about this one, but to be honest there's really nothing there! The in-game tutorial explains what each value means, but it never really explains how to play the game well. Many people just come in without any knowledge whatsoever and pick units arbitrarily. It requires some pretty intensive effort from experienced players (Like myself) to actually help these new guys and give them a hand. There are plenty of resources available for them on steam, but it's not always obvious where to find these.-Planes are unrealistic as well-SPAAG ground range is arbitrarily set at 1050m (Except for otomatic which is 2100, down from 2275)-Tank Range maxxes out at 2275M (for no real reason)-Ships don't fire KE/AP Rounds!!! (like they do IRL!)Overall, I absolutely adore this game. The dings I gave it above are things most regular players won't care about or really notice. If you like RTS, you couldn't go wrong with purchasing this game and having a blast. Please read the tutorials after you do, and check out a guide or two! If you're still confused, ask someone like me who knows how to play the game well for advice! We're happy to train you new guys!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
Short review.This game series has turned out to be one of my favorite RTS games as it depicts "almost realistic" modern warfare with things sacrificed for the sake of gameplay. But, never the less. It's complex gameplay makes up for a hard learning curve, so at the start of your playing of wargames, you will get obliterated by other players in online matches. Deck system and no traditional basebuilding, Every unit has their strenghts & weaknesses and everything has a counter. These reasons help this game to stand out from the rest. To be really good at this game, you just have to learn constantly about the mistakes you make in your past games, so you know what not to do the next time you wind up in a match again.Naval combat was advertised for this game a lot, but it winded up to be a big disappointment. It's all about who has more  anti-ship missiles or CIWS. But where this game shines is the land combat. No one really plays naval on multiplayer for that exact reason.You really don't want to play in the 10vs10 servers, because it is usually, in my experience very inconsistent. I had a thing going on for 10vs10 games, but it just winded up too many loses for my profile, often due to other players leaving too soon or after deploying their sovre without any escort to the sea and ragequitting when it gets killed by anti-ship missiles. So you really just get sick of it. So stick to the usual matches, 3vs3 etc.But, it's positive sides really outweight the negatives. So I really really recommend this game to any RTS fans out there, it's an very solid RTS game optimized for PC gaming.

												Strategy games are fun as ♥♥♥♥.This game is no exception.There are countless units to play around with, a very interesting campaign system and many cool challenges you can do with or without your friends.Some of my challenges are:Tiananmen Square Protests - Make a china deck for you and your teammates but make an infantry-only deck for the bots, max out their team size and make sure their transports are unnarmed. You'll have 10-15 minutes of preparation per game before swarms of protesters attack your tanks. It's a lot harder than it seems.Black Lives Matter / Ferguson - Basically Tiananmen Square but with american decks.Zombie mode - Make a deck for yourself without any air vehicles (maybe korean B-5's for good measure), but with the enemy deck, make it completely out of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ cold war era tanks and jeeps. It may seem unfair but those ♥♥♥♥ers move so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ fast and they overwhelm you even faster.Star Wars - (use the sandbox mod) Basically make a naval deck with all capital ships (Luda, Sovremenny, Congo and Oliver Hazard Perry). The enemy's deck must be ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ethiopian fishing vessels and small boats alike. Basically with all of the tracers flying around it'll look like a Star Wars battle and with the sandbox mod the AI will spend ALL of their OVER A MILLION POINTS on instantly unleashing a holocaust of REFUGEE SHIPS at you. (Prone to crashing).-But yeah, it's a really fun game. One downside is that servers are not so populated and the game has a very steep learning curve.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												Overview:This isn't your typical Command & Conquer or Starcraft style RTS, this is a somewhat complex combined arms simulation with a little bit of a learning curve. It helps to have some background or at least a basic understanding of modern military strategy, technology and terminology but with a little bit of research that can be achieved. As long as the player has an understanding of what the units are, what their purpose is and what their strengths and weaknesses within that purpose they should be able to play the game efficiently. The player's army consists of a "deck" of "cards" which are purchased with "activation points". In each deck their are nine unit types, each with their own row of slots. There are logistics, infantry, support, tank, recon, vehicle, helicopter, plane, and naval units. Each unit type gets a limited number of card slots based on the type of deck. For instance, an armored deck would have more tank slots and less infantry slots. Each card represents a unit and costs a set amount of activation points, starting at one point and gradually increasing up to five points as the player purchases more units within an individual unit type. The player is normally given 60 activation points to spend on each deck. When a player enters a game each card costs a certain amount of points to place on the map. the more powerful the unit is, the more points it costs. Points are earned over time and the income increases when a player or their team takes a point and places a command vehicle in them. The Review:I have been playing Wargame for a little under a year, starting with Airland Battle. As a Marine Corps veteran I immediately noticed that the developers did their homework and created a very accurate representation of most of the American vehicles and infantry units without sacrificing balance. Within a week of playing I was hooked and the addiction hasn't worn off since. For the most part Red Dragon was a big upgrade from Airland Battle. The maps are more detailed and look more natural, the units are more balanced and the gameplay became smoother without taking away from the original Wargame experience. I was very dissappointed with the naval units, they seem like they were thrown in at the last moment and they don't fit in the game very well. Every game I've played against someone who had a large naval presence I've won. I think it would have worked better if they removed the frigates and destroyers, leaving just the river boats and other small ships. The only other negative aspect of the game is the AI "Fast Move" pathfinding, it would be nice if the player was able to select specific roads for a vehicle to travel down instead of selecting a location and having the AI take the fastest road. There have been too many instances where I've called in a unit, forgotten about them in the heat of a firefight and they've blindly driven into an enemy line. Other than that the game is great, there is a massive amount of units to select from allowing for a huge amount of variety. Each unit has strengths and weaknesses and I have yet to find any overpowered units or exploits, the game is very skill based and well thought out. It isn't too often you find games of this quality. I would reccommend this to anyone willing to put in the little bit of time it takes to get past the learning curve. Happy hunting!

To put it simple, you can buy it in FULL PRICE and wish you had paid more - the sheer hallucination that they're taking the premium you paid to develop the next game or dlc will keep you optimistic for EVERYTHING ELSE IN LIFE.- It comes with a pack of 3 games: Multiplayer, Warchat, and Reading the Steam Reviews (which I am adding to).- Multiplayer = everything you dreamt or imagined about the Arms Race that should happen but didn't happen - EVERYTHING, I mean it, execpt the part about the nukes.- Warchat, best chat room ever, takes you back to the Cold War when all kinds of ideologists and extremists - Leftists, Rightists, Communists, Jihadists, Imperialists, Fascists, Nationalists, Racists, Sexists (WTF?)... discuss how they wipe one another out IN REAL LIFE.- Play single-player and AI-skirmishes as "tower-defense" and achieve a kill/death ratio > 100:1.- Play single-player as a tutorial before playing multi-player and witness the ratio getting reversed...for a long time.- Beginners plz don't start by choosing a "support deck"......or your house will get torn down by an elephant.- Rock cissor paper/ Heli Tank AA/ Grenade luncher rules all infantry.- Patience. Grow up and learn not to quit when having a hard time. When you do, you leave all the♥♥♥♥♥♥you summoned to ONE OF your poor teammates on the OTHER SIDE OF THE MAP. Unable to manage, he quits, leaving all the♥♥♥♥♥♥to the next guy......GG in 5 min.Last but not least, I'll tell you a joke: Act of Aggression.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												I recommend this game because there isn't any compition to it.There is no other RTS which let's you play with this many units.Nor is there any RTS that deals with the cold war like this. If you play this game you will probably end up knowing a lot about military hardware from the cold war that you didn't know. That being said. There are some warnings to this game. Despite it being very unique, and still being worked on. I should point out a few things:1. Navy Is broken, don't get this game to play with ships, very little effort was put into them, and they do not function very well at all.2. All of the screenshots for this game on steam are fake. All of them, for example, Wheeled vehicles move faster on roads so in the screenshot where tracked and wheeled chinese AA units drive together, is litterally not possible in the game, since there is no fuction to make units move together at the same speed.3. There is no formation control at all. So if you want any formation you'll have to manage all your units one at a time. 4. The game isn't particularly balanced, overall Western Forces has some huge advantages, they may not be obvious, but to competitive players they are blatant, hence why that 80% of competitive players play NATO. This has been the case since release and also in wargame ALB, so do not expect this to be fixed anytime soon, especially since the developer doesn't acknowledge overall balance concern raised by competitive players.5. This game has a lot of hidden statistics, some of the most imporant statistics are not displayed ingame, and in order to play the game efficiantly you HAVE to go on the forum, and do a lot of reading.Some pros to this now:1. Huge amount of units, you'll see how simplistic and silly, most games view on units are when claiming to be authentic.2. There are genuine differences in units, and they feel powerful mostly.3. The engine is pretty hardcore, unless you have litterally a thousand units on the map, this game runds extremely smooth in my oppinion.4. Despite the unbalances, the game has a lot of room for skill progression, if you have the wits for it, it's possible to be really good at this game, and in that case it doesn't matter what faction you play.5. If you are a nationalist this is probably the game of your wet dreams as you will be allowed to trash evil communists/capitalists with just about every land or air vehicle made in the Soviet Union, USA, western europe, east asia and oceania the past 40-50 years. Even as Denmark.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
												One of the best RTS ever made. Worth every penny. I have 1800 hours in this game now according to Steam, and I still enjoy it. I still learn new tricks and tactics every now and then.If you like (semi-realistic) RTS, you will love Wargame.There is no base building and it has a very steep learning curve, but once you've figured things out, you're going to love it.Made by a great studio which is still supporting the game with patches and DLCs. On top it still has a very active community and you will always find a multiplayer game.Estimated online player count:Minimum: 500Maximum: 1000 - 1200 (late evening and saturday night [CET])Steam sale peaks: 1500 and moreThose numbers have been stable throughout the past at least 12 months.Since the game is pretty complex and detailed, you will need some time to get good. But at the same time this ensures the game isn't going to get boring anytime soon. So many nations, so many units, so many different tactics you can try.

content:
Posted: January 2
												Wargame: Red Dragon is the third installment of the Wargame franchise, and is an excellant work of Eugen. + Great gameplay experience.+ Variety of nations: 17 in base game and additional 4 in DLC.+ Large variety of units with deck building system allowing to customize your play style.+ Well-designed textures, even able to run on older hardware.+ Modding capacity available for those interested.+ Replays+ Both small-scale and large-scale battles are available.+ Customizeable match settings+ Large variety of different sized maps, each well-done.- UI is distinguished, yes, but could be more customizeable.- AI is simplistic and difficulties of AI offer little change.- More available default decks, such as one for more prominant "coalitions," or pair-ups of nations, would allow for new players to adapt to the deck-building system better than one or two default decks.- Multiplayer community is uncommitted to the game, as multiple players may leave in the middle of a match for trivial reasons.- Campaigns are lacking and no additional content is provided for them.- Naval units are lacking and no additional content is provided for them.* Not base building RTS* Multiplayer focused* Takes time to learn units and how to use them well. Game does provide armory where player can view every units characteristic.Adapted from another person's review. Credit to Sunbeam for an accurate overlook of the game.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												I greatly anticipated this game for a long time, after falling deep in love with AirLand Battle. If you are a veteran RTS player, or never touched one in your life, or a military buff that has never even played a game, this game is really something for you.However, I will warn you now, that there is a large learning curve in the multiplayer. To compete against experienced players takes a lot of learning, as the massive selection of units, maps, and mechanics makes it an enormous task. This does not mean you can not have fun learning though! (read on..)In skirmish modes (Against the AI) You have the option to slow down and stop (as well as speed up) time to give you more time to give orders to your unitsThe deck mechanic is really what adds so much to this game. You can spend many hours (I have) browsing the armoury, analysing and comparing unit stats, adding them to your deck, checking out the amazing unit models, and then getting to take them to combat! With 1450 units in the game, there is an amazing feeling with finding that an understated unit is a beautiful performer - You can get very attached to them.The devs have really taken what was excellent about the two previous games, and then piled on more. There is plenty in this game for you.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
												WarGame Red Dragon. 8/10I love RTS. My favorite to date is still Company of Heros because of the story driven theme and it's a good RTS in general.Wargame Red Dragon is next up. While there is little personality to the game, I love it anyway because I am also a sim junkie. This is what would result if World in Conflict got A-10 warthog Flaming Cliffs pregnant. I really like the scale, the terrain, the Era, the models and the depth of comand. Just creating your own special decks for multiplayer is fun, and is perfect for satisfing your mico manage OCD.While many people complain about balance, I do not. I would rather try to come up with clever stratagies to bring an underdog up. We have played using the worst OPFOR decks we can create and still win (more so than with a premium Blufor deck). Some features I personally like. 1) When you are playing a multiplayer game, you are sort of stuck watching the battle from birds eye view so you can keep an eye on the field which isnt that cool, but when the battle is over, you can replay it and adjust the time. Now you can watch the battle from any angle, even from a units shoulder. Those who make epic vids will love this.2) While the scale isn't "realistic" it is scaled very well.  Well enough to give you some feel for actual stratagy. This is why I say it has a nice SIM feel to it.3) VARIETY. You can create the deck you want to play! It's not a matter of caping an "AMMO" dump so you can afford tanks. You get what you bring, you bring what you want. Great for team play.4) I LIKE THE NAVY! This notion of one Navy being better than another is false. It's all about your deck and how you use it. If your enemy showed up with a better navy than you, then chances are your Air Force is better than theirs. Every battle is an excercise in knowing what is your strength and thier weakness is this vast combonation of units.5) I like friend chat and invite features. You dont need to tab in and out of Steam to invite friends to join game. 6) Choke points are only partially important.  As a result there is always a way around a fortified position, it's just time consuming and risky. Not a mindless meat grinder that devlopes the same area each instance of the map.7) The best and really only modern arms grand command simulator! If you like games like Total War Napoleon for the battle instances, you will like this one. That leads me to what I wish the game had.1) A grand campaign like the Total War series. Then you could bring other units into it like ICBM, spies, satalites and diplomacy. Have populations and national rescources.2) Combat enjineers who deploy bridges across rivers for battles.3)Anywhere but enemy territory placeable FOBS that dont run out of supply if in a friendly zone but can be placed in a neutral area. 4) A topigraphical overlay. I love the importance of LOS and elevation, It would be even better if it was easier to see from a distance.5) Better concealment for infantry in forrest. Some AI behaviors for them. Like running away from napalm, taking cover automaticly under fire from heavy weapons.6) Navy divers that can swim unseen and Marine units that can forde rivers on foot.7) Loss of communication to units if all your Command units are destroyed.That about sums it up. I don't subtract from the game for the things it dosn't have, because it's unrealistic to expect everything. I giive it high scores because it aproaches RTS in a way I always wished they would, and I like the theme that so few have tried to do, and the Few that have tried were not this good. I.e. Real War, JTF, or World in conlict.A very good game. If you don't get it, chances are you'll spend just as much on somthing not as good. Keep in mind it can be very rough on the video card and memory. The Auto tune for graphics will set it too high. Unless your rig is pretty epic, this will push even the better computers just a few years old to the brink. Once its set right though, it runs like a champ and looks great. You can run replays better than the play out.Hope to see you all on the battlefield.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
Disclaimer: I am not a big time RTS player. The only RTS games I have played are the earlier AoE games, 1, 2 and a little bit of Mythology; so my review of this RTS game may not be framed in ways similar to others who may have considerably more RTS gaming experience. I also have really only played the Destruction multiplayer game mode and tend to only play with friends or play solo. Wargame: Red Dragon is a fast paced RTS set during the Cold War. Players control individual units that they deploy from a pre-selected group of units called a 'Deck' that they can build (or share with friends!) based on nations belonging to NATO or the Warsaw Pact.W:RD takes out the boring aspect of resource collection and keeps the action fast and intense; It is not easy to learn and very hard to master. After 144 hours I still have yet to beat the first campaign. (My perfectionist habits have something to do with that, but only a little bit). Pros:- Obvious learning curve (only a pro if you're into that sort of thing. I am).- Intense, fast paced action.- A lot of units and nations to choose from. Deck building actually got me interested in other nation's military hardware/history.- Multiplayer is great with friends; ignore the overall community in the global chat. Frankly just turn that off.- The AI on higher difficulties punishes you for stupid strategies.Cons:- Lack of tutorial content. (Lots of good stuff on YouTube if you don't have any friends to help you learn).- Maps start to feel a tad boring/same with how many there are. This game could benefit from a lot more maps.- Without your own server you can't host games larger than 4v4. (This game supports 10v10)- Lack of simplified mod support. There are mods, but the support for them could be more streamlined for creators and users.Notes: I'm sure a lot of people may talk about 'balance' and such but I have yet to fully experience the full potential of this game and different potential strategies so I cannot rightly speak about balance yet. Favorite deck style: West Germany Mechanized.This is a definite buy for me. Full price. Even better if you can get it on sale or in a huge Steam sale Wargame pack deal and get the older games, too. See how the series has changed between releases.

Posted: July 27, 2014
												Welcome to the land of the Hard Core Gentlmen over 1500 units spanning Land, Sea, & Air representing a Host nations all built an trained to fight... If you step up to the big league ...you better know how. This game is unforgivably hard an multiplayer is even more brutal, for every one tactic, there are 2 or 3 counters so you better bone up on your combined arms tactics quick fast in a hurry. You micro manage logistics making sure your army that you create to form custom decks have the fuel an ammo it needs in real time while overseeing an executing strike taking enemy teritory an denying them resorces. This is a game of punch an counter punch. You have to think big an 2 steps ahead making sure you have the intel and equipment to in the right place to take your objectives, Cause if you loose a unit its gone. The battlefield is fluid an vividly rendered .... your not going to find a better looking game. It is painfully hard with a steep learning curve and it wears it as a badge of honor. If you like RTS's or a Military buff, or you just want to live out your dreams as an armchair general. Do me a favor Get this game you wont regret it. Well what are you waiting for, Gear up an get to fighting... Good Luck and Happy Hunting.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												Wargame: Red Dragon is an interesting take on the strategy genre. The game takes place through two screens: the map screen and the battle screen. The map screen takes a form similar to that of WW2 planning boards you always see in movies, and is quite novel if not effective. The battle screen is as one might expect: a bird's eye view of the battlefield(with the option to zoom in to an incredible range) but what is interesting is not the screen but the mechanics of battle. If you've ever played almost any other RTS then you'll know ammunition is not usually a feature of those games. However in Wargame: RD you must worry about logistics, you'll need to send in supply trucks to keep your tanks armed and your Helicopters filled with missles.The only real failing point of this game is the lack of the proper tutorial. The entire game is summarisied in text screen tutorials which do little to explain the complex mechanics of war. The RTS afficandio will quickly pick up the tools of the trade but I fear that someone not familiar to the genre might not fare as well.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												Overall, one of the best games I have ever played.. I haven't played any multiplayer games yet. But seeing the videos online, playing against humans certainly is different than against the AI. If want to play against the AI, you will find a mixed bag. Sometime the AI is simply overpowered and sometimes it's acceptable. The game, just like any complex strategy game, requires a steep enjoyable learning curve but it is certainly worth it. On the negative side, the game is better played in multiplayer which is a problem for people who doesn't have the time or friends interested. The game could use some better terrains system. I can consider this as a future development. I am looking forward to see the next iteration and I would like to see the following:1. Better AI. 2. Better terrain system that can give more depth to the game. 3. Modding 4. Better campaign  If I choose only one thing to ask, it will be better terrain system, building to hide in, real towns and cities, ability to build ground defenses (mines, sand bags, camps and so), ability use the commandos and infantry in more deep way). The game is really good in terms of weapons management and selection but the maps are not interactive.  Will definitely buy the next iteration. Modding is what makes the PC games superior.

												Although the game takes a little adapting to, Wargame: Red Dragon is a unique RTS experience. With a competitive multiplayer and pretty good singleplayer (albeit with wildly differing playstyles, as the AI is rather different to a 'real' player). However, my preferred method of play is the AI Skirmish - there's nothing quite like giving the AI hordes of cheap tanks and taking them on with a hand-picked selection of my favourite units! Truly a game with something for every type of RTS gamer!Oh, and one more thing: The developers have released 2 free DLC packs for this game, and, at the time of writing, they're working on a third to upgrade the Scandinavian nations from the previous game (you can play them, but they're sub-par) to the same standard as the others and add some new maps. Support FreeLC! Buy this awesome game!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												From a newcomer with no experience with the prior games, but one who has been obsessing with this one for the past 3 days or so: Wargame is an amazing endeavour and is one of the most in-depth RTS's on Steam.The Wargame series is heavily influenced by World In Crisis, another WWIII RTS, and if you've played that game, you'll be familiar with the broad strokes. The biggest difference is one of scale. In WiC, an armored commander will end up controlling maybe 3-4 heavy tanks and a couple other random units once he's maxxed out. In Wargame, a player with an armored deck (more on decks in a minute) will *start* the game with maybe 8 heavy tanks, or else mass hordes off lesser or obsolete tanks, in addition to support... and it goes up from there. The maps are also truly massive, with even the smaller ones roughly 100km by 100km and going up from there -- the scale is more in line with the first Supreme Commander. Within that vast distance, even specialized commanders must jostle with multiple control groups of their frontline guys, recon, supply/logistics (this is a big one), air defense, and so forth.Like WiC, the game is built around hard counters, with even the mightiest unit reduced to scrap in seconds if it meets its counter. The key is recon, to know what the enemy has and where, so that you may counter it. Are they sending in mass hordes of tanks? If your recon spots it in time, you can counter with helis or Maverick-armed AT planes. Does the enemy have an assload of AA? Keep your helis/planes far away, and charge your own armor or light vehicles in. Do they have a bioball of massed infantry in a town? Time for your arty to step up -- or even better, napalm-equipped units. All of this depends on having good recon to know what counter you need to bring onto the field.As far as the much-derired naval content goes: Yes, I'm sure the pure-navy maps suck. But coastline maps are where your navy shines. You do not command capital ships in this game -- think more along the lines of patrol boats. And every deck gets free naval units the player may build if he chooses. Completely ignoring the water parts of these maps is a valid strategy, letting you concentrate everything on your land and air; but on the other hand, owning the water denies the shoreline to the enemy, and the heavy AA of most ships gives you an excellent no-fly zone.I mentioned supply and logistics. All units have only limited ammo, some more limited than others; all units besides infantry also have fuel; and, naturally, units need healing after taking damage in combat. Supply units take care of all these needs, but the supply units are all vulnerable and die if an enemy even looks at them wrong. This adds an extra dimension to combat not found in most of these games.The graphics are servicable, and are mostly enjoyed in replays. In-game, you will be too busy to enjoy them, similar to Supreme Commander: you're zoomed-out, dealing with icons. Sounds are also basic and servicable; unit prompts are always in the unit's tongue.As far as decks go: this is one of the greatest innovations of the game. A deck is the selection of units you bring into a match. Decks can be generalist, or (in the spirit of WiC) focused on armored, air, etc; focused decks give you bonuses to focused units at the expense of reduced options everywhere else. You can draw units from the entirety of your faction (NATO + Japan/S.Korea, or else WarPac + China/N.Korea), or you can limit yourself to just a few or even one nation for further bonuses at the cost of, again, reduced options. (Want to play as Denmark fighting against the Soviet Union? This game has your back!) You can and will spend hours simply building various "decks" you can bring into a game.The AI is servicable, but limited. It will keep a new player on their toes, but its quirks will soon be learned by even the novice. It "fast moves" on roads too much; it never buys ships on coastal maps; it seems confused on what to do with infantry. On the other hand, it can build a mean armored column that will take you by surprise and back it up with gunships and AA. If you want the AI fighting at its best, give it a more armored and support-focused deck that neglects infantry.On that note, it should be mentioned that the multiplayer community of this game is filled with racists and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. You are better off with people you know IRL.Anyway, if you are looking for an incredibly deep RTS with a steep learning curve, yet one that eschews the APM-centric style of most RTS's, you've come to the right place.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												Wargame: Red Dragon is an RTS expandalone, so there is no need to buy the other games. In a genre defined by dogma, this game is a beacon of hope. This game has many western and eastern countries, set between 1970 to 2000. This game attempts to strive for realistic depictions of real life hardware.There is no base building, you create your army before venturing into the flames of battle. It does this in an addictive deck system, in which you can pick and choose your units. There are a staggering amount of choices, including motorized infantry, mechanized infantry, tanks, helicopters, hq units, supply units, planes, and others. The scope of the maps matches the scope of the deck system, including massive maps built for combined ops. This allows for massive engagements with semi-realistic weapon ranges.Even though this is the third game in the franchise, it does have obvious flaws. One of such is the infantry. Infantry moves strangely, with speed and animation not synchronizing. The formations of the infantry is often staggered circles, they do not take cover unless you shove them in structures. For some reason, tanks and other vehicles cannot use coaxial machine guns. These another factors contribute to make this game's tactical side to appear shallow. There are no strategic bombers or missile launchers, and the ship combat is grossly scaled down and simplified. This game features multiple "dynamic" campaigns, which are annoying but pretty well crafted. The skirmish and multiplayer are solid. The multiplayer features a very ecstatic community, if you take it with a grain of salt it can be vary humourous. In conclusion, this game is a fresh new take on RTS, only one of its kind, however it suffers from a lack of polish and attention to detail. I cannot wait until the next installment.8/10

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												Let me assume that you like a rts games, may be with emphasis on tactics. Let me also assume that you are intrested in mordern warfare, realistic one, with a full variety of war machines... I think you will be intrested in this game.This game isn't a simulator, there are no real parameters of vehicles, there is no accurate ballistics, there is no physically based armor penetration. This game utilizes a really impressive, tuned for balance and scales of the game, set of parameters to imitate combat like a real one. And what is more important, it does it quite well. The number of fractions and available war machines are very impressive, nevertheless some intresting vehicles are absent . There are two blocks - Nato + Allies (Blue) and Warsaw Pact + Allies (Red). Every fraction has it's pros and cons, but overall Reds a less accurate, but more endurable, while Blues vice versa.The single missions are not very important and can be considered as a training before you jump in multiplayer games. They are all about hypotetical conflicts and quiet entertainig. Unfortunately your experience in these missions won't help you much in multiplayer games. In latter ones you will suffer, because there are a lot of skilled players. They know tactical tricks, they have a good micro, they know maps. Thus it would be much better to play with a friends.As a summary, Red Dragon is an intresting realistic-like strategy game with emphasis on a multiplayer game, if you like rts genre, you should probably try this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												Pros: Great RTS, good multiplayer, good graphics.  I love to play this game, my friend and I play this all the time, and the DLC is free.  Games are easy to get into, you can find multiplayer games on any difficulty.Cons: AI.  I have a few problems with the AI in this game. 1. Whenever I try to play the campaign, I lose, even on easy, the AI somehow has enough great tanks from 1000 points to bum rush and defend against 4 K1s.  2. Stupid stuff- My friend and I sometimes play against AI.  Whenever we get to the last zone the enemy controls, and destroy their command, the game doesn't end, which it should if you destroy their last command, and we spend 30 minutes looking for it (we don't quit because it will put a loss on your record) and we finally find it hidden in forests in the middle of the map, and even right next to out main base!  It is literally trying to find a needle in a hay stack.  3. Balancing- I played a 4v4 game (3 very hard AI and I vs 4 medium AI) and the 4 medium AI won! (I did better than all the very hard AI).  4.  Spam- I had to make my own deck for the AI to use because every time I play against AI that is using a regular deck, they buy commands and billions of attack helicopters that frustrates me to no end.Overall:  I love this game and highly recommend it.  Yeah, the AI has some problems, but multiplayer is very fun, plus, how can you beat free DLC?  Worth the price!

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												Overall, one of the best games I have ever played.. I haven't played any multiplayer games yet. But seeing the videos online, playing against humans certainly is different than against the AI. If want to play against the AI, you will find a mixed bag. Sometime the AI is simply overpowered and sometimes it's acceptable. The game, just like any complex strategy game, requires a steep enjoyable learning curve but it is certainly worth it. On the negative side, the game is better played in multiplayer which is a problem for people who doesn't have the time or friends interested. The game could use some better terrains system. I can consider this as a future development. I am looking forward to see the next iteration and I would like to see the following:1. Better AI. 2. Better terrain system that can give more depth to the game. 3. Modding 4. Better campaign  If I choose only one thing to ask, it will be better terrain system, building to hide in, real towns and cities, ability to build ground defenses (mines, sand bags, camps and so), ability use the commandos and infantry in more deep way). The game is really good in terms of weapons management and selection but the maps are not interactive.  Will definitely buy the next iteration. Modding is what makes the PC games superior.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												Although the game takes a little adapting to, Wargame: Red Dragon is a unique RTS experience. With a competitive multiplayer and pretty good singleplayer (albeit with wildly differing playstyles, as the AI is rather different to a 'real' player). However, my preferred method of play is the AI Skirmish - there's nothing quite like giving the AI hordes of cheap tanks and taking them on with a hand-picked selection of my favourite units! Truly a game with something for every type of RTS gamer!Oh, and one more thing: The developers have released 2 free DLC packs for this game, and, at the time of writing, they're working on a third to upgrade the Scandinavian nations from the previous game (you can play them, but they're sub-par) to the same standard as the others and add some new maps. Support FreeLC! Buy this awesome game!

content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												It was very hard for me to fully summarize all interesting & facinating aspects of this game, since that  every setting , every element connected with mechanized warfare attracts military fans like myself. After the entire a hundred hours of playing default campaign(25) and Outposts (75), I managed to recommand it to three of my friends and now we Netplay every few days, of course they're also military fans. Actually I mean, not close to C&C or RA, neither does it like CS1.6/CS:GO or other FPS, first of all you need to be interested in military affairs, which those previous games does not require. Also, you have to be very clear what those equipment & troopers are for, what they can do during a battle, and how can you reach the best cost-effectiveness ratio rather than gathering a collection of bad choices. It is kind of like the Art of War, containing certain military theories if you noticed, which sets a very hig threshold for normal players. Anyway, ￥79 is definately worthy.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												Absolutely engrossing as a real time strategy game although a little deep if you are not familiar with the genre. Best played with friends of a similar skill level to have a fun experience. This is the first RTS game I've got properly in to and after an initial (and considerable) learning curve I'm really struck by how solidly made and deep this game is. There is quite a high barrier to entry here and you will be frustrated at first by tactics or units you are unfamiliar with.   If you are new to RTS games or even the Wargame series I'd recommend playing against friends at first - as the difficulty ceiling is so high, you'd be spending hundreds of hours to become competitive with other players who already have a good understanding of the game. Unfortunately the AI appears not to be able to fight you in the same way a player would and this becomes more and more apparent whilst playing against real opponents.   I had no technical issues with this game at all and the it runs remarkably well considering the graphical detail on screen.  If you are a long time RTS player or new to the genre all together there is enough depth here to keep you hooked for a long time.
