content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												A truly fantastic RTS, this game really should go up on the shelf alongside Command and Conquer, World and Conflict, and all of the other classic Real Time Strategy games out there. Wargame: Red Dragon is the refreshing 2014 installment and sequel to the 2013 Wargame: Airland Battle. Red Dragon is the third installment in the series and provides new features and choices for gameplay while retaining the best features of the Wargame: ALB. This time the Cold War moves from it's Theater of War in Northern Europe to the Pacific and Eastern Asia. Fans of the previous Wargames franchise as well as players new to the series will be really delited with this latest sequel as developer Eugen Systems debuts it's 2014 installment in the Wargames series. Oh Yeah, did I mention they added Naval Combat?!Singleplayer:For those of you who have played Wargames before, whetehr it be Wargame: European Escalation or Wargame: Airland Battle, you will know that the plot line for the franchise is set in a ficticious alternate historical timeline set in the late 1970's and well into the 1980's. Wargame: Red Dragon features four new campaign plot lines set during the cold war in Asia; each is set in a different time with a different faction. The reason there are four different campaigns is because of the fact that each campaign goes along with a difficulty setting: command the South Korean military forces in order to repel an overwhelming North Korean invasion force on Easy Difficulty. Try reigniting the Sino-Soviet border conflict as the Chinese on Medium Difficulty. Repel an immense offensive by the PLA of China in an attempt to reclaim Hong Kong as the British on Hard Difficulty. And for the finale, lead a conquest of the Japanese mainland before the American forces can arrive in order to support their comrades in distress as the Soviet Union on Very Hard difficulty. So, with all of these different campaigns the player is given more choice in how they go about tackling a situation then in most RTS campaigns which I found to be really enjoyable since the game conforms to your playing style. I think that the developers of this game did a great job in not just the way the game plays but also in the storyline in order to make it as realistic as possible but still balanced enough to fight a fair war. Choosing the late Cold War as a time to set an RTS is really interesting because weaponry and warfare are still balanced at this point between either the PACT faction or the allied NATO forces. The context of the setting takes place before the information era so weapons systems haven't quite yet reach a point a point where a drone strike can whipe out a unit of hostil forces with the push of a button from all the other side of the globe. This games storyline and multiplayer provides two different ideologically parted empires waging violent and destructive skirmishes across the globe. While Wargame: Red Dragon's campaign is a fantastic embodiement of these features and incorporating them into it's storyline, the only thing that bugged me a bit was how in the singleplayer storyline the conflicts didn't seem to have much connection to each other and should have been drawnout longer. Multiplayer: While the Wargame series is infamous for it's setting during the Cold War, the embodiement of these factors is better brought out through the multiplayer experience. Set on a number of maps throughout Asia (I presume) the multiplayer element feels the same and doesn't stray too much from Wargame: ALB with the exception of new Asia based factions and units added to the game. In terms of map diversity however, the game does feel a bit different in the details. The more traditional maps of the first two Wargame installments were set in European countryside towns with some Urban presence including buildings for infantry to duke it out in, but usually it would be forests and farms. Wargame: Red Dragon's maps are different both visually and aesthetically. Since the addition of naval warfare to the series, the maps in Wargame generally revolve around coastal areas with dense jungle and plots of rice farms. The forests have now generally been replaced by jungle. One of the latest items of the maps for this game I was excited about was the introduction of denser maps which means more urban areas and denser jungles which really allowed for the tank battles to take place further away then the infantry battles. The overall experience of Wargame multiplayer feels like it's gotten a refreshing new update and I would definitely recommend this game to anyone looking for a good pop-in and pop-out RTS.

												This is one of those games that may feel overwhelming at the beginning but once you start playing it's just GREAT. If you played with plastic soldiers when you were a kid this game is for you. Great level of details for the units and mechanics of combat with a great aereal view makes you feel you are seeing a real combat situation. Also that even if i haven't tried the naval part of the game i smell it won't be as good as the land part.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												Absolutely engrossing as a real time strategy game although a little deep if you are not familiar with the genre. Best played with friends of a similar skill level to have a fun experience. This is the first RTS game I've got properly in to and after an initial (and considerable) learning curve I'm really struck by how solidly made and deep this game is. There is quite a high barrier to entry here and you will be frustrated at first by tactics or units you are unfamiliar with.   If you are new to RTS games or even the Wargame series I'd recommend playing against friends at first - as the difficulty ceiling is so high, you'd be spending hundreds of hours to become competitive with other players who already have a good understanding of the game. Unfortunately the AI appears not to be able to fight you in the same way a player would and this becomes more and more apparent whilst playing against real opponents.   I had no technical issues with this game at all and the it runs remarkably well considering the graphical detail on screen.  If you are a long time RTS player or new to the genre all together there is enough depth here to keep you hooked for a long time.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
												PROS:+its fun+it runs well even on potatoes+its in depth+its challenging+great community *citation needed*+two facions, lots of nations+hundreds of real life units+fun single player campaign+fun single player in general+fun multiplayerCONS:-no playable tutorial, and the tutorial it has is pretty useless-jet spam-cheatsy AI-not as many game modes as the earlier games-cheap unit spamI really really really love this game, like, alot. When I saw this game was on sale i bought the pack for me and two friends at a grand total nearing 50 bucks, a total ♥♥♥♥ing steal honestly.I had seen this game before on youtube and i knew it was something that id love to play. when i installed it and loaded it up the first thing i noticed was that the tutorials are more like simple manuals than anything, infact im really happy i had airland battle because that game comes with a playable tutorial, that showed me many of the basics, afterwards i spent several hours on youtube learning about all sorts of different stuff in the game like tactics, unit types, how to build a decent deck, etc etc.Once I thought i had the basic idea of deck making down i made an american deck and went into a 1v1 against the AI and got my♥♥♥♥♥whooped, i revised this deck several times and have since made dozens of decks for america, with just as many for other nations as well.This brings me to the AI, it is extremely frustrating and seems to carry the same issues with it that the previous games had. it seems to have limitless points and it will always know where your units are. if youve got an ambush set up with whatever unit type, when the enemy arrives, if ever, it will also happen to bring with it what it needs to ♥♥♥♥ your♥♥♥♥♥♥ In other cases they have a large attack elsewhere that forces you to redirect your forces and right when you do that, they come rolling through the now lightly guarded flank you just moved forces from. another thing i noticed is that its either to easy or to hard, medium and easy bots i can steam role so much so that it normally ends in a 15 minute man hunt with every single unit i can muster searching the whole map in one large net that covers everything, however if i play agaisnt a hard bot my units are always out numbered out preformed and destroyed with ease.When i got this series i also bought it for two friends, we hopped into airland battle first and had fun playing the defense game mode and the multiplayer campaign, both of which i was heart brokento see didnt return to red dragon, which is fine, because the 3 it has are fun to play regardless, just kina sucks i cant play those great modes in this new game.The first issue i ran into in this game was deciding what units to use and what nations i should play as. i eventually settled on maining the US and brits and making specialized decks for pretty much every occasion, and decks that covered more than one specialtty and were more generalized. this game has way to many units for me to even begin to memorize honestly, i look at youtubers or listen to players who can identify a vehicle just off of its fire rate, mobility, or its black outline. each of the larger nations have its own one of a kind units, while smaller nations not only use some of their own, but have a large slew  of tech from other nations, one of the most common examples are leopard tanks. some nations even get really old units from WW2 and that makes for some fun custom games with friends or against bots. each of the large nations has its own specialty, with the US your airforce is unmatched and for the UK you have some of the most powerful armor in game. while the game doesnt showcase exact armor values, speeds, or preformances of vehicles, it gives you an accurate representation in values much easier to understand. rather than saying that tank A has this much armor at this angle and this ATGM can pen this much at this angle it will say tank a has 12 armor at the front and this ATGM can pen 20. same thing carries over to planes with their values. there is honestly so much when it comes to units its very overwhelming to many players.one of the biggest issues this game has is the spam of one unit type, it can either ruin your forces because its a♥♥♥♥♥♥idea or ruin your enemies fun because its ♥♥♥♥ing cheap. something that bothers me heavily is jet spam or heli spam, the first half is more true for american forces while the second half more so for russians. with the jets they comletely ♥♥♥♥ing ruin your ground forces and your AA normally cant kill them, or tank all of them out. when it comes to heli spam youll have tanks or infantry roling into a city or jungle and out of nowhere there are dozens of rocket choppers ruining your forces before the enemy sends in its ground forces to slaughter any of the remaining stunned units, and to be fair this is a legit tactic, but  9 times out of 10 your AA cant handle such a large task and will get killed by the choppers. the same can be true for arty, something any nation can spam, but with that you can actually pinpoin the enemies location so generally they either have to move after a volley or two or risk getting killed by counter arty or some kind of plane or heli.another thing is the spam of cheap as dirt units, 60 jacksons, hellcats,chaffees,T3485s, or any other out dated unit costing 10 to 15 points they are often wasteful and its great when your enemy does it but infuriating when your ally does it, now there is nothing wrogn with sending these units onto the exposed flank of heavier armo to take them out or sending them against APCs and such, but spamming 60 or so and rushing the enemy with SU76s is ♥♥♥♥ing stupid.the community itself is very much alive in this game, and is, interesting to say the least, you can meet some great people playing this game  but ill say this, enter warchat at your own risk.all in all this game is excellent, and the issues i listed really get overshadowed by the pros. this game is a super in depth and fun to play RTS i seriously suggest it for any hardcore gamer who likes these kind of games and really wants a challenge.TL;DR REDFOR TANKS BEWARE, THE APACHE LONGBOW IS IN THE AIR

content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												I recommend this game highly.. BUT I DO NOT RECOMMEND PRE-BUYING it for the beta if you are looking for naval units that are missing from the other games.   They simply do not exist yet.  They will sooner or later.  But Eugen is trying to fix the 'blob' atmosphere of the naval in a game where blob atmosphere reigns supreme.    People blob tanks, airplanes, infantry, AA... why would they think they wouldn't blob naval?  The only real way this could happen is if boats had a larger collision radius, and could not physically be blobbed, forcing distance between them.This version of the game without naval is superior to Airland battle.  It changes a lot of things and the tactics of playing it change with it.  Its a bit of a learning curve, but BLOBBING = winning.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
												I have read a lot of the bad reviews.  Some have good points like the navy part is lacking in number of units and the campaign is not much fun.  But most of the complants are people that are just bad at the game and get on here and FLAME becasue they are getting destroyed in multiplayer.  Main reason why is becasue they don't take the time to understand and learn.  I got wrecked the first month i played too but i learned and didn't rage quit and go cry about it on a review.  If your looking for a kiddie rock, paper, build order spam like Star Craft this game is NOT for you.  This game is much more advanced in the tactics needed to win most of the time.  The Wargame series is easily the best (non build order spam) RTS games you can buy.  Man up and play multiplayer and learn.  The game is not hard and is not complicated to play but it does require you to make the right calls at the right times with the right unit mix for success.  Or go back and spam zerling or build a victory fleet and think your awesome.  haha.  PS i do like Star Craft but it is like playing with kiddie toys once your learn Wargame.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
												If you love strategy games in general, with the modern day setting there is no reason not to get this.It is very tactical, has quite a steep learning curve, but only in the sense that you need to understand that everything has a counter. Once you learn which unit does what, the combination of them makes for great gameplay. You should feel comfortable after about 10 + mulitplayer games. It`s an addictive, well polished and great franchise. With around 300+ hours in the previous iteration of this game Wargame Airland Battle, and around 20 + hours in Red Dragon, I cannot recommend this enough. Each tactic has it`s merits, and each player brings something different to the table. Your ability to communicate with team mates, and subsequent manouveres allows for exciting and nail biting intensity.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
												Wargame: Red DragonA fantastic game that is loads of fun. An improvement over the previous titles, it is now much more of a complete RTS. It is one of the best RTS games available, and requires more realistic tactics, thought and gameplay than other RTS games. Imagine ARMA II as a proper RTS Game with each of the thousands of air, land and sea units have specifications based on real life. Multiplayer is where this game truly shines. The single player is just good as well with a "pick your own path" open gameplay. Multiplayer has a steep learning curve, but is well worth it once you understand the game play and functionality. The deck building function of the game is also great fun in its self and gives you the option to build your own unique forces. You'll be constantly trying to perfect your deck to be the best it can be, chopping and changing as your tactics change.

content:
Posted: March 25, 2014
												Since the game has pretty much stopped development, I figure I would write a review.I have been invloved with this game since closed alpha and have followed its development quite closely. This game is a blast and as my hours show, my favorite game of all time. The unit choices are amazing, but keep in mind alot of those units you will never touch as they are outdated or useless, still it is quite amazing the level of choice you have. The game is quite simple, you build a deck thats unit choice is determined by its country, coalition (more than 1 nation) and so on. You fill these decks up with various units and play. The campaign is decent apparently, I have never touched it but it is worth playing for new players to get used to the mechanics. The learning curve is quite steep, but is completly worth it in the end. The community, while sometimes cancerous, has an excelent community initiative called the Wargame Learning Program that offers 1 on 1 personal tutoring that is completly free and incredibly helpful. People are more than happy to show you the ropes as the community is quite small and new players (who try ) are very much appreciated. I personally believe that playing with friends is mandatory and makes the experience far better. Since the game is often on sale, I reccomend palying with your mates. Finally, dont get this game for the naval combat, it is a silly gimick and has been completly abandoned by the devs. Ships still lack sounds and it is quite unblanaced. Also FRENCH BIAS IS REAL. Final rating French/10.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
(Had to wright this review AGAIN from scratch because steam didn't post and save it the last time so bear with me if something seems off or typos.)This is an amazing strategy game and a MUST have for RTS fans. Has a high learning curve so don't expect any handholding. PROS:+ No Unit Limits. (I've had upwards of over 300 units on the field at one time this includes tanks/infantry/vehicles/helicopters, and jets not counting my allies or enemies units.)+ Thousands of Different Units. (Though some are kind of reskins each unit has their own special role on the battle field.)+ VERY Strategic. (Should I postion my infantry in the nearby town and have them take cover in the buildings below or just march a few thousand infantry in forest cover over that mountain and risk getting napalm bombed if spotted by a recon unit.........meh I'll just fire a few hundred artillary rounds at their base camp and try to get lucky.)+ Cinimatic AND Functional. (Not often does a game manage to create so many cinimatic moments yet be fully about a functional playing experience)+ Polished Land Combat. (Land combat is pretty much perfect in this game more on water combat later.)+ Resource Management. (Your Frontline Base(FOB) comes with a set supply number. Pay close attention as this will be your life blood. Your resoures are split into 3 categories Ammo, Fuel, and Spare Parts. Managing to supply units far off will prove to be rather challenging but all the more fun. You have a limited number of units that can deliever supplies with their own varying strengths and weaknesses. Supply ships can be sunk, Cargo Caravans can be stolen/blown to hell, and supply choppers can be shot down so be careful with them in high conflict areas as they will be high priority targets for the enemy.)+ Multiplayer. (Yay for some Nay for others more on that later)+ Lots of Factions. (From Nato, to North Korea, to Russia and many more)CONS:- Water Units/Combat Sucks. (Red Dragon introduced water units into the Wargame franchise and it really shows. What lies before you is a lackluster experience. Water combat is clunky, ship pathing is wonky and besides the many other obscure reasons I'd rather fight a donkey. Ok lame jokes aside the new water units mainly ships with the occasional sea helicopter or jet are sorely under utilized as most players have just given up on water units and maps altogether because of said problems. Not to mention maps that have a heavy water and land mix screw over infantry that ride in vehicles as they can not travel across water and there are no ships that can ferry them across. The only way to get infantry around on a water/land map is if they're helicopter troops. Eugene has something going here but it really needs more work put into it.)- Multiplayer. (1. If you expect to enjoy that glorious 10x10 multiplayer action BEWARE! As the game will kick you if your internet speeds are too slow. Honestly I've never played a multi match until the end because my internet speed  is such garbage. Thankfully the game has a great single player skirmish mode with a very competent AI where most players spend their time.  If you have pretty decent speeds this shouldn't be a problem though. 2. Because of said problems and a few other's finding a multi match may be a bit hard and even if you do the game will kick players for speeds or some may just leave for reasons causing you to be put in a situation where it's almost impossible to win a match.)- No Resupplying of FOBs. (Ok some people are gonna say that's what's so good about the game or that I'm a noob and using too much or I'm not playing strategically or I should have just built more before the start of the game. While that may all be true at times it shouldn't be used as an excuse to cover up such a glaring fault. If this game sales itself as a realistic strategy I don't know how they justify real world bases actually getting supplied but not here. Though you can increase the amount of supplies a FOB has in a txt file in the directory, an ingame feature where you order a resupply for limited amount should have been added.)- NO NEW MAPS! (There's been a lot of reasons given why Eugene hasn't added new maps such as they had to take time from the development to fix bugs and exploits instead . But now they're working on their new game AOA which is taking up all their manpower. What has constantly been requested is a Map Editor or some sort of tools where we the community can make our own maps. The excuses for this not being a thing have been varying and confusing from Eugene not owning the engine the game is made with too maps being too complicated for tools to recreate or something along those lines. Really we have the original maps but having something new to play on would be GREAT at this point)- No Modding Support. (Sure there are a few mods here and there but they're almost unheard of. Some people who have played the game for a long time still don't know their are mods and that mods could even be made for this game. So far there are a fair bit of skins and a few other mods like sandbox but nothing MAJOR grandbreaking like you know.......NEW ♥♥♥♥ING MAPS!!! When Eugene returns to the series they need to seriously think about making the franchise moddable) tl;dr: The game looks good, plays good on land, has ALOT of stuff and resource management but water stuff sucks, multiplayer is jacked for most, NO NEW MAPS and no mod support.Final Rating: 7.5/10  Updated Rating(5/4/2016): 8.5/10Great game but lacks in other areas luckly most of them are non-important. A must buy on sale and a must have for any RTS fan.UPDATE 5/4/2016: I was planning on doing this update to the review MONTHS ago but kept getting side tracked. Anyway the devs have not let us down and updated the game with all new maps FOR FREE! No dlc or microtransactions bull just free updates with new maps. And these were maps of our choosing as well since we had a community vote on it. The maps added new longevity to the game. Now here's hoping Wargame 4 is even better. Updated the rating.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Wargame: Red Dragon will certainly come off a dissapointment to most AirLand Battle players, and while it isn't terrible, there aren't many reasons I could think of to recommend this game over AirLand Battle, especially for its hefty pricetag.To go into detail, let's look at what the game gets right. There is a huge roster expansion, with many new vehicles, factions, and maps. Sadly, most of these new units are reskins of existing ones, but this is true to life, so Eugen deserves some lee-way. The maps are massive and expansive. I am not sure if they are bigger than AirLand Battle, but it sure felt like it. Logistics is more important, as vehicles run out of fuel much quicker and the bigger maps also eat up more fuel. It is an interesting system that adds a dynamic to the game that we haven't seem previously, as going after supply vehicles will actually damage the enemy greatly.Now let us talk about where it goes wrong. Oh, there are so, so many ways this game goes wrong. First and formost is that they screwed up the deck building system. Now, when you make a deck, there are only five open unit slots, where as previous games held all 10 open for use for any deck. The problem is that the game forces you to use specialized decks, but specialization is a bad idea. What if you happen to bring a specialized deck that is vulnerable to the enemy's deck type? Well, you're screwed. The five slots prevent you from making a well-rounded deck. I get they wanted people to have incentive for using specialized decks, but this was not the way to do it. They should provide postive reinforcement for choosing to specialize, like making the bonuses for specialized decks greater (and making their unit restrictions less harsh: many units that certain specializations exclude you from don't even fit into the opposing category, meaning it just removes units for no reason), not by removing stuff that made normal decks good.Balance is all over the ♥♥♥♥ing place. AirLand Battle struck a nice balance, with only the jets being a little overpowered. Now that is flipped on its head. One SAM (or Redfor equivalent) can easily pummel a jet. Sure, anti-air availability has been cut, and so has their ammo, but now planes are weak as♥♥♥♥♥♥and they rarely even reach their traget. They are just a good way of wasting money. Infantry is also useless. Before, putting infantry in buildings was an effective way to ensure that area of the map was basically yours, unless your enemy used specific anti-infantry vehicles to counter. Infantry are now weaker. They die quicker, and their weapons are far less effective against heavy armor. They are, however, cheap. The worst thing is artillery. I don't know what the ♥♥♥♥ went through Eugen's Systems combined heads when they thought of making artillery more destructive. Artillery is supposed to be a support tool used for bogging down and enemy and lowering their morale in preparation for a ground attack, but in Red Dragon they are an offensive tool that can snipe units from across the map and continuously pound just about anything (and I do mean anything) to death. Entrentched infantry? Dead meat. Top-teir armor? Be gone after 3 salvos. Even helicopters can get ruined by these things. It is such an abysmal decision and it ruins a game like this, where arguably balance is everything.Then there are navies. actual, proper ship on ship warfare can be fun, but there really isn't much to it. Whoever has more ships wins. You can spam extremely ♥♥♥♥♥♥, low-level ships, but nothing will get through their output of fire.These changes completely ruin this game and remove any fun from it. It is replaced with frustration, as opponents cheekily snipe you from across the map (including the all-seeing AI) with artillery, amass fleets of♥♥♥♥♥♥teir boats and tear through everything you have, and make the airforce a complete waste of time and money.I thought Red Dragon would be fun because of the new units and setting, but I just got a ♥♥♥♥♥♥, unbalanced version of AirLand Battle that does not do justice to its predecessor. ALB is more well-rounded and balanced, and it is altogether more fun. Don't be tricked by fanboys throwing heaps of praise on this game, and don't waste your money. By ALB or EE.As a sidenote, there is ONE group of people I can recommend this game to. RD has the easiest and most fair AI of all the Wargame titles. That doesn't mean it is easy or fair, it just means it is actually ♥♥♥♥ing beatable. So if you are mostly a singleplayer type of guy, you should probably pick this up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												Wargame: Red Dragon is a tactical war game set in the 1970s to as late as 1985, it can be both enjoyed inSingleplayer and Multiplayer.In Singleplayer, there are 5 campaigns based off real life events back then which the players can immerse in.-Busan Pocket [Player - South Korean]-Bear vs. Dragon [Player - China]-Pearl of the Orient [Player - UK]-Climb Mount Narodnaia-Second Korean War [Player - BLUFOR Forces]Each of those campaigns host a different style and strategy of gameplay which the player must adapt to and stand on the winning platform.The developers weren't lying when they said there were over a 1,000+ units in the game,they can all be found in the 'Deck Create' option in the Main Menu.In Multiplayer, the player can also select from a variety of gameplay modes to play from,- Destruction- Conquest- Siege- Vox PopuliEach of these gamemodes host a different kind of objective, for example, in Destruction mode the player has to destroy a certain amount of units which depletes their "Objective Points" for each kill, let's say that the enemy has 1,000 points. The player must then destroy units which points are equivalent to the number of "Objective Points" that they have.There isn't many flaws in the game and I can say that the game has never once crashed on me or shown me a bug, It's a great game overall, if you don't mind paying $39.00 to play it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												As the third entry to the series, Wargame Red Dragon brings better graphics and a wider selection of units and retains the characteristics that distinguish itself from any other strategy games. I especially like the new coalition system, in which countries that used to be almost irrelevant can come together and form an alliance. For example, the Eastern Bloc consists of East Germany, Poland, and Czechoslovakia, and each one of them hardly stands on its own, yet when put into a coalition they can be every bit as powerful as the USSR or USA. This makes a huge difference in gameplay, as now basically the entire armory can be seen in action, a very much welcome departure from Airland Battle.Naval Battle is indeed lackluster as many reviewers have pointed out. It just doesn't have the strategic and tactical element of the rest of the game. Take a look at the game room lobby and you will see that hardly any player plays naval.As with all strategy games, there are OP units and OP fractions, yet it really still boils down to what a fraction is good at doing and what the battlefield is like. Maximize their advantages and avoid fighting in areas where they are weaker, pay close attention to the maps and you've set yourself up for an exciting military themed RTS.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												Summary:  Great game, and one of the best strategy games on Mac.  If you've ever wanted to command the army of die-cast military figures you played with as a kid, then this is for you.If you're a military buff of any sort, or just love strategy games, this is worth a look.  The amount of detail is incredible.  It's not for everyone.  It has a tough learning curve, and maybe it's just me, but I wish the interface was a little more detailed.  It's definitely heavy on micromanagement, but I've never felt like the game was unfair, just that I wasn't able to keep up.  The campaigns (which I've spent most of my time on) can be brutally difficult (especially the final one), and each one is a bit of a puzzle as you figure out what units to move where.  The ability to speed up or slow down campaign battles is incredibly useful, and a huge improvement over AirLand Battle.I still feel like artillery is a little underpowered, though.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												Probably one of the most interesting games I've ever played. Just the units alone make this game garner my attention. There's 1200+! And the gameplay really is a perfection of the RTS gimic of countering. Every unit has a counter, but some counters are better than others, and it's that split-second decision of not only picking counters, but also attacking and defending, that really gives this game it's charm. However, this game certainly isn't perfect. The naval battles basically consist of spamming as many large boats as you can, which really kind of takes away from the constraint of the land and air battles. The learning curve is pretty steep, which isn't helped by the pretty awful community. There is also a lot of rage-quitting in games, with little to no punisment for it. I love this game very much, and if either updates or a sequel could handle these problems, I would be very pleased.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												One of the greatest modern RTS games of all time, far better than your average RTS. Features realistic combat between various units from Aircraft and Navies to Infantry and APCs. A small tactical mistake such as losing a strategic road intersection can cost you a battle. The game has a difficult learning curb but still is fun to play. Features every major Warsaw Pact and NATO nation such as ANZAC, UK, USA, USSR, West Germany, Japan, Both Koreas, China and several more nations. Each nation has at least 100-250 different units ranging between every kind of human technological innovation in the Cold War such as Jet Fighters, Anti-Aircraft, Modern Tanks, Rocket Artillery, and much more. The only thing this game needs is major Middle East nations that played a large role in the Cold War such as Iran, Iraq, Israel, Turkey, Syria, and Egypt. Otherwise, this game has over 2000 different units combined, intensely realistic combat, requires the player to make complicated tactical and strategic choices in both campaign, singleplayer, and multiplayer. One of the greatest RTS games of all time, if not the best.10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												As the third entry to the series, Wargame Red Dragon brings better graphics and a wider selection of units and retains the characteristics that distinguish itself from any other strategy games. I especially like the new coalition system, in which countries that used to be almost irrelevant can come together and form an alliance. For example, the Eastern Bloc consists of East Germany, Poland, and Czechoslovakia, and each one of them hardly stands on its own, yet when put into a coalition they can be every bit as powerful as the USSR or USA. This makes a huge difference in gameplay, as now basically the entire armory can be seen in action, a very much welcome departure from Airland Battle.Naval Battle is indeed lackluster as many reviewers have pointed out. It just doesn't have the strategic and tactical element of the rest of the game. Take a look at the game room lobby and you will see that hardly any player plays naval.As with all strategy games, there are OP units and OP fractions, yet it really still boils down to what a fraction is good at doing and what the battlefield is like. Maximize their advantages and avoid fighting in areas where they are weaker, pay close attention to the maps and you've set yourself up for an exciting military themed RTS.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												     This is a lengthy review, so if you would rather see the pros and cons, just skip to the bottom.          For those new to the series, Wargame: Red Dragon is the 3rd game in the series. It differs from the first two in that the battles and campaigns take place in Asia, mostly the Korean peninsula, instead of Central and Western Europe. It also differs from the first two in that naval combat is present in this game, but more on that below. Now onto the review.Graphics and Sound     This is first thing most people see when watching the trailer. They don't dissapoint. All three games in the series have amazing graphics, and Red Dragon is no exception. Watch in amazement as dozens of rockets, shells, and rounds pound the enemy and the ground. Craters are left, forest burned down, and entire neighbourhoods destroyed as you fight for control of the strategic sectors scattered around the map. Sounds are also well done. Not only will you see that 500 pound bomb hit the ground, you'll hear it loud and clear. Some explosions can even be heared clear across the map!Campaigns and Skirmish Mode     Singleplayer consists of two game modes: campaigns and skirmish mode. Skirmish mode has stayed the same from the previous games. Not much to say about it, pick your army deck, your enemy, and your map and fight it out. The campaigns are where things have changed. There are currently five campaigns:  Busan Pocket, Bear vs. Dragon, Pearl of the Orient, Climb Mount Narodnaia, and 2nd Korean War(DLC). So far I've tired Bear vs. Dragon and Pearl of the Orient, which are pretty challenging. I've more or less played through Busan Pocket and 2nd Korean War, each of which play well and are pretty balanced.      The main addition to the campaigns is the seperation of units. Unlike Wargame: AirLand Battle where each division had reccon units, tanks, planes, ect., Red Dragon seperates units into armored divisions, infantry divisions and squadrons. I found this an interesting addition, and I think it adds to the game. You'll now have to decide who gets air support, who gets armored units and even who gets proper supply lines. There are drawbacks however. I noticed that there are little or no random events and the strategic options such as commando raids and air reccon arn't present either. While they didn't really affect the campaign overall, I did miss the air reccon.  Naval Battles and Gameplay     For my last trick, I'll talk about the long awaited naval battles! From what I gathered, these were a long awaited addition to the game. Let me just say that if your buying this on account of the naval battles, don't. To be honest, they're harder than the ground battles, and not really in a fun way. If you play as NATO, you'll find yourself massing your fleet of two destroyers and seven PT boats together to avoid the rain of anti-ship missels being thrown at you by the Soviet-Chinease fleet, which is made up of one or two large destroyers, and dozens of light ships. I suppose it could just be me(I didn't really try to conquer the sectors to get more points), but it feels unbalanced. It also felt unrealistic because the larger ships can't fire over obstacles or even very far. If your like me, and your playing this more for the land battles, then you'll enjoy it. The navel aspect means some vehicles can cross rivers, and the PT boats are fun to use on the smaller rivers. Reinforcements can also come by sea in landing craft.     One thing I did notice from all this is the AI has been downgraded a bit from AirLand Battle. I find that the AI is constantly massing units together and rushing me. This usually ends in 90% of the AI's army being destroyed at bridges or other choke points. It did ambush me a few times when I was on the offensive, but overall it seems dumber. Another slightly annoying thing is that when your making custom decks, your now limmited to a certain amount of transports. So if I want to build an airborne army consisting of Huey helicopters, I can only select five units before I have use a different helicopter. Again, It's not a game breaker, but it is a little annoying. I suppose it does challenge you, though, as you'll have to decide who will get the best transports.     So overall, here's what I see:     Pros:        Excellent graphics       Great Sounds       Good campaigns       Lots of new units and new nations       F-86 Sabres with rocket pods!       New naval combat units for you to rule the coastal maps with     Cons        New naval battles a little out of wack       AI seems a little dumber       Deck building a little more complicated       No random events or strategic options     Overall, I've really enjoyed this game, and despite it's few problems, I still reccomend it. It's a good addition to the series and it is a lot of fun. If your on the fence, or still want it for the naval combat, then I'd wait untill it's on sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												If you enjoy real time strategy games, as a commander looking from a top down point of view on a huge map, with cold-war era armies battling it out with each other with amazing firepower and awesome graphics, this is the game for you!Before you start a (non-campaign) game, you have to create your own deck consisting of different units like infantry, tanks, vehicles, helicopters and jets. And in each category there are many choices of units, whether you prefer stronger but more expensive and in lesser amounts or weaker but cheaper and in higher quantity, and even the type of transports that infantry move around in, be it by helicopter or by apc/ifv. With the diversity that this game provides, you would never get tired of reediting your deck after every game to figure out the best combination for you, and that is one of my favourite parts of the game!The gameplay itself is very good, and the AI is always challenging as they will have point advantages over you according to the difficulty you set of them, ensuring that you never get bored and have a challenge in every game. Gameplay is also not linear, there are many ways you can go about engaging your enemy, be it infantry hiding in buildings to ambush oncoming tanks, using tanks  to make long range engagements, or even sending infantry in helicopter transports to make a sneak attack on the enemy base! The usage of jets is also very satisfying, something that you don't usually have in other rts games. The tactics you could use are limitless, it all comes down to your creativity!10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												One of the greatest modern RTS games of all time, far better than your average RTS. Features realistic combat between various units from Aircraft and Navies to Infantry and APCs. A small tactical mistake such as losing a strategic road intersection can cost you a battle. The game has a difficult learning curb but still is fun to play. Features every major Warsaw Pact and NATO nation such as ANZAC, UK, USA, USSR, West Germany, Japan, Both Koreas, China and several more nations. Each nation has at least 100-250 different units ranging between every kind of human technological innovation in the Cold War such as Jet Fighters, Anti-Aircraft, Modern Tanks, Rocket Artillery, and much more. The only thing this game needs is major Middle East nations that played a large role in the Cold War such as Iran, Iraq, Israel, Turkey, Syria, and Egypt. Otherwise, this game has over 2000 different units combined, intensely realistic combat, requires the player to make complicated tactical and strategic choices in both campaign, singleplayer, and multiplayer. One of the greatest RTS games of all time, if not the best.10/10

												Tried of time by time military strategy game ? Then try Wargame Red dragon !! number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												Wargame: Red Dragon is a tactical war game set in the 1970s to as late as 1985, it can be both enjoyed inSingleplayer and Multiplayer.In Singleplayer, there are 5 campaigns based off real life events back then which the players can immerse in.-Busan Pocket [Player - South Korean]-Bear vs. Dragon [Player - China]-Pearl of the Orient [Player - UK]-Climb Mount Narodnaia-Second Korean War [Player - BLUFOR Forces]Each of those campaigns host a different style and strategy of gameplay which the player must adapt to and stand on the winning platform.The developers weren't lying when they said there were over a 1,000+ units in the game,they can all be found in the 'Deck Create' option in the Main Menu.In Multiplayer, the player can also select from a variety of gameplay modes to play from,- Destruction- Conquest- Siege- Vox PopuliEach of these gamemodes host a different kind of objective, for example, in Destruction mode the player has to destroy a certain amount of units which depletes their "Objective Points" for each kill, let's say that the enemy has 1,000 points. The player must then destroy units which points are equivalent to the number of "Objective Points" that they have.There isn't many flaws in the game and I can say that the game has never once crashed on me or shown me a bug, It's a great game overall, if you don't mind paying $39.00 to play it.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												One of the better RTS games I've played. The only other RTS to give me the same rush on multiplayer would be World of Confict. you can feild massive amounts of troops to the battlefeild and if you do not use strategy can still be pushed back. Steamrolling is less susceptable in this game like you would see in company of hereos 2 when facing germans. If your being pushed back use your artillery to pound the land between them and you or if they have a strong defence soften them up with artillary and airstrikes. land marines and vehicles behind their lines, or air assualt infantry into towns to hold the line for a rapid defence. Use destroyers and frigates to pound the coast or smaller ships up rivers to handle pesky amphibious vehicles from sneaking on the other side of the river. The game has a vast arsenal of troops and even after 100+ hours in the game i have not explored all of the different nation's varying units and how to best use them. If your a strategy nut that likes real time over turn based ones this would be a must have for you.Pros: - Very good balanced units between Nato and block forces. you can enter a match and not feel that one side has an advantage over another towards victory. - Having supply lines has always been a nice touch. Dont expect to keep units in a fight for ever. Fuel, ammo, and armor will deterioate over time along with morale. keep them supplied with cargo trucks and cargo helis. -challenging campaigns. -very nice models of vehicles with good accurate weapon names and characteristics. - infantry actually has a role on the battlefeild and wont feel insignificant versus tanks, can do plenty of damage if used properly and are the best units to have when defending parts of the map. in urban environments they are second to none and you'll have to burn them out.Cons: -Ships are lacking somewhat in larger combat classes such as frigates and especially destroyers. No cruisers so don't look. its mostly corvette and smaller style ship warfare using anti-ship missiles enmass.  - AI will always know where your command units are haha, does not matter if they are hidden. They will also artillary strike hidden units that sit in one spot too long even if they have yet to spot them.  - Some balancing is needed in ground based AT missiles still, depending on who you ask the block forces seems to hold an advantage there as many of their tanks are equipped with them. Very good game. I'd give it a 9/10 easily.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												This is without a doubt the best RTS I have ever played. Amazingly detailed campaigns which lead to huge multiplayer battles, from 1v1 to 10v10, battles and maps vary from small skirmishes to huge clashes between superpowers. Over 1400 units from numerous nations from NATO and the Warsaw Pact. Wargame: Red Dragon delivers all the best aspects of RTS, and Eugen Studios has now added Naval Warfare into this amazing franchise. Many maps contain the ability to bring in naval reinforcements, leading to naval landings, combined with tanks battles in the open ground, urban warfare in the towns and villages, special forces raids, all with fighter planes circling over head, shooting each other down, or delivering deadly payloads from cluster bombs to napalm. This is a must-buy for anyone who enjoys RTS, whether that be COmpany of Heroes, the Total War series, or even Civilization, this game tops them all. 10/10!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												Where to start. This is a late review, very late, but with Eugen you cannot write a review at launch, allow me to explain why.This game, at it's base level, is pretty fun, and pretty good, I will not lie. HOWEVER!!!!Eugen, the developers of this game, ever since the first game in the Wargame series came out, have been notorious for wrecking their games with bad "Balance" patches.Red Dragon is no exceptionYou literally cannot get a feel for how to play this game, because every few weeks it seemed Eugen "WAS" (I will explain more on the "Was" in a bit) releasing "Balance" (Read: Not balanced at all) patches. Last week your Radar Anti-Air might have been godly, but this week, it can't hit the broad side of a barn. Your M1A2 tanks might have ruled the field, but the buff to the artillery now makes them big beefy targets, useless, big beefy targets.Imagine, if you will, if a game developer one day, decided to look at it's forums, and released a patch responding to only the chronic whiners on their message boards. Well imagine no more, because that is EXACTLY how Eugen operates. If you have read my review on "War of the Roses", you can see the dark side of when a developer ignores it's game in how Fatshark operates. With Eugen, you have the exact opposite. They listen to the community so much, they cannot "Finish" the game. It changes it's mind more than a bi-polar woman in a shoe store (I know that's sexist, sorry, I could also go the "Bi-Polar Fat Guy at McDonald's" route if you prefer). One week, you finally get the feel for things, everything seems working fine, then squeaky Mc'IOnlyPlayOneArmy 12 year old lays down a lament about how his artillery cannot single handedly win the game for him, this brings along a whole slew of the "I cannot figure out this game so it's unbalanced" crew, aaaaaand....Eugen proceeds to "Fix" the game to help them.And it's never "Fixed", balance swings from NATO to PACT so lopsidedly that instead of realizing what "Balance" means, they fix the OTHER side so hard, it creates an vicious cycle. The last large patch that "Fixed" the Warsaw pact, also "Fixed" a lot of other things. There hasn't been a large patch since, and this was some months ago. (this is why I said "Was") earlier.Needless to say, the game is now pretty much dead compared to what it was Pre-Patch.Soon Eugen will release a "Fix the Scandanavian Nations" patch. So, again, screw all you know about the game because it's a lie. HOWEVER it should be noted, early previews of the patch seem to be rather, well, underwhelming. But the "Balance" that comes with it, should likely wreck the game again, so I will not worry.And the frustrating thing about all of this? I can actually RECOMMEND this game. It's not a BAD game at heart. It's actually a lot of damned fun. It's pretty, easy to get a grasp on, intense, I could go on and on! It's just cool!IF!And I cannot stress this enough, IF, you get a good group of friends to play with. Just like the "Total War" series, you need to find people to play with that you can set ground rules with. "Pubbers" will almost always exploit the broken units, spamming the hell out of you with Jets and Artillery until your eyes bleed. However, the innovative "Deck" system, means you can limit games to certain time frames, army types, ect. ect.And with the right group of people, that can be a blast! There IS strategic depth in this game if you dig deep enough, and set "House Rules" that allow them to shine through. Single Player is a waste, I won't even use up too much space to describe it. Just know, it sucks...bad. It has probably the worst AI I have ever seen. It literally "Cheats" while trying to make you think it isn't. (Such as, enemy AI units will go RIGHT to your hidden units, surround them, but won't engage until they "See" them with Recon) It's like playing with that one♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥in high school, that always INSISTED he WASN'T looking at your screen (In my day we had no internet) but you knew ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ well he was.But reluctantly, I will recommend this game, but as I said, find a good group of friends, set some house rules, and pray Eugen doesn't make you have to recreate all of your decks (Armies). Because, oh yeah, I forgot to mention, their "Updates" constantly make you go back through and recreate the armies you spent so much time putting together.But! Good Luck and have fun!Here is the summary:Pros:PrettyGood, easy to understand GameplayDeck system is awesome!Free DLC!Pretty fun under the right circumstancesCons:*Miserable "Public" play (And a really annoying community, Wargame chat is literally a pool of trolls)*"Fix Patches" often times cause you to have to recreate all of your armies, and often times swing the game's balance so off, that you have to almost relearn how to play.10v10 games, a highlight of this series, are limited by spam, over-powered units, mass player exodus, lack of maps, and terrible performance issues that have still not been resolved.Single Player is useless, seriously, f**k single player....with a wrench...in the♥♥♥♥♥♥Summary:A great game if you have friends! It may ruin friendships sometimes, it's that intense, but still...they'll get over it.If you want to go into this for the Single Player, or you have no friends and want to make some in the community, too bad.  You will never find a more wretched hive of scum and villainy (Outside of Call of Duty).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												Lots of fun. It takes a little time and breaking the mold of normal rts games.Normal rts strategy games. Get the most powerful unit(s) and spam to win right?Not so much with this game. There are over 1500 different units in this game, ranging from infantry, APC's, trucks, supply trucks, tanks, mobile tank hunters, atgm's, helicopters, mobile sam rocket launchers, airplanes, boats, artillery and more. Every unit has a very specific function, whether it is dedicated anti air, or robust like infantry. There is a lot to learn about this game, but the community is helpful to new players learning, and everyone is always ready for a new challenge.Going back to earlier, spam to win. That doesn't work in this game because you need to balance quality with quantity. You normally have to defend many zones, and if you have your best troops in the center (and hoping they dont die) you have nothing to defend against the 30 squads of rangers creeping through the forest, or many you spent your points more wisely, and you have your own militias to counter, but they have better troops. You need to balance your troops and with a little luck, you may survive the charge.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
												Wargame: Red Dragon is hands down one of the best RTS games created in the past 10 years.  If you have a decent graphics card you will notice images that will blow your mind.  Zoom out to see the entire battlefield or zoom in to see the dense foilage and textures on groundhog level.  The variety of units is undeniably spectacular and the gameplay is fantastic.  I wish Eugen would have done a better job at marketing this game to the North American community; because I firmly believe that this would be one of the most popular games played today if they had.  Constant updates and new units to keep the game fresh over time, there are really not enough good things to say about this game.  Absolutley YES I recommend this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												One of the greatest modern RTS games of all time, far better than your average RTS. Features realistic combat between various units from Aircraft and Navies to Infantry and APCs. A small tactical mistake such as losing a strategic road intersection can cost you a battle. The game has a difficult learning curb but still is fun to play. Features every major Warsaw Pact and NATO nation such as ANZAC, UK, USA, USSR, West Germany, Japan, Both Koreas, China and several more nations. Each nation has at least 100-250 different units ranging between every kind of human technological innovation in the Cold War such as Jet Fighters, Anti-Aircraft, Modern Tanks, Rocket Artillery, and much more. The only thing this game needs is major Middle East nations that played a large role in the Cold War such as Iran, Iraq, Israel, Turkey, Syria, and Egypt. Otherwise, this game has over 2000 different units combined, intensely realistic combat, requires the player to make complicated tactical and strategic choices in both campaign, singleplayer, and multiplayer. One of the greatest RTS games of all time, if not the best.10/10

												Learning curve is quite steep compared to other RTS I've played. This is because it is not simply about who has the most of best rated units. It comes down to who uses their deck to the fullest extent. For example in Total War games (one of my favorite RTS) you usually end up with a zerg fight at the end of the battle and huge cluster ♥♥♥♥ of units going at it.You could have the best tanks in the game and ♥♥♥♥ up and walk into a city with infratry waiting to amubush you and lose all your units. Thats what I love about the game is there as actual strategy involved, and you can play it many different ways depending on what type of units you like. In General if you love Cold War Era military tech and wonder what♥♥♥♥♥♥would have been like if NATO and Warsaw pact went to war without nukes, this is the game for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												Summary:  Great game, and one of the best strategy games on Mac.  If you've ever wanted to command the army of die-cast military figures you played with as a kid, then this is for you.If you're a military buff of any sort, or just love strategy games, this is worth a look.  The amount of detail is incredible.  It's not for everyone.  It has a tough learning curve, and maybe it's just me, but I wish the interface was a little more detailed.  It's definitely heavy on micromanagement, but I've never felt like the game was unfair, just that I wasn't able to keep up.  The campaigns (which I've spent most of my time on) can be brutally difficult (especially the final one), and each one is a bit of a puzzle as you figure out what units to move where.  The ability to speed up or slow down campaign battles is incredibly useful, and a huge improvement over AirLand Battle.I still feel like artillery is a little underpowered, though.

												Pretty good game.  Naval matches do need some work, they typically devolve into numbers based slugfests.  Additionally naval units lack some commands that would make them more effective.  This game uses a class system ie. armored, marine, support) with each class having unique units that aren't available to other classes.  In order to be at its best, teams need a blend of classes.  In addition to being able to play as nations, you can also play as coalitions.  For example, you can play as england, ANZAC (Australia and New Zealand), and Canada, or you can play as the Commonwealth that has units form all three.  Overall this is a pretty good game.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												There's three games to the Wargame series, and in my opinion this is the best. A lot of people will disagree with me, and say that the 2nd; Air Land Battle was the best. However, this one here adds a completely new realm to the series; naval combat. I've played the second, and to this, this is much better. Not because of naval combat, but "stuff".The Red Dragon version is just into "stuff". You load up the game in some sort of military command room lit with ominous red lights and given 16,000 units to chose from. Yes. Sixteen thousand! Now, a lot of the units are just different units with different weapons, but I'd say 75% of them are completely modeled, textured, for their roll. Now, the issue I had when I loaded this up was to understand the difference between a "USA Marine Stinger" and a "USA Marine Igla" was. The two weapons are anti-air, have the same strength and so on. And you'll realize how confusing it is when you are juggling tons of units.The game play is completely different to all other RTS. You really need to coordinate with your team. Tell them to flank here or there, smoke a certain position to cover retreating units, send recon helicopters behind enemy lines near a mountain top and spot what ever they're doing. Don't expect to walk into a game and win. You'll either lose the ones you play, or just be carried by some amazing commander. The Campaign is lack luster. Not amazing. It's good for starting out, mainly for practice. But I would rather do skirmish battles. They're a little more fun, and you have more freedom. There isn't even a story so to speek. Would I reccomend this? Yes. It's a great game. I don't have much hours because I don't really have someone I can trust in a battle to protect me from getting flanked. And that's an issue you'll run into. Many unskilled players. So you either learn quickly, or dominate the other team.I'd get this if you want a change to most generic military RTS's out there. Just get ready for the incredable learning curve this game offers.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												When I first played this game it confused the crap out of me...  I didn't understand it, and thought it would explain itself as I played the campaign...  Little help did that do...  I then started playing skrimish matches, trying to understand this game.  Later did I find out what the deck really was, then as I played more and more and experimented with more and more the more I began to understand this game.Now that I know the weapon types, skill, level, and tactics to use, I know quite a bit about this game now...  now no I'm still not a stratigic Master, however the more and more I play with others and find their strategies, the more and more I begin to know.  Now I still consider myself a noob at this game, but the more I understand it, the more I find out about how to do things...So about the game, let me tell it to you like this... It is kind of like chess, however the peices have already been set up by you and your opponent, and another thing... you don't know where they set theirs up at and they don't know where you set yours, now,  once you find the peice and thing you want to make a capture with your peice that is already in position... you have to consider if there are other peices out there they can use to take your peice you just used, or if you have peices that you think they can't see in position ready to help that peice once captured...  So take it like a mix of chess and battleship...  you don't know where they are, but when you find them how will they react to your attack, or defenceI give this game a 7/10 and recommend it to anyone who likes real time strategy on the battlefield that you can control a bunch opf units at one time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
												Wargame is a very cool game. It makes me come back to play it even if I lose most of the time. Pro:+ The game is esthetically pleasing and very detailed.In the game you can see the entire theatre of war from above and get a perfect view of the overall progression of the battle. Or you zoom in to the grunts seeing them assaulting, devastating and dying with flamethrowers, cluster bombs, mortars etc.It looks just like in the trailer.+AVAILABLE NUMBER OF UNITSI guess they have about 1500 units in this game. Each one beautifully detailed with their own country typical weapons and decals. This is concerning the land armies. The naval units are not typical to every nation. There are Russian and Chinese and American typical units. This might also be due to the fact that small nations don't have the money to develop their own warships. Anyway, 1500 units is good to me. I have to admit that there are also a lot of units that are just copies from other nations with another decal. An example for this is the leopard tank. It's a solid unit and that's why you can find it in nearly every NATO nation’s army. But even this tank has sometimes different stats depending on the nation.+ Air to Air and Air to Ground and Air to Ship combat is the best simulated one I know in a strategy game. It's very nice and a plus to the game since air land battle.+ONLINE BATTLESOnline battles are the bread and the butter of the game. So you will end up playing against other players most of the time. It is definitely a solid gameplay. I have to say it is hard for beginners so you better invest time to get to know your units. Which is kind of a draw back if you just wanna jump on the online game and defeat others like nothing? This is not what is going to happen. You will lose a lot of times before you win. This is because the game has a lot depth due to its huge number of available units. My mind set on playing online changed from "I want to win the game" to "I want to give the enemy a run for their money". + UNIT SELECTIONThe selection of the units is a really based on a really good system. You have lets say 55 points to put units into your unit card deck. A unit card deck defines the amount and kind of units you're leading into battle. You can increase these points to get more cards. So you can deploy more units or you invest points to get better units but less of them. You can also specialise your deck to lets say airborne. This means you have all good fighters, choppers plus Arial prototype units available but you are badly equipped with ground units. This system enables role play for you and your friends and is fun on the battlefield. It also forces army variation. BUGS:- When you zoom in to a place on the map where a battle was commenced, there is a graphic bug at times. The craters of the bombs appear above the ground and not in the ground. Single Player:- The single player is a complete different experience to the online game. With different I mean it is weaker. You have a strategy map with a lot of territories (maps) to fight on, which is good and a nice Idea because this way a campaign is fought on maps according to your decisions. This is a nice idea, BUT there are always some strategic more valuable territories to play on then others. This results in playing over and over again on the same map. The Idea is nice but it's not well thought through. - On top of this is the AI. It's not clever and in my opinion it didn't get better over the series. After 3 games you know what it is after and you can adjust yourself to it. The only challenge is the number of troops that are thrown at you. - Presentation of the single player got weaker with the series progression. Meaning it was the best in Wargame European Escalation and it's the weakest in Red Dragon in my opinion. Air Land Battle isn't a far cry from Red Dragon so you decide which one is worse. :)What exactly is weaker on the presentation?:In European escalation you have an introducing video after each mission played. It's not much but it's better than a screenshot show or some artwork colleagues who tell you what to do. This is what you can expect in Wargame red Dragon, cartoon colleagues with speech bubbles. In total I would say the single player is a tutorial to get you ready for the real deal, the online matches.- The Ship battles are boring. Let's sum it up to "The player with the biggest host of naval units wins." That’s it.BAD THINGS IN ONLINE PLAY:ARTY SPAM:A lot of people use artillery spam. This is pointless in my view because everybody can do this and it only drains resources of your team. It doesn't kill a lot of enemies; it stuns them at best and kills some infantry and light vehicles. But in the end it's just over used.PEOPLE WITH NO BALLS:If you join a game 10 vs. 10 Players you wait at first ages until the lobby is full and the game can begin. As soon as you are on the battlefield and start playing you can be sure somebody left the lobby already. Or and this is when it comes to the low number of balls. People leave the game when the see that there team isn't doing so well. This in turn makes the game short since if people leave the remaining people have to manage additional units left from the gone player. Micro mgmt. becomes a pain and you know you can't win since the enemy team has more players to manage their troops. GAME ENCOURAGES PEOPLE TO LEAVE ONLINE MATCHESThe best thing is that the game encourages players to leave a game. Since there is a game mod that counts the number and the value of the units you lost and destroyed. If you are the last player on the map because you're a man that fights to the last man you get punished on the statistics. Because you are the one who lost the most units. It's just natural that the last player left loses the most units. So statistically wise the one player that was the best one because he didn't leave is the worst one.So this is it about my review. I hope it helped you to get an Idea about that game and if you will give it a try or not. And my personal thump up to you if you did read the entire thing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												One of the better RTS games I've played. The only other RTS to give me the same rush on multiplayer would be World of Confict. you can feild massive amounts of troops to the battlefeild and if you do not use strategy can still be pushed back. Steamrolling is less susceptable in this game like you would see in company of hereos 2 when facing germans. If your being pushed back use your artillery to pound the land between them and you or if they have a strong defence soften them up with artillary and airstrikes. land marines and vehicles behind their lines, or air assualt infantry into towns to hold the line for a rapid defence. Use destroyers and frigates to pound the coast or smaller ships up rivers to handle pesky amphibious vehicles from sneaking on the other side of the river. The game has a vast arsenal of troops and even after 100+ hours in the game i have not explored all of the different nation's varying units and how to best use them. If your a strategy nut that likes real time over turn based ones this would be a must have for you.Pros: - Very good balanced units between Nato and block forces. you can enter a match and not feel that one side has an advantage over another towards victory. - Having supply lines has always been a nice touch. Dont expect to keep units in a fight for ever. Fuel, ammo, and armor will deterioate over time along with morale. keep them supplied with cargo trucks and cargo helis. -challenging campaigns. -very nice models of vehicles with good accurate weapon names and characteristics. - infantry actually has a role on the battlefeild and wont feel insignificant versus tanks, can do plenty of damage if used properly and are the best units to have when defending parts of the map. in urban environments they are second to none and you'll have to burn them out.Cons: -Ships are lacking somewhat in larger combat classes such as frigates and especially destroyers. No cruisers so don't look. its mostly corvette and smaller style ship warfare using anti-ship missiles enmass.  - AI will always know where your command units are haha, does not matter if they are hidden. They will also artillary strike hidden units that sit in one spot too long even if they have yet to spot them.  - Some balancing is needed in ground based AT missiles still, depending on who you ask the block forces seems to hold an advantage there as many of their tanks are equipped with them. Very good game. I'd give it a 9/10 easily.

												Alright, so you like RTS games and you're looking for a great one. Let me tell you, you've found it.The newest iteration in the series is great, and even though the new naval combat isn't as great as expected by fans of the franchise, the game itself is an amazing RTS,The only major complaint that that one may have is the steep learning curve: learning all the unit types, how they counter each other, how some are better than others and what strategies to use can be overwhelming to many new players. Because of this and the fact that the game is 100x better when you play with other people, I seriously encourage you to check out the  Wargame Subreddit and its Teamspeak server (Teamspeak address: 92.222.252.202:9990), as all the mods and mentors there will help you learn the game.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												Massive improvement over Airland Battle, in nearly all aspects - from general gameplay like micro and macro management, to graphics and visuals. The new maps feature much more varied terrain than the previous game(s) and you'll need to think your tactics through with the specific terrain of each map in mind. The number of units nearly doubled, with new factions being added, and the existing factions getting some extra units, since the timeline has been extended to the mid '90s. The size of fielded forces in a deck has also increased, considering the somewhat larger maps and need to prepare for all types of confrontations (land, sea, air), or to further specialize with thematic decks (marine, motorized, airborne, etc.)Best part, though is that you can play as Best Korea. 10/10 GOTY.Edited later: Now they have Israel and Yugoslavia is only a few days away. The world's best kebab removal duo is in the gamme. How can you NOT want to play this?
