content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												(Detailed Pros and Cons at the bottom)First off, So you disregard all of those bad reviews about software problems. I havent had a single crash yet. You may want to reinstall or check something that is wrong with your computer maybe you dont have the required hardware...idk, but I can tell you dont reject this because because of those reviews.Now This is a HUGE RTS with like many people are saying has a huge learning curve. You'll get the hang of it pretty easy but you will spend many months if you wish to master it. Maybe even years. I got this game at the beginning of this week and I already have 48 hours (Ive been sick, thank god i had this game.) This game honestly reminds me a lot of Close Combat:A Bridge to Far but in a larger scale. I Recommand this game to anyone that loves RTS, Military tactical game, Master a game and not take a day. I honestly wasnt going to get this game, until I saw a bunch of my friends get it. I was going to ask if it was worth getting it but I had 30 mins left for it to be on sale so I had no time to ask so I brought it and Im glad i did.Pros:Campaigns: You have multiple campaigns with extra features then multiplayer. You control entire warsOver 1000 Units: Overwhelming but great to see the amount of stuff they put into this gameDeck Building and Customization: You'll never see another player have the same deck. Unless you copy theirs.Environment: Detail is amazing. Zoom in til your in the middle of streets while a battle rages, or zoom out into mapMultiplayer: Great for playing with friends, thats all i do. Its a great feeling when you out do someone in this game.Master: Learn from your mistakes, watch replays, edit your army, fix your strategy, Win or Repeat. No easy COD killsMirco Managing: To master you need to mirco manage, It not that the Units are dumb as some reviews said. Its more you need to do alil more work if you want your units where you want. I understand this could be a Con to some people.Cons:Tutorial: This has to be #1 because yes it has a "tutorial" but its start up reading. There is no playable tutorial which really sucked. If you have the time, youll learn from playing...single player, multiplayer, even ask me...I'll tell you what I know. If you have the time read the "tutorial" because it has a lot of useful info. Its a lot of reading tho.Gamemodes: Just 3, could easily add more for this kind of game. 1 of which 90% of the community play.AI: The AI is dumb sometimes when it come to the gamemode. They are more trying to kill you then doing the objective.If you like games that you figure out and be good right away this game isnt for you. There is just far too much stuff to learn you'll never learn everything. It's i think 40$, I got it on sale. Would I recommand this game for full price. Yes but ONLY if your a HARDCORE RTS player and your friends all had it and played everyday. If not but you still want it then you can maybe wait for it to go on sale again. I dont buy anything full price so. Anyway hope you get it, hope you enjoy, message me if you have any questions or wanta play. My friends and I welcome everyone and we enjoy helping players out.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												I have to admit, Wargame is something that requires patience, a high toleration of frustration and even more practice to master, but once you got to a point where you understand what to do and what not, it is pretty amazing.It requires so much micromanagement to successfully overwhelm your enemy (assuming he's human, that is) that you won't even have time to grab a sip of coffee. It really teaches you to actually read the description of a unit and use common sense. Spamming 20 Tanks will cause your enemy to either ambush them with AT Infantry or call in an airstrike - and you can kiss these tanks goodbye.In StarCraft or CnC, it wouldn't matter - but here? If your Leopard is gone, it's gone. The crew is dead, the vehicle destroyed, and they won't come back.Sometimes, you feel so desperate but turn it around, sometimes you are so full of yourself that a single mistake will cause the deaths of all of your soldiers.If you want complex action and a lot of stuff to learn, Wargame is for you.If you want quick skirmishes with brainless rushes, play CnC or StarCraft (not saying either of the two is bad!).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												Very high learning curve, a lot to manage and figure out... but totally worth it. It's like World in Conflict on crack. Many of the same concepts as World in Conflict also exist here, but significantly more fleshed out, technical, and realistic. The generic unit archetypes of WiC are replaced by meticulously-modelled real-world military hardware from the latter half of the 20th century, but have fairly easy to understand stats and weapons. There is also a huge wealth of nations and their respective hardware. While obviously the majority of the hardware is Soviet or American, the other major nations of the 20th century are all well-represented with a mix of their own weapons and imports from the superpowers.Once you start to learn the intricacies of the game, it becomes a lot of fun, further amplified by the deck-building system which lets you create your own custom battle force. You can specialize in air power, tanks, infantry, and all other manner of battalion-level formations. Similarly, you can play generic NATO or Warsaw, or specific nations with access to those nations' newest top-of-the-line hardware.Very intricate, very fun.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												Could you imagine what would happen if Cold War becomes hot? Well you don't have to, just play Wargame. In the whole Wargame series (European escalation, Airland battle and Red dragon) you can see many different scenarios that were very possible just 25 years ago. Whats more units are very realistic and you have to know pros and cons of them. For example even well camouflaged  old T-34 can be lethal for M1 Abrams or well used Swedish reservists can stop soviet paratroopers. Pros+a lot of different, realistic units+interesting scenarios+really nice multiplayer+ability to create your own decks to make your army more suitable to your tactics+free DLCsCons-there are no all Warsaw Pact countries like Romania or Hungary (I can't find other disadvantages)In conclusion, if you like RTS games you should buy it.

content:
Posted: January 13
												This is my first RTS purchased on Steam and it's certainly going to be my last because no RTS compares to Wargame: Red Dragon in terms of depth, eye candy, difficulty, realism and entertainment!I don't even need to entail why. Look gameplay footage of this game. Now compare that to spamming bunch of units of one type in a tight cluster attacking another set of units in a tight cluster with a 5 inch distance between the two groups like you see in other RTS's. Case closed.If you're a scrub-weakling like me then I hope you have a lot of patience and love for the game element because this game is ABSOLUTELY ruthless and you really have to dig across the internet to get every bit of knowledge needed just to figure out what to do. Then comes execution and I find this game challenges your micromanaging abilities but not so much that it's Starcraft AZN APM or die level. It's just that you need both to do well.I still recommend this game to beginners because there are valid alternatives via doing comp stomps (You and rl people versus the AI), Single-Player Skirmish Mode or just simply finding a weaker player than you. Just note that you should pursue 1v1's instead because 10v10's diminish your ability to influence games. Plus, all RTS's are a pain to learn so really seeking easier RTS to get gud at will still leave you feeling frustrated, especially since this is the BEST RTS ever in terms of realism, graphics and gameplay YET YOU DON'T OWN IT because you're still playing Battle of Toontow...err I mean RA 3.Expert RTS'ers should buy this because I'm obviously qualified to tell you so. Really though, I'm not a expert RTS'er so I'm in the dark about everything.Watching replays is quite a satori though. Especially if you're a beginner and you win you first match and it's well executed.Also qualifies as a educational game. Good for the children to teach or just those who like learning new things about real life military equipment and outfits.Community is toxic. Much worse than the World of Tanks community from my experience.Tl:Dr: Best RTS ever with the same hard af learning curve. Good for beginners because all RTS'es are hard to learn either way and might as well pick up a S tier RTS. Extreme challenge with extreme rewards.10/10PS: Dark Souls of RTS games?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												I wanted to love this game.  It had so much going for it - it was following up on two really good games, it had improved on some of the weaknesses of the older games.  It was going to have a naval component.It turned out to be much too ambitious.  The naval aspect was a question of who could spam more anti-ship missiles, there were few ships to chose from, and Eugen didnt even bother to add engine noise.   The single player campaigns are boring - a war across the most heavily defended border in the world comes across as a slap-fight.  There isnt much in the way of policing the multi - so expect TKs, nazis, racists, name calling.  You know, everything that's wrong with online gaming.This could be forgiven, if it werent for Eugen's policy of Nerf-or-Nothin' - every few months, we'd get an 'update' which radically changed the specs on the game's units - what you could buy, how strong they were, etc.  It was maddening - and not new - they did the same thing with Wargame ALB.Even THAT could be forgiven, if the game werent so unstable.  Stuttering is commonplace, CTD is commonplace.  Stuttering that turns to locking is commonplace.  Sometimes giving RD the three-fingered salute doesnt kill it - I discovered the game was still running in the background after last crash, despite having closed it in Manager.  Why is my GPU running at 70C at rest?  Oh, RD is still running.I really wanted to like this game.  There was so much potential.  But Eugen should have gone with its first thought, and just released it as a DLC.-DonEDIT:9/28/16Hey, look, they released the Low Countries for money.  Yeah, well, I'm not gonna spend more money .... uh...where are my aircraft?  You released a DLC - that I dont even own - that still screwed up my decks?  Not all of them, just most, so if I want to play the game I've got to go through the lot, figure out which ones are now missing their aircraft, and re-add them.  Oh, and you've done it for naval aircraft too!  Hey, so now I have a second round of going though and re-adding - not all my decks, just some - just to make it that much more of a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥  Thanks, Eugen, you'll never see another dime of my money.EDIT:10/4/16  You ♥♥♥♥ing♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥  You ♥♥♥♥ing did it again.  Now none of the units which had the stealth fighter have it.  Stuff is missing from the Soviet decks.  You ♥♥♥♥ing incompetent ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.  A professional company would have made changes when the DLC was bought.  A great company would give the DLC to its loyal customers.  Remeber doing that?  Remember how great we thought you were when you added stuff to ALB free of charge?  Really made me eager to buy your next product. Under new management, I guess. ♥♥♥♥♥♥heads.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												This is not a game for me.  I can't beat an equally-supplied A.I. on the same map.  Maybe I expected my minimal RTS skills to translate better to Red Dragon, but it's plainly obvious they don't.Wargame: Red Dragon is worth trying out.  If you're a strategy buff and love the Cold War era and the years just after them, you'll get a kick of nostalgia out of this game.  The dizzying array of units to choose from is enough to keep you occupied for thousands of hours.  Game runs smoothly, player base is active, sounds are satisfactory, music a little repetitive, and pathing is fair enough.  You will remain a noob for many scores of hours if you're totally new to the Wargame franchise.  I can't say whether that should dishearten or encourage you.  It's a steep learning curve, but one worth testing regardless.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
												Wargame Red dragon puts you in command of a massive arsenal of cold war weaponry allowing you to out think your opponent and counter him before he can counter back. The thriving community and chat alone contribute so much to this game and make it even better than similar games. When I first started I sucked, and you will probably also suck to begin with. I mean I doubt you will memorize all 1400 units before playing your first multiplayer match, if you do then you are awesome. But my first few matches were fun and they still are now that i am no longer a novice. Even though I lost I still had fun, and you know a game is doing somthing right when even losing is fun. This game has tremendous replay potental in the Multiplayer though the campaign doesn't have the best AI. No two games will ever have be the same because of unit diversity. I reccomend reading Sandy Gunfoxes 200 page guide here on steam or in google docs if you are new to the seris to help familiarize you with the basics and unlearn conventional RTS strategies and adopt real world tactics which this game relies on. This game is amazing, and if you get bored of the game (which I doubt will happen anytime soon) you can sit in chat and talk about all sorts of things from the F-35 fighter jet to the Syrian crisis with the community. This game should be owned by anyone who loves military strategy and/or history. 10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												This is not a game for me.  I can't beat an equally-supplied A.I. on the same map.  Maybe I expected my minimal RTS skills to translate better to Red Dragon, but it's plainly obvious they don't.Wargame: Red Dragon is worth trying out.  If you're a strategy buff and love the Cold War era and the years just after them, you'll get a kick of nostalgia out of this game.  The dizzying array of units to choose from is enough to keep you occupied for thousands of hours.  Game runs smoothly, player base is active, sounds are satisfactory, music a little repetitive, and pathing is fair enough.  You will remain a noob for many scores of hours if you're totally new to the Wargame franchise.  I can't say whether that should dishearten or encourage you.  It's a steep learning curve, but one worth testing regardless.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												I wanted to love this game.  It had so much going for it - it was following up on two really good games, it had improved on some of the weaknesses of the older games.  It was going to have a naval component.It turned out to be much too ambitious.  The naval aspect was a question of who could spam more anti-ship missiles, there were few ships to chose from, and Eugen didnt even bother to add engine noise.   The single player campaigns are boring - a war across the most heavily defended border in the world comes across as a slap-fight.  There isnt much in the way of policing the multi - so expect TKs, nazis, racists, name calling.  You know, everything that's wrong with online gaming.This could be forgiven, if it werent for Eugen's policy of Nerf-or-Nothin' - every few months, we'd get an 'update' which radically changed the specs on the game's units - what you could buy, how strong they were, etc.  It was maddening - and not new - they did the same thing with Wargame ALB.Even THAT could be forgiven, if the game werent so unstable.  Stuttering is commonplace, CTD is commonplace.  Stuttering that turns to locking is commonplace.  Sometimes giving RD the three-fingered salute doesnt kill it - I discovered the game was still running in the background after last crash, despite having closed it in Manager.  Why is my GPU running at 70C at rest?  Oh, RD is still running.I really wanted to like this game.  There was so much potential.  But Eugen should have gone with its first thought, and just released it as a DLC.-DonEDIT:9/28/16Hey, look, they released the Low Countries for money.  Yeah, well, I'm not gonna spend more money .... uh...where are my aircraft?  You released a DLC - that I dont even own - that still screwed up my decks?  Not all of them, just most, so if I want to play the game I've got to go through the lot, figure out which ones are now missing their aircraft, and re-add them.  Oh, and you've done it for naval aircraft too!  Hey, so now I have a second round of going though and re-adding - not all my decks, just some - just to make it that much more of a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥  Thanks, Eugen, you'll never see another dime of my money.EDIT:10/4/16  You ♥♥♥♥ing♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥  You ♥♥♥♥ing did it again.  Now none of the units which had the stealth fighter have it.  Stuff is missing from the Soviet decks.  You ♥♥♥♥ing incompetent ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.  A professional company would have made changes when the DLC was bought.  A great company would give the DLC to its loyal customers.  Remeber doing that?  Remember how great we thought you were when you added stuff to ALB free of charge?  Really made me eager to buy your next product. Under new management, I guess. ♥♥♥♥♥♥heads.

												The third Wargame... game takes you to East Asia and lets you slaughter hordes of crappy Chinese and North Korean military units. It also added ships and small-scale naval battles. Those are not quite as good as the land battles, but thankfully there's still plenty of land-fighting action to be had.The single-player campaigns are better done than what was in ALB by having a proper story structure and events, but it suffers from repetition as you fight on the same battle maps constantly since the enemy keeps attackin and you keep making them die horribly. Also there's multiplayer. I'm sure that's fine too, but truthfully I never really felt like playing it because how I play this game seems much better suited for singleplayer. I guess that means I am a dummy. :(Anyway, this game is pretty good. Have fun! ^_^

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												Pros: Challenging but rewarding. Extremely detailed graphics and units. Red Dragon seamlessly integrates air and sea combat into the foundation laid by European Escalation. You will lose days of your life, because the game will engross you. Like, seriously, pack a lunch if you plan on playing a match, because it's going to last a while (I love that). The only Cold War force missing is Cuba, and knowing Eugen, it's probably in the works.Cons: Lack of depth in naval units; the game only has twenty or so naval units out of maybe two or three hundred, but it leads you to believe there are more. Wish there was, frankly. There is a learning curve and it is steep; the game is unforgiving, and if you make a mistake you *will* pay for it. The game could use some video tutorials. As an addendum to that last, it's in game tutorials are woefully inadequate. There's a feeling that the developer expects you to muddle through, and this game is not forgiving enough for that. If Starcraft I/II are go fish, Red Dragon is a world championship chess match. Red Dragon is if anything more forgiving than it's predecessors, but it is definitely not easy to just pick up and play.TL;DNR (?): This game isn't for everyone, but if you're looking for beautiful graphics, glorious depth, realism, and a challenge, I highly commend it. If you just want simple RTS to play casually, RUN AWAY FOR THE LOVE OF ALL THAT IS HOLY. That said? Omigyad I love this game.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2014
												The best installment of the series IMHO. Highly recommended for anyone who is interested in intricate RTS games and military technology!An in-depth, somewhat realistic approach to modern warfare, with a relatively steep learning curve and a micro management intensive gameplay that will keep you pinned to the computer for hours. (Or scare you away, but do not be afraid! It is truly worth your patience).I absolutely love it. Make a deck/army to use out of more than a thousand units, different infantry sections and vehicle variants and then carefully manage your Leopard tank to rock Soviet armour... or set up an ambush with infantry waiting for the enemy vehicles to pass, just to active RPGs, when they can fire a devastating sideshot into weak parts of enemy armour.... there are lots of such tactical possibilites, thanks to the well thought-out combat system.This is not a rock-paper-scissor game like Starcraft. Just like in real life, every gun matters if properly used... no matter how elite your infantry is, it will get mowed down by the cheapest LMG on open ground, if you are not managing it properly and utilise cover and so aswell, the mightiest MBT can fall to auto cannon fire, should an IFV manage to sneak behind it.Truly a very enjoyable mix of reality and gameplay-balance decisions. I am sure everyone can find his way to fight in this game, especially in gigantic battles with 20 players, where everyone counts.Not to mention the absolutely stunning video engine, bringing great scaling and visuals, while retaining a good performance.A great game for every wholehearted strategy fan.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												This. F***ing. Game. Seriously one of the best RTS out there. It is really on a whole nother level than the COH series, or any rts for that matter. The attention to detail in the units is stunning (more talking about their armaments and pros/cons, but the renders are nice too) a good amount of effects found in combat are modeled in game, including morale, being stunned, failure of different systems if they are hit (firing computer reset, gearbox hit, ammo sorage hit (BOOM) etc). Word to the wise though. This is not your sit down, hop on, crush people. The learning curve is steep with this one. If you dont have some semblence of an idea of what type of armor is rolling down the road towards you, chances are theyre going to roll right through whatever you have if not equipped properly. Wargame: Red Dragon is easily the best RTS out there in my opinion.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												First of all: This is a love or hate title. The learning curve is quite steep and you will get smacked in the multiplayer for the first 10 hours (don't buy this game if you want to play against AI - it's horrible). But that is why I love this game: It took me forever to get used to all the hidden mechanics. I am biased in a way due to over a thousand hours played, but I genuinly believe that it is the most refined, in-depth depiction of a cold war gone hot. If your are into complex, challenging RTS set in the cold war, this is basically the only game available to you. Give it a try when it's on sale again.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												The Wargame series is a visually impressive quasi modern day RTS. The focus is on unit command instead of base building or economic development. I'm personally a fan of games that move away from the building RTS genre. Notable games such as the Ground Control and Total War series come to mind. If you enjoyed those games and also have an interest in modern day combat, I would highly recommend the Wargame series. Specifically to Red Dragon, it is clear this is the latest iteration of the series as the amount of content is truly impressive. The multiplayer experience is excellent in custom created games, however it is lacking certain aspects. As opposed to AirLand Battle there is currently no co op campaign. There is also a fundamental flaw regarding skirmishes in multiplayer verse the AI, there is a high occurance of dsync. If you enjoy regiment size or larger command games this game should be on your list.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												Ok, first note: this game is first and foremost a multiplayer game. To enter the MP may feel difficult in the beginning, but once you're in it's great fun! My advice for newer players: go look at some YT videos, although Razzman may be the best in the game, I'd advice stealth17 even more as he is more focussed at learning new players stuff. He also has rookie nights so I'd have a look at that. Besides that: just ask for some help, but not at the ingame wargame chat! (that chat is ****) You can comment on certain videos, or go to the forums, the wargane reddit page etc. Just ask for tips and tricks, and maybe there is someone willing to learn you a thing or two personally. All in all a great game, but you have to be willing to 1: keep learning and 2: be willing to learn from your defeats as well. With the good mindset you can have many hours of fun in this game!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												Pros: - Tons of content and free DLC (aside from the newest DLC, which is $6)- The variety of maps and units keeps the game fun and interesting even with 480hrs of play time. - Incredible detail just in general. - Campaign is fun and can be challenging. Cons:- Match-making is awful. Most sessions are either in-game, setting up, or debriefing. Of the few that are open, most are nearly empty (you'd wait forever for the required number of players to join and the game to begin). Of the handful of games that have a decent amount of people in the lobby, most of those are almost always on the same 3 or 4 maps. - Players leave the match as soon as their team starts losing since there are no repercussions for doing so. - The units of the players that leave are given to another player. If half the team leaves, a single player can have half of their team's units. It's too much for anyone to handle, so guess what? they leave too.- A single person with a bad connection can slow the entire match down for everyone else.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
												All in all, Wargame as a series trumps the RTS genera in my opinion. The game has a steep learning curve but, it's well worth the effort, probably one of the most realist RTS game out there and by far the most encompassing as far as tactics are concerned.      The community can be VERY toxic and of little help but on occasion you run into some nice folks from time to time. Red Dragons Campaign is abysmal and far to complex for what it is and as there was in Air-Land Battle there is no Cooperative play in Campaign mode in Red Dragon.  i give Red dragon A 7 out of 10....If you like HARD CORE Real Time strategy game, this one if for you... if you don't, move along.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2014
												Wargame is back! This time though, You won't be shelling German towns or sneaking in Scandinavian forests, You'll be burning poor asian women and children with napalm one more time! Thats right, The Wargame Theatre of War is now Asia!The game controls the same as EE and AirLand, but the folks at Eugen have added another layer of tactical micromanagement- Sea battles. The units never cease to amaze me how one second I can be applauding their perfect executions of my plans... To wondering how such braindead soldiers even understand the concept of breathing.Nevertheless, The game still proves it is fun, challenging and intellegent even if it feels like AirLand battle with the prototype date pushed back to '95. The addition of the new counties is always welcome, and Japan, China, North and South Korea, and Australia fit perfectly in the numerous factions. The addition of coalitions and the reworking of deck types makes building and customizing decks an extremly fun pass time.But newcomers to series be warned: THIS GAME HAS A LEARNING CURVE THAT RIVALS EVE. That's right, don't expect to drop in and beginning distributing letal doses of freedom, and the tutorials aren't worth jackshit. Still, If you got the balls and are willing to sick it out, the game is immensely fun and satisfying.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2014
												Excellent game here, which distinguishes itself from most RTS by forcing the player to apply actual military common sense to the battle rather than gamey common sense. No Action Per Minute contest or mathematically calculated rushes of a single unit to kill the other side. Learning the Art Of War in this game can be tough, but is also rewarding as hell, as outthinking the enemy will allow you to crush even the mightiest armored push.The game is, in itself, really beautiful on the graphical side, and though the musics are not exceptional, they do their job correctly. The balancing might be disputed by some (usually the new players who think their favourite nation should crush everyone), but the fact is that BLUE and RED have the same amount of victories in multi, according to the released data.If you want to see a game with more than a thousand different units, with each faction having its own character and way of waging war, if you want to play something that favours actual planning and competence rather than mechanical application of drilled builds and rushes, Red Dragon is for you.Oh, and Eugen will release free DLC in the upcoming weeks and months. ;-)

That's right, don't expect to drop in and beginning distributing letal doses of freedom, and the tutorials aren't worth jackshit. Still, If you got the balls and are willing to sick it out, the game is immensely fun and satisfying.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2014
												One of the best RTS I have played in a long time, and possible the best rts with a modern combat theme. It has most of the major element's from modern combat, including navies, tanks, armored vehicles, light vehicles, infantry, helicopters, airplanes, artillery, missile launcher and so on. You get to customize your armies for online battles and ai-skirmishes with units from a wide range of countries like, USA, Britan, China, Russia, north korea, japan, norway and more. The game seem to have a fairly decent root in reality when it comes to realism, altough it is as every game still far away from the real deal.The game also features a turn based/RTS hybrid "campaign", that is more or less the equivalent to scenarios in different strategy games, but still alot of fun to play. Overall the game possess very good graphic's, but still run on low end systems, such as my laptop.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2014
												This is an RTSers dream first and foremost. This is not Star Craft, Age of Empires or any other "I click faster than you thus I win" kind of game. This is a game that puts you in the commanders seat behind a brigade size modern military element and tasks you with anihilating the enemy with customized warfighting capabilities tailored by your playstyle and tactics. The gameplay is non-stop heart pounding modern war that showcases not only an incredible array of real military units; but also an engine that makes the combat realistic. There is a solid modding community that is ever expanding on their home site for making the game into whatever your skillset is able, but I truly cannot speak highly enough about this game. I am a veteran of the RTS genre; CoH, CoHII, Supreme Commander (all), SC, SC II, AoEII, Rome, Medievall, Shogun Total war, but for this genre and time period NO OTHER GAME TOUCHES IT. Buy it....plain and simple you won't regret it. In fact the only thing you might regret is your lack of TRUE strategic skill as this game will test you and punish you, but that makes victory all the more satisfying.

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												DISCLAIMER: This review is mostly based on singleplayer/Co-op gameplay of the game.This review will likely receive a hard time from overawed fanboys that think they know what is going on in the world and know how it feels like to execute a near modern field battle.-Toxic chat. The global chat is filled with know-it-all show offs that try to impress others by speaking about politics as if they were experts. Most people using the chat are these show offs. Then there are those that are simply trying to persuade others to join their matches, which are completely benign.-Unit diversity lies. The game will try to make you think that there is an extremely broad selection of units. This is by no means true. Sincerely, there aren't that many different units in the game. The game will make you believe that there are, by reskinning the same units, changing them to another variant, and altering the traits of said unit, for example the M1 Abrams tank, there are SIX variants in the game. SIX! While these variants may (and probably) exist, this does not change the fact that Eugen has stated that there are over 1300 units in Red Dragon, but in reality, there are only about one quarter of that amount.-Unbalanced naval conflicts. People will always whine about the fact that BLUFOR has an aerial advantage when it comes to naval conflicts, which compensates for REDFOR's hardier sea vessels. This is true, but it does not completely compensate. Think about it. If you send a Tornado jet right into the midst of several ships, its destruction is guaranteed. Of course, this is a suicidal tactic, but you cannot always afford to wait for one of the enemy capital ships to become isolated, while your own ships (that must hold strategic deployment sectors around the map) are pounded into oblivion. Also, the more planes you bring along, the less ships you can bring, which limits your margin when it comes to ship expendability. -Incompetent AI. Something about all battles in general, when you're up against the AI. The AI always, ALWAYS has far more money than you, rendering them able to deploy half their cursed deck onto the playing field as soon as you hit the "Launch Battle" button, placing you at a severe numerical disadvantage. Also, the AI is abhorringly foolish. The milisecond you send a plane in, the AI launches EVERY SINGLE PLANE THEY HAVE BOUGHT at you, which will either result in your entire task force being reduced to smoldering ash, or, if you've prepared for this, the entire enemy air force will be littering the battlefield. If the former occurs, it will put you at a disgusting disadvantage, or if the latter takes place, you will be left with a monotonous and likely rapidly finishable battle.-Unrealism. Red Dragon can be really irritating at times. When your units (in this case, tanks) are moving through a village that is also being traversed by opposition tanks, in my experience, the enemy tanks somehow always manage to get a bead on my units, and destroy them, whereas my tanks can never seem to pinpoint enemy locations and neutralize them. Many people will just disagree, and call me a noob. Fine. But then when my tank is outside of the forest, and the enemy tank is in the forest, he can always establish a line of sight and send my crew down the expressway to hell. In naval battles, I have witnessed helicopters being hit multiple times by the MAIN GUN of my ships. THE MAIN GUN! The main gun would rip the chopper to shreds when the first freaking shell connects! The realism of this game is also contested in other parts of the game, such as the fact that tank shells NEVER ricochet, or that picket fences are taller than LAVs, but these can easily be forgiven. Sure, some will argue that it's just a game, or that it would be a bad game if it were too realistic. Red Dragon is a military RTS game, using historical assets. It pretty much revolves around realism. It cannot afford to let these things drag it down.+Astonishing graphics. This is a negative review, but that does not mean this game doesn't have somewhat of a silver lining to it. The graphics are quite simply extravagant for when this game was released.+Coherent soundtrack. Wargame: Red Dragon houses a sountrack that adheres almost perfectly to the setting. If you dislike the music of Red Dragon, you can easily switch to the soundtrack of European Escalation and even Airland Battle. +Battle map diversity. This installment has a multitude of maps for the land battles, which is great, yet it is severly lacking in naval maps, as there are only 6. TL;DR: The game has a toxic global chat, too many unit reskins, unbalanced naval units, multiple unrealistic tactical scenarios, a demented AI, but it does have good graphics, a fitting soundtrack, and a large selection of maps. Overall, I feel that the cons heavily outweigh the pros, which earns this game a negative review from me.

They added new factions... good thingThey added navy... poor integration. Oh yeah navy can obliterate land units but land units can't touch them... smart idea. Not.Rolling terrain... yaaay... if sector borders would be "rolling" as well. Some sector borders appear to be underground if you don't look at them from specific angle. Which is a pain considering that you have to put CVs into them.SP campaign Nice concept. But considering that AI is stupid, there is no versus like there was in ALB and overall lack of polish leaves you saying "poor realisation" again.Many say that game doesn't have big player base because it is hard. No. It is because players don't have time to rally around a solid game since they get clubbed in their face with new one each year.This is how it goes:Release of the game with many things that would make it enjoyable to play being absent -> adding those things with "free DLC"-> game is finally what it should be for actual release-> new game 4 months later (this time it will be with bases)-> most migrating to new game leaving you in a game that is to rts games what G+ is to social networks.Instead of focusing on MP part of the game (which Wargame should be solely about) and polishing it out considerably before release, they split their focus on both MP and SP thinking they will be able to pull it off but failing and ending up with rather sad product that will die out in about a year or so.Sad because in its core concept is a very good game. However instead of upgrading ALB they sidegraded, upgraded non cruical parts and even downgraded on some areas. And that is not something sequel should be about.Should you buy it? If you get it on massive discoutn.

number of helpful: 26 of 51 people (51%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												Warning: raw text.Wargame... what it does that word mean to you? Once a greatest contemporary RTS game... now it means another Call of Duty for... ehm... kids but in this case for 20+ y/o kids.I have been fan of Wargame EE since I saw trailer on TV in 2012, but now I must admit it became sh!t not "the sh!t", but literally sh!t. I will present you a little comparison between EE, ALB and eventually RD. EE was first of its kind, RTS with beautiful maps, authentic units, interesting and innovating gameplay. I have spent many hours of my life playing amazing campaigns, where I was defending Vaterland from commie basturds, where I was dealing with counter revolutionists in Poland... and I don't regret any minute of this time (this is WRD review so nothing much bout EE here). Life was going on. Year later came AirLand Battle with PLANES, at this time I have been like, OMFG PLANEZ NOW THIS GAME IS PURFECT. Along with now maps that weren't flat as chest of 10 year old girl this was a major step forward. Gameplay did differ a lot, since any thread could be resolved now with planes and rivers ingame did matter a lot but werent game breaking. City battles were amazing with new block system, all these US Marines versus VDV, Jägers versus Motostřelci etc. Even with it downsides as reservist problem (danish haer havernomnom something if you remember), F-14/MiG-31 tryhards, early SOVJET STEAMROLLER T-72B1/T-64BM/BMPT/BURATINO and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ singleplayer it was good game. But in this time it was clearly visible that this game should be a GREAT standalone expansion pack and not just a GOOD game. "Here comes the rage" aka "Now about Red Dragon". As any developer/publisher knows its much more profitable to release every year a new game, than updating old ones. First what everyone saw is obviously ships, but from the beginning I was skeptical about this... and i was right, the major selling point - the navy was (and still is) S.H.!.T., everyone expected F-14's taking off Nimitz to shoot down AShM Su-27's and then Iowa bombarding the battlefield (liek in World in Conflict!). But no. It was more like: ok lets use some LaFayettes and kongos to counter sovremenny's, in case they win call in some TRAMS, CF-18's and maybe some Super Pumas. In case when there is some river then spam some Monitor Zippo's and STRB's, oponent wont have how to counter 11 river boats for shure. Some tanks? Hellfire will pwn them like they are from paper. Some infantry? Monitor's napalm will give you smell of fried konkurs team. Planes or helis? Still no problem for you, coz blobbed 11 AAA canons will land it pretty fast. END. That was it... The Mighty Naval Feature (yep, instead of making something useful like towed weapons or playable campaign they made this).Overall, game feels like ALB with enlenghted (yes, i made up that word) timeframe. Now instead of Waffen SS Black PanzerDivision of Death consisting of Challengers, Leopards 2a4 and Abramses, you have to choose. Her Majesty Challenger 1+2's, or United forces of Freedom M1A* abramses, or combined Vichy France and Wehrmacht Leclercs and Leopards 2a5's. On other side vroom vroom T80UM and useless T72b upgrades. Now since last years where prototypes are accepted is 1996 we have some Star Wars techs already, for example Rafales using year 2000 Mira's, or year 2000 Caesar's too (guess in what country is developers HQ?), or North Korean T-90, omg devs apparently watched too much Kim Chong's propaganda. If we are talking about "Red Dragons" and "Blue Dragons", these factions are entirely made up by developers, because instead of making possible to use real advantages that these countries armies possesed in real life, for instead example human wave attacks of china they gave them some pewpew units that don't make sense from "authentic/realistic game" perspective that marketing departament of Focus Interactive tries to enforce. When Eugen first switched from mentioned realism to, ehm, balance, they started to including units that should never have been given to players for example other planes than ground attack ones and maybe some fighters (Mig-31's and B-5's are definitely out of frame here) or Patriot AA, srsly patriot in wargame, in MY wargame? One thing that bothers me is Eugene thinking they could fool us with "we are making you a big favor releasing FREE DLCs", from the beginnning i was in belief that even countries which should not be included in this war theatre would be updated immediately after release, but no, 40% of nations weren't updated, we had to wait another half year just to have some abandoned countries (GDR, CSSR, PLR) beign able to compete with factions updated from release. Now is 6th of November and Scandinavia countries are just plain useless. THANKS OBAMA, i mean, THANKS EUGEN. Lol, why were these countries included in first place, you might ask. Answer is people who play it are mainly from yurop and hurting your target audience is not a good idea. But when all resources were thrown on excellent navy feature, there was simply no time for minors. Eugene just killed two birds with one stone. Terms for updating were stretchered from March to...November! And also devs are looking like a knight in shining armor for giving player FREE DLC (FREE), for free. Blah blah blah, ur still readin? Maps are fabulous lookin from any distance, either from "tacticool height" and from close up, there are only two RTS's which could boast with it, and even here we see problem, instead of adding old maps from previous games, devs are making new ones, you might ask why? Because someone wasnt enought competent to do make map editor suitable for coverting own maps own games to different own games, lol. SO basically RD is ALB with new maps and new fancy units! First half of the year there were only 73 new models in RD, rest of "new" units were just fugly reskins of existing models so i wont glorify devs for it as reskining is relatively easy, personally, i made OVER 9000  HQ reskins (bulsht, i've done like 200 of them, you can chech my screenshots in profile or forums), so i have right to brag about, ehm, laziness of developers. Funny thing, EE was forgotten with no balance patches after ALB was released and ALB was lost in abyss of ignorance after RD seen the light of monitors, so guess what's gonna happen after Act of Agresssion (next Eugene game) will be released... yes you are right. At the time when i'm writing this wall of text, on virtual battlefields high end tank oneshots atgm team which is firing on it, mortars are shutting down any attempt of offensive, one spetsnaz squad is killing hundreds of enemies, meanwhile some cluster mlrs's are destroyng starting convoys, STRB's are pwning everything that has that bad luck of being 2500m near river, volley of patriot missiles from hedge near end of the map is shooting down another SEAD plane, while nordic vikings are bravely defending from combined power of whole soviet military somewhere in korea... Welcome to WargameTl;dr Red Dragon is not bad game, just developers are still disappointing us. Check wikipedia for definition of expansion pack. If you have an opportunity, try this game. You should make your own opinion about this game, instead of reading pointless reviews on steam. Thats all and I'm going to get pwnd in RD again, so thanks for reading. Thrawn out.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												Following on from the brilliant Air Land Battle, Red Dragon offers revised nations and Naval Warfare. The latter does not really appeal to me and I often wish they would have just run with an amphibious aspect of the game as the ships are just broken IMO. Which is a shame as no doubt the developers put a lot of time developing the units.As you can see from the number of hours I have ploughed into this game, I like it and why not. It is a very unique game and nearly all games played on MP are going to be different with the number of viable nations and coalitions. Like ALB it has a near vertical learning curve. So if you have skipped previous incarnations of this game them you might be in for a bit of a hard time. Don't be put off. You can play against the A.I which might cheat and not simulate human tactics and play. They will allow you to get to grips of what units do what. Also how to use them effectively. Howevr this will require some watching of you tube to get peoples views on deck building. As deck building is the core of the game. Ther are no bases to build, however in certain game modes occupying territory yields an income of sorts to buy units from your pre-configured deck.The game has been out for over a year now and this means that new players really stand out. However the forum is a good place to post and organise games with newer players. Smaller games are a great way to really appreciate the game. 1v1 up to 4v4 (other variations are available but require deicated server support). In house games are a great way to learn to play and offer feedback to mates after a game. Again there are more experienced players out there who offer tuition as they want to add to the community.10 v 10 is great fun and can be quite a punishing place if you are new. As new players have a tendancy to quit the game once they lose an initial push or are overrun. This has a big impact on the players left on the game and which is why a lot of newer players tend to receive the cold shoulder by some players. On the reverse of that it is also a gaming environment where new players mistakes can be corrected by other stronger players. As long you aren't feeding units to the enemy in the games most dominant game mode. Destruction, basically awards points for killing certain units with a set value. More expensive units give higher points.To summarise a great game with fantastic MP, it has been out a while so expect to do a bit of homework for MP games. If you wish to win that is. Alternatively play it with mates in your own in house environment until you are up to speed. A truly glorious game that deserves a thriving community, unlike the dwindling one of current. Hopefully Eugen will pull another out of the bag.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2016
												Well, here it is.Wargame: Red Dragon is a fun RTS/Tactical kind of game. I'm going to jump right into Pros/Cons.Pros:Deck Creating - Red Dragon really lets you go to town on making your army, your way. You can choose from not only countries, but coalations of countries to expand the amount of units you have available.Multiplayer - Multiplayer can be really awesome a lot of the time, a 10v10 battle can be really intense. Also, chopper rushes.Graphics - The graphics are really good for an RTS game, theres a lot of detail put into the game, and you can really tell the time they put into making the units.Cons:Scale - While the battles can be pretty big, the amount of units that are deployed on the battlefield are kind of small. Infantry squads generally only have a vehicle and 5-6 soldiers. Each vehicle is it's own unit. Unlike the Total War games, which have upwards of 2000 soldiers on the battlefield, Red Dragon only sees 500 or 600 soldiers at a time.Maps - Now, the maps aren't that bad. They're big. But that's the problem. See, as I sad above, the scale of battles is somewhat small, and the maps are HUGE. It feels kind of a waste.Well, overall, this is a good modern strategy game. I would rate it 7/10.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2014
												As someone who plays the SP side only, I'm actually enjoying WRD more than I'd expected.  Having entirely new armies (North Korea, South Korea, China, Japan, ANZAC) is fun.  I'd previously heard of the Type 59, the J7, the Korean K1, etc but never really understood what they were until having to lead or fight them in the campaigns. The campaigns themselves are a pleasant surprise.  There are a few mechanics I miss from WALB, but overall, the new organization around companies & battalions leads to a much wider variety of tactical situations than WALB.  I've had some surprisingly interesting battles where I'm fighting with scraps of different formations and having to put together a novel tactical solution.Far and away the best part of WRD is the variable speed.  While I eventually came to love WALB, the sheer franticness of the battles meant that I nearly always had to rely on setting up a defense and waiting for the AI to bash into me, since the AI could outmicro me in defending against my attacks (optimizing AH and ATGM ranges while simultaneously dropping mortars AND calling in CAS strikes :<).  With the new bullet time feature, I'm finally able to enjoy employing real tactics, and I can finally get down to ground level and enjoy the phenomenally beautiful engine.  There have been some amazing scenes that I always missed in WALB since I needed to stay high to monitor the entire board.  One downside is that the campaign map seems less well thought-out than WALB.  It's often unclear what you can and cannot do, and when you can't do an action (e.g. Assign a squadron to a new airbase), there's no explanation why.  I miss the "cards" you could play in WALB around the actual movement of formations, such as aerial recon, commando raids, naval strikes etc.  The ideal Wargame would blend the new mix-and-match formation system with the strategic actions and UI clarity from WALB.    The only other downside is that the AI seems to rely more on bull-rushing you with everything it has right at the start of every match.  My recollection is that WALB had a little more variety in how the AI would respond.  This may well be because they've removed some of the worst features of the "all-seeing" AI from WALB (thank you!), and without that omniscient vision, a full on rush is the only tactic remaining?  Still, it's early in WRD's evolution, and hopefully the AI will gain some more variability as the game matures.  So overall highly recommended.  There are one or two steps back from WALB, but also some real advances and I'm greatly enjoying my time with the campaigns.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												I am reviewing this as someone who has never played a game in the Wargame series before. And well I can tell you, buying this franchise now, when it has so much content is a fantastic experience, as everything is new to me.At first the game seems a little overwhelming, and you wonder how you are going to be able to concentrate on so many elements, and make tacticaly pushes at the same time. But after playing a few rounds of the game, and getting a couple of hours under your belt it becomes an addictive fever of how you can improve your army choice and their tactics of use. In this game you can create completely custom armys, with a choice of over 750 units per side, so thats over 1500 units in total. And you can put a combination of any of those 750 in to your army you want, or you can use a specific nation only, and if you want a specific role, airbourne, marine, mechanized, armoured, just some examples, and with these you will get bonuses, allowing you to field more units, not less, in your specialisations!I have only really played the British and USSR in any detail yet, although I have also created North Korean and Anzac (Australia & New Zeland) armys also. And well I can tell you, the choice of units you get, first seems overwhelming, but don't worry, pick something, try it out, after a game or two you will go, hang on, nope i prefer a longer range artillery type, or possibly you feel your vehicle anti air vehicles are to vunerable to being spotted and prefer to field infantry anti air in future. And this progression and refining is continual.I find 4v4 games enjoyable, but I find the 10 vs 10 games exciting, and thrilling, as ten people try to push and defend a line, and support one another, it feels a lot more unpredictable, and evolving and in the end realistic then any other RTS I have played. If you watched back many of the 10 vs 10 battles on video you would struggle sometimes to realise whos units are whos, and that it wasn't a real historical battle, the way lines are formed, holes found and pushed in the enemy lines, and weak spots reinforced in your own line.The only problem I have found with the game is when your team starts loosing, a lot of people will be quick to drop out of the game, which is rediculous as many times I have found you can fight back from a loosing position if you work together. I think there should be some form of punishing the statistics of those who quit out early. Okay the players resource points is shared out between players, but sometimes a team is only just slightly loosing, because they lost their harbour, and half of their team will quit, meaning micro management just got a lot harder! And even with half the team quit you got to give the guys sticking to it credit though, they fight on to the last fire base, and hold every inch of ground.I vow to be someone who never quits out of a game early because I am loosing. Its all about having good fun, gameplay, and in the finish, last stands can be great fun. You can hold them off to the end of the timer, it will be a draw often.Do not be put off by the lack of VOIP (Voice chat) in game, you will find the system, where you can type short messages and ping it, smoke tag a spot of ground, with the writing much more useful. You can quickly type "Enemy AA" or "Enemy Arty" and tag it on the enemy position. Or tag where you will capture, or what troops you are pushing on to a spot very quickly. And this is better then struggling to describe something on these huge battlefields some times.So in short, a great Real Time Stratergy game, if you haven't tryed this series of games yet and enjoy RTS games, I would say it is a must buy. A great experience, and a new level of large scale RTS. What are you waiting for, buy it!

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												This is the first game I've played that I've been really, really conflicted about.Pros: Graphically impressive, very complex tactics, amazing level of detail in unit design (including visibility, perception, armor, range, damage, etc. etc.). Probably the closest thing to real-time realism on the market right now.Cons: Extremely steep learning curve, zillions of units and game mechanics to learn, and the developers didn't support it with a tutorial. The fan community has brought up various resources to help, but general feeling is that to get a proper designer tutorial, you'll be looking at buying the first game, European Escalation.The game is very complex, which means it'll take time even for those familiar with the older games in the series to pick it up. (First game EE was purely land, second game AirLand Battle introduced aircraft, this game introduces naval units.)I'm fairly experienced with other historical RTSes (although none are as realistic as this one) and I found the learning curve for RD unworkable with the limited time available to me. I put eight hours in-game, trying out guides and putting what I'd learned from fan manuals into practice: my victory or defeat still feels entirely arbitrary. [Update: this is because the guides deal with playing against humans, but the AI uses several pathfinding shortcuts which give it several important differences from human performance - it has omniscient line-of-sight so concealment doesn't work against it, and it has "human wave" mentality for dealing with chokepoints.]The fan community has been great, and if you have a lot of time and attention to put into this game, it may be the game for you. Likewise, if you don't mind buying the first game and working through that as a prelude to playing this one. Folks who find analysis to be fun in its own right, or who are detail oriented, may enjoy this game too.I found the time demands of learning the game to be too heavy. I disapprove of the designer's decision to essentially shortchange new players by removing the tutorial on the assumption that they'll have played the prior games. The fan support is very heartening, but it seems to reinforce the designer's laziness so they can get away with it. The designer should include solo-play tutorial support in ALL titles in the series, not just the first few titles. This sales model of "expecting people to buy your earlier games before they can play your later games" was already proven unworkable with the Wizardry series way back in the 1980s. Eugen should know better.There's all the hallmarks of a good game in here, provided you can devote the very significant time and focus requirements to crack the shell, either by doing online mentorship with the fans, or by buying the previous titles in the series. However, in all honesty, it didn't work out for me and I couldn't recommend it in good conscience.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
												Wargame: Red Dragon. Where to start? This is the thrid installment of the WarGame series. It is a semi-realistic game focusing on possitioning, strategy and tactics. It has over 1400 units from 17 nations to choose from. Every unit has limited ammo and fuel, maps are large. Recon and supplylines are crtical for victory.The only bad things I can say about the game is that the naval aspect feels unfinished, it has no proper tutorial and some game mechanics seem rather obfuscated, the two latter things can be solved by reading guides made by the community as for ships they will hopefully feel more complete after tons of patching by the developer and free DLC. They do listen to the community and they do actively patch their games.If you come into this game expecting something similar to Command & Conquer, StarCraft or Act of War don't. WarGame is a very different style of RTS. There's no base building and you only get the units you choose to go to battle with. The way you choose your units is similar to a deck of cards. You build decks before going to battle. Each card holds a certain amount of units - the stronger and more modern the individual units are the less you get in each card for example you get over 30 T-34/85's in one card but you get only 1 M1A2 Abrams in a card, a deck consists of several cards under several categories: Logistics, Support, Infantry, Armour, Vehicle, Reconnaissance,Helicopter, Plane and Naval. If you choose only powerful units you may end up with no forces to fight with. Unit cards are also limited by type, amount and an overall limit on how many cards you can have. A deck should have a balance. In the campaigns you cannot make your own decks, they are predetermined.You are not allowed to field your entire force at once. You are limited by points, you get these points by capturing zones with your command units - the more zones you hold the faster you accumulate those points - the more reinforcements you can call in.The game has several game modes:Destruction - Destroy enemy units for points, the more the enemy unit is worth the more points you get. Conquest - hold more command zones than the enemy and reach a certain amount of conquest points to win.Economy - similar to conquest, but you win by having a stronger economy than the enemy. You will be sending out units sparinglyYou win by hitting the limit or by having more points than the enemy when time runs out or by destroying all the enemy command units.This game has too many mechanics to descibe in a single steam review or maybe even a full review such as recon, camouflage, missile types, missile guidance types, tank shell types, and the list goes on. if they were all mentioned in detail we might end up with a book of sorts, even certain community guides for this game can be a 1000 word essay, but if you are open to learn them you fill find that WarGame: Red Dragon is a strategy game unlike all others and a very fun experience.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2016
												Well, here it is.Wargame: Red Dragon is a fun RTS/Tactical kind of game. I'm going to jump right into Pros/Cons.Pros:Deck Creating - Red Dragon really lets you go to town on making your army, your way. You can choose from not only countries, but coalations of countries to expand the amount of units you have available.Multiplayer - Multiplayer can be really awesome a lot of the time, a 10v10 battle can be really intense. Also, chopper rushes.Graphics - The graphics are really good for an RTS game, theres a lot of detail put into the game, and you can really tell the time they put into making the units.Cons:Scale - While the battles can be pretty big, the amount of units that are deployed on the battlefield are kind of small. Infantry squads generally only have a vehicle and 5-6 soldiers. Each vehicle is it's own unit. Unlike the Total War games, which have upwards of 2000 soldiers on the battlefield, Red Dragon only sees 500 or 600 soldiers at a time.Maps - Now, the maps aren't that bad. They're big. But that's the problem. See, as I sad above, the scale of battles is somewhat small, and the maps are HUGE. It feels kind of a waste.Well, overall, this is a good modern strategy game. I would rate it 7/10.

												I used to be a sergeant in the army and in the army we use alot of planning, drawing, communication, create attack and mission templates., 90 % of what we did was planning+thinking  and and map reading before any plan was exectued.  This has almost none of that, its all about clicking speed with the mouse - it's more like 10 to 15  % planning and 85 % clicking on the map like a idiot.  I have played hardcore RTS (modded) games that revolve around realism and other realistic game genre such as operation flashpoint and ARMA series. From graphics to concept and gameplay everything has alot of potential and alot of it is well executed.  However interface and command options are abysmal and poorly executed, tutorial is completely lacking, the shortcuts are not intuitive. the interface and command options of the game '' AI war'' are thousands light years ahead of this game. What it comes down to is either capturing zones on the map or blocking the routes to that zones. This game revolves around micromanagement and speed of clicking, getting the right unit type to the right spot on the map at the right time. Everything about planning is thrown out the window in favor of poorly executed micromanagement and clicking speed. One of the worst interfaces and deployment/planning sequences of all the RTS i''ve seen. Basically you are put in the role of the general but without any shortcuts, interface options or planning details in order to execute a plan - you are on the field without the options a real general would have. You cannot draw on maps, pre plan orders for units before the game starts and compose battle groups before the game starts. The singleplay is the worst i have seen since 1998 Sorry but this game is highly overrated, its micromanagent all the way and has little to do with real strategy, tactics or planning. Unit balance is really bad and the Stats of units do not correlate to gameplay , the range of some weapons are ridiciously low and some units are just vastly superior. Also some eastern  units and real life tank types are missing. The Dutch nation DLC is ridilious and should be free , almost every conflict country is available but you are being punsished for being dutch. The dutch have been in every theatre of conflict since the 1st word war. Also most of the dutch units are just units that are available for other nations. When it comes to realism, interface and command i give this game a 4/10 , which is really poor When it comes to just casual RTS like games i give this game a 8/10, which is good If you like clicking around the map like a maniac get this game. Harcore realism has to do with intelligence , the ability to plan ahead and delegate everything in a proper way but also to be flexible when you have to change a mission template. This game has almost none of that and feeble minded players could easily rush you with  extreme clicking/micromanagement speed. If you expect real life realism don't even bother, it feels like a unpolished RTS version of ARMA 2 but and without al the options. Sorry but this game is not realistic.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												I had 3 M1-Abrams tanks on a cliff, spread out into a line formation. The tanks were hull down, only the turrets were visible, the hulls were behind the raised edge of the cliff. My tanks were stationary. I had infantry deployed on two sides providing eyes on the kill zone. 5 T-64s approached single file on a road, coming into view one at a time. They destroyed all 3 of my tanks for no losses on their side. I defeated the enemy's entire force, taking over all of his zones. Inflicted 2700 points of damage to his 1500 against me. The game awarded the AI a decisive victory. I was not allowed to purchase reinforcements at all during the battle. The AI was allowed to. Of course. I had over 900 points accumulated at the end of the game, and had every zone on the map occupied.Lots of effort was put into the graphics, but no effort into modeling warfare. The pathfinding is a mess, as well. There is no way to change unit facing. Units don't move where you tell them to. Typically, your tanks will face the enemy with their rear armor facing them if you try to set up an ambush. Most of the game is spent trying to get the forward armor to face the enemy. Try to move your tanks, they will charge towards the enemy backwards.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2015
												The most in-depth strategy game I've ever played. Eugen deserves some felicitations for the ambition manifested by this game and its engine. Despite the learning cliff, this game strikes the right balance between predictability and replayability. The UI is deceptively simple, and the complexity of the game owes more to tactics than any other single element. There is no base-building mechanic or resource collection to speak of here; all the units are at your fingertips right from the start, ensuring intensity from the beginning of each game.This is not an easy game to learn. Each unit has hard counters, many of which will not occupy the same price bracket. Tanks get a special mention not as invincible death machines, but simply as counters to enemy armour, which are themselves vulnerable to all kinds of threats, ranging from infantry to ATGMs to airstrikes. There is no unit that cannot be killed in one hit by another, far less expensive one. This means that Wargame can also be highly frustratinng at times. It also means that the ability to predict where your opponent is going to place their units is a skill to be valued. Coupled with a unique recon mechanic that completely eschews LOS bubbles and fog of war, this makes each round surprisingly tense. In many cases the only thing telling you whether a treeline contains an enemy squad or not will be your instinct. Expect to spend the better part of 50 games figuring out the basics. Watch replays or you will find yourself going up against and losing to the same formations again and again.  Playing a match of Wargame is like conducting a symphony. Miscalculating maneuvers by mere seconds can mean you'll be picked apart. But when it all comes together- it's exhilerating, and there is nothing like it.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												This is a very fun game. Perhaps the best RTS game of the last decade, which is saying a whole lot. Why can I not recommend this game then? It has hands down the WORST community of any game I have ever played. Because the game lacks an automatch feature, expect to be kicked from lobbies for having too low or high a win/loss ratio. It can often take up to a half hour to find a game. Teams of extremely experienced players will sit in a lobby stacking one team and wait to fill the other side with players they can steamroll. This is how the majority of the small handful of games offered in the match browser are at any given time. Eugen is not interested in adding an automatch feature, so don't buy this game. At least you can easily find a match in Company of Heroes 2. Shame it's an inferior RTS in every respect.

number of helpful: 14 of 28 people (50%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 21, 2015
												In the early beginnings, this game was heading for greatness.The balancing was refreshing and you had a huge variety in tactics, because units had different stats, ranges, prices etc. for different nations.The point system instead of factories, and cardsystem to build your army....wow....Also, you had to earn your units in the beginning, so  you didnt have access to that super tank from the start.Then someone had an idea and thought they could become a competition game, and they started balancing so that every unit had the same stats in all nations on both sides, all tanks do the same damage and have the same range on both sides, all planes have almost identical stats, the amounts of units are the same regardless of sides and so onThe neverending nerfing of units, and constant cries of "OP, OP" started the downfall.Then they removed the ranking system, and everyone had all the units all the time.......the "1000 units" point actually became mute then, as there really only were 50-100 units that really were possible to use effectively...They stopped developing maps, and only recently started porting over older maps, because......The devs dont know their own engine!!!(fact)Then we found out that there were cheats out there, cheats that removed fog of war.....(Gamebreaker??Yup, think so!)One should think this would make them prioritize some anticheat or something, but the devs just ignore it, and pretend it doesnt exist.(basically, because they dont know their own engine and dont know how to fix it)So now, this game is reduced to constant spamfest, very little tactics, and since you always know there might be someone cheating, that actually makes sense, but playability has gone out the window, fun factor is gone and....well.....And then we have the AI......well, there is actually no real AI, it doesnt make tactical plans, or really "play" the game, it kinda just see everything you do and counter spam accordingly, then it cheats a lot and goes straight for your HQ's, you just watch how that one unit of his go, straight thru you units, unharmed.....well, when i think about it, its kinda like playing against another cheating player, only he's a little dumberSo.....do i recomend?Nah, not any more!Sorry, you were too late.There was a great game here once, really great, but it got FUBAR'ed by devs with unrealistic expectations (this would never ber LOL or Warcraft)And they put this game on the shelf and put all their effort into Act of Aggression, so now its kinda dead in the water...Its sad, i played a lot, but havent played it in months now, and AoA is not my cup of tea, so....well, i guess an era is over

number of helpful: 19 of 38 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												It really pains me to change my review of this game but god damn did Red Dragon drop the ball on way too many things.First off, the ships. They sucked from the get go, they were patched to suck less, and then were never touched on again. In other words, they still suck. A minor complaint to some as they are not mandatory, but considering it was basically the unique selling point of the game, its a shame that it never got the love or attention it really needed.Secondly, the balance. Eugen doesn't know how or to whom its balancing its games. It seemed for a bit that there plan was to make a game that was balanced in such a way that the people who played it a lot and learned how to get real good at it, there game would be a very balanced affair. Meaning that people with not as much skill may not recognize counters or better strategies and tactics here or there, but they'd be there, they'd exist to be learned and taught.But, if the idea of competitive Wargame ever became a huge thing to watch or experience I never heard of it, and so I think that whole idea fell through. Then there was this idea that they'd balance to realism. Which led to many fun arguments about why Hinds shouldn't have AA missiles and how the Marines didn't have LAVs as troop transports ever, both of which are hilariously false and dumb.So now we get to the point where the balance has switched priorities and objectives, and has been screwed with and muddled up so many times that the other major selling point to wargame, the amount of units it has and the fun hardware that it has, its depth of units... is also false. There is a best deck for each nation. There really isn't that much tactical flexibility that would allow you to bring A instead of B, its just that this one deck will always win out all other things being equal.All of which wouldn't be as bad if Eugen seemed to still be patching and fixing the game. But they're really not. They haven't touched it in quite a while, outside of adding in the new maps recently, and the community has kind of recognized that they've moved on to their other game Act of Aggression. Its a shame really because I think Red Dragon could have, with a half a years additional polish, made for a much better playing experience. But as it stands? Its a mess of different ideas and concepts and thoughts and mis-steps, that no one is even bothering to look at anymore.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												This review has been completely updated as I wrote the first review with little understanding of the game. Previously I thought the land battles were good, but I liked the naval battles more. That has completely changed. The naval battels are quite bad, land is the only worthwhile part of this game. So first, the naval battles.     Naval battles in a mixed land/water maps ussually handled by one person. It ussually ends up being blufor spamming anti-ship jets against redfor, or one of the sides will push towards the enemy spawn, and the enemy will have saved money and instantly spawn in 2-3 ships and destroy the aggressors. I have never had an actual naval battle on these maps. The closest I have come is missile stand offs. Occassionaly the navy will start bombarding land, and at this point you cant afford any sort of anti naval units, so it is just a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ To conclude naval battles are essentially missile cheese battles.     Land battles are far better. My only gripe is with high end tanks. They run for about 170-180 but are a little lackluster. If a tank 1 has 15 frontal armor and a gun that does 18 damage, and tank 2 has 22 frontal armor and a gun that does 20, the tank 1 will do one damage and tank 2 will do 5. This means Tank 1 kills tank 2 in ten hits and tank 2 kills tank 1 in two hits. This seems fair enough, but it means that heavy tanks can be damaged by any sort of semi heavy projectile, even shots from a 30mm auto cannon on a BTR-90. They are also destroyed extremely quickly by any sort of ATGM. Any sort of anti tank attack helo can kill these high end tanks with 23 frontal armor in 2-3 hits. Other than that I have no problems with the game. It manages to be realistic, but still faced paced at the same time. Just make sure you play conquest, Destruction modes are essentially world war 1 all over again.

												This game puts you in the middle of a conflict zone, in real time strategy mode. You get to play withas many millitary units as you possibly can and defeat your enemy by capturing their territory. The game has a point system which means ,you can spend only a limited amount of points on your army strength ,before going to battle. The game features mmog features, which puts you up against other players of the game.The music is great and the graphics good.So all in all the game has many + points and relatively no minus. But to name a few :-Positives1.The game has mmog features which makes it competetive and fun2.The game has smooth graphics and good music3.A variety of war units to choose fromNegetives1.Lacks a microeconomics aronud it like cs:go hasAll in all a good game for any age. A solid 6/10 for presentation.
