content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
												This game combines the complexity and mechanics of card based or table top strategy games with the real time action of a conventional RTS.That's a good thing if you understand that, but it means there is a steep learning curve to the game. You can not zerg in this game. Well you can, but you won't be very popular with your team mates.Get to know the 100s of units' strengths and weaknesses, get to learn the complex mechanics, get to know the maps and their conventions and you there is a great sense of satisfaction to be had. You can't just jump in a guess though, and the game it's self doesn't offer anything in the way of education.The interface is clunky, half the time a left click works half the time a right click works. The move button is labelled attack, the flank button is labelled move and the layout is keener to be 80's retro than usable and sane.All that complexity and dedication to learn what's going on adds up to an unfriendly experience for new players. You play your first game and loose all your units in 20 seconds to rocket spam; then your team hates you for feeding the enemy. So in your second game you bring rocket spam and your team hates you for wasting their resource and attracting counter battery to supply routes and refuelling units. And so it goes on.Playing as a team will be a much more rewarding experience. For a start  you have a chance to be competitive when facing servers stacked with other teams, and your co-ordination and collaboration will give you a huge advantage to counter-balance your nubness.If you are a 'serious business' player and want a less simplistic RTS then this is right up your street, but it is in no sense a casual or accessible game, and games from outside the 'wargame' series will not have as much in common as you expect.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2014
												Fantastic RTS. One of the few more modern strategy games that I actually enjoy playing. This game is still buggy to some extent indeed but most of the stuff is cosmetic and doesn't bother me very much. This game employs many real world weapons systems accurately and allows for real world tactics to be utilized because of it. This game is not necesarrilly a simulation by any means, but it is certainly one that you have to actually think about when you play, not just point and click and mindlessly win. I have played all the Wargame games from European Escalation (the first) and I already have more hours logged on this game than the other two (relative to the amount of time I've had them) and this game has only been out for just over a month at this point. The unit variety is enourmous and no single combat unit has an identical counterpart on the opposing faction, making for VERY fun and unique matches that vary player to player. Overall, this is a FANTASTIC game, and although it could use a little ironing out of the cosmetic bugs such as improper weapon animations and I believe some sound effects that are not that of the weapon being fired on certain AA missiles, is absolutely one of my favorite games that I have played, and that's a lot to say the least...

												I loved War game EE despite its very challenging interface, I got War game air land battle and after over 600 hours of multiplayer I loved it and still play it once a night.I Got War game Red dragon and .....well I played it for 500 hours and just kept trying to like it.in the end I stopped playing.The main issues are the Maps they are to small and there is no where to hide your heavy equipment.roads all seem to converge in densly urban death traps. and just force you to crash head on into the enemy there are no genius master strokes in flacking or bluffing your location.It could have been but it is just not.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
												Navy combat needs a huge balance pass. The level of imbalance is crazy, its so clear when you read the stats of both sides ships, and even more clear when you fight with both sides ships. One side is better, to the point of needing half as much command points to win.Many units across all factions seem to have huge errors in their cost, and power levels. Example: a flac gun with 16 frontal armor ( same as a main battle tank ) with a cost of 60 ( half as much as a main battle tank )Wait 1-3 months for balance.If you have a firend that you want to skermish with vs. AI or eachother - Buy it, you will have fun playing and learning the game. If you care about hard core competitive multiplayer where every side has an even chance and the only difference is how clever you are - dont buy the game.

number of helpful: 9 of 19 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												I had high hopes for this piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥of a game, and so did most of my friends, and yet Eugen shitfrenchbaguette faces managed to ♥♥♥♥ up this game so badly that I have no intention of ever playing it again.So what's wrong with the game?Firstly, map balance. Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥they really are ♥♥♥♥ing stupid when they can't create a basic map that doesn't give one side a massive advantage. Don't get me wrong or anything, advantages will always be created when you create maps for this game but you need to try to keep them as low as possible but the devs obviously did not give a ♥♥♥♥.Secondly, unit balance. This RTS has serious issues with balancing out units, take the BMPT as an example. It was good in Airlandbattle but in Red Dragon it absolutely destroys any opposition. It out ranges all MBTs, infantry and has seriously heavy armour. Now if this unit was a one off case I doubt many people would mind but if you look more closely at other units *cough* SAS *cough* you start to see more and more unbalanced units.Thirdly, bugs. I can't believe this game is out considering how many bugs it has, helicopters fly through mountains, you will bug out during the loading screen more often than you will play, player stats are off (apparently a week after release I had already spent over 1000 hours in game) and the list goes on and on.Bad game is bad, 1/10

number of helpful: 8 of 17 people (47%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												TLDR: It's an ok game if it's on a heavily discounted sale. You're not missing anything. I can't say i can recommend this game because you're not missing anything if you don't buy it. If you played the previous games and just want a new theater of war, go ahead. Otherwise, there are better RTS games out there.While European Escalation is still the best in the series and Airland Battle being a complete disaster, Red Dragon is a positive return towards a well balanced product. It combines some of the crafted and procedural campaign aspects of European Escalation that provided imersion and includes the strategic map from Airland Battle. The AI is improved over AB in that it doesn't just spam the highest value units at the player. There is some more rhyme and reason behind it's logic. The graphics seem unchanged from the first game. It looks fine. It's more or less bug free and it provides free DLC.

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												Just avoid, horribly unbalanced, the AI cheats heavily on the easiest setting, and the always on chat is extremely toxic.The AI has infinite points/ammo/fuel they can see hidden units, their normal non AA tanks can attack aircraft yet yours cannot. The visibility for planes/helicopters that are non recons is awful considering how far they should be able to see.Due to seeing everything, the AI will launch artillery on your command vehicle or destroy your flanking tanks with a single plane, while yours barely scratches theirs.Something that helps in a RTS is flanking, but the AI sees everything so flanking is impossible, they'll just see you coming and kill you from a distance.The only AI weakspot is infantry in buildings where they die in vast numbers trying to kill your infantry with tanks.They get no penalty for moving through rough terrain while yours do.Multiplayer results in rushes or cheap tactics with sore losers and a toxic community behind it.The beginning campaign is not at all beginner level, the autowin is unrealistic with its expectations of your forces.Avoid unless you like a smashed keyboard, as this WILL result in one.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												I really like dthis game and had hours of great fun. I was thinking about getting this game as a present to my friend, who really likes RTS. However, after the last patch it has become absurdly obviously that the Eugen developers have a clear bias. They make one of the factions of the game, bluefor, overpowered with easily the best units in the game with competition. To list a few; Nighthawk, Longbow, Patriot, Challenger 2, Otomatic, KF-16C Block 52D, Maglans. These units make those factions fun for a short while and provide novice players a handicap and experienced players a challenge. However, Eugen has clearly presented a bias to the other faction, redfor, by not only refusing to provide counter balancing units, but also reduce the power of the ones already present. This makes the Redfor DLC pack virtually pointless to buy and makes the only redfor playable factions the Eastern Block Coalition and Soviet Union. This bias severely restricts the games' online playability as winning 1 in 5 games as redfor or boring “cookie-cutter” tactics as bluefor. I have observed units on redfor be nerfed time and time again, but this last patch was the final straw. If Eugen cannot provide a balanced gameplay, then I cannot recommend the game to others.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												I was really interested in this edition of Wargame because of the promised expanded campaign. That was an extreme letdown. There are 4 very short campaigns with fixed factions and no options. +Instead of bringin in army goups or MEU's, you bring in pre-made "regiments" that form an army in the sector they are fighting.+Units are destroyed on the regiment level instead of army level.+You can reinforce the regiments now instead of just playing a war of attrition.+Lots of new units, amphibious units.+Excellent music and sound.-None of the campaigns take place in the 90's (when the game actually takes place. Makes no sense). For example, in 1987, I have access to USMC infantry with a configuration from the 90's.-Campaigns are short and only the RedFor countries (china, russia, etc) start in good position. NATO/non-Warsaw is always spread thin and on the defensive.-Warsaw units are still stupid powerful. Their transport helicopters take more ground fire than an Apache or Warthog, all their units have the best accuracy in class, best range in class, best penetration in class, best health in class, etc etc.-You still have to play leapfrog with scout units, which is tedious (though non-scout units seem to have a slight increase in vision range, so it's a little better).On a side note, you'll probably want to turn chat off if you buy the game. There is generally at least one person ranting about how they are going to "kill the West and♥♥♥♥♥♥all their children". Trolling is EXTREMELY bad in this game. Probably the worst I've ever seen.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 4
												I would love to recommend this game but I can't. The game itself is a lot of fun. Very punishing and rewarding play or you can soften it up a bit by having more points. The units are INCREDIBLY varied and I am still seeing new strategies tried. There is a very steep learning curve for this game and to be good you need a lot of micro. The reason I can't recommend this game is due to the community that surrounds it. There is no moderation in the wargame chat and there is no punishment for team killing. Team killing a command vehicle can sway an entire battle and there is nothing stopping it from happenning. To report someone you have to have a copy of the replay and create an account in the forums but it doesn't do anything. One particular player literally had a change.org to get him removed from the game. That's how bad it is. I literally can't even post the chat here because it's too explicit and racist. I can't play a match without constantly moving my command vehicles because I'm worried for friendly fire from my team. I would return the game if I could. Oh, and single player is fun for about ten minutes so you HAVE to play with the community. Do not buy this game and if you do then do NOT play with John Brownwood.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2014
												Despite being in beta stage still and having some serious bugs, (deck making crash and unreliable mp flare beacons to name a few) this game is awesome! They fixed some of the flaws in Airland Battle and EE like improving artillery, and adding arrows that  show which reinforcement point your troops come in from which is very helpful. The new units are really cool and the new maps are beautiful and more realistic looking than their ALB and EE counterparts, and the new factions are cool as well. The naval units are not in the game yet sadly, but apparently they were very buggy in the closed beta and needed fixing, and I am sure they will be fantastic when the game is fully released a month from now. If you like RTS games and favor games that are more realistic I highly recommend Red Dragon. Wargame can be difficult at first for new players, but playing against the ai is a good way to practice for mp combat. I am very pleased with Red Dragon so far, and cannot wait for the game to be fully released so I have access to all the new features like naval combat and the campaign maps.

												They say this is the best RTS game currently availablebut its not a good game ,this game suffers for trying to do too much and ending up being a master of noneThe game itself plays like any Total War game ,one turn based where you sort out where you posistion your units,then a battle then repeatThe map and tile placement is exactly that ,place your forces to counter act whats going to attack youThe battles themselves are very poor there dull to watch with a relatively weak mechanic  ,it makes you wonder if anybody who gave this game a thumbs has ever played Blitzkrieg by CDV made in 2004 because in comparison this new and improved game looses poorly to a game produced over 10 years ago and looses on graphics tooThey say this game makes you fight in a combined force but so did Blitzkrieg but only CDV implemented theirs much much betterNever played online yet but which is where i suspect this game gets it popularity similar to World in Conflict both suffer from weak mechanics but because of that it gives way to a fast paced easy to play multiplayer which isnt really strategy My advice is if your looking to blow things up with your friends give it a try if your looking for a genuine strategy game with engrossing battles try looking for Blitzkrieg (shame its not on steam)

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
												Bigger, Badder, BetterI love how this game completely expands upon its predecessors. While Airland Battle felt more like a rectified and updated European Escalation, this feels like an all out war for top sequel. The game practically hands you all these different units and says, "Go have fun." I love how units do not rout as easily, either. There are so many factors that can decide the outcome of a battle. Because of the lessened rout, the little guy has a chance to make the difference. One panicked tank is able to harass an enemy column long enough for me to reinforce it. Never have I had so much fun blowing through enemy units or losing mine in a single, decisive swoop by my opponets. It keeps you thinking quick but always two steps ahead. What are you willing to sacrifice? When should you retreat? How will you make your advance?The Naval aspect opens new doors. Just this morning, I used an amphibious assault to take my opponent's point. Using Infantry and LAVs, I was able to distract the enemy invasion from taking siege of my ally. When they turned their heads, I swung my sword for the killing blow. My ally poured his reserves into those countless PACT units. My aircraft finished what was left. It might as well have been the Highway of Death on that map. What an invigorating experience and a sweet victory. This game is now my favorite of all three Wargames. Great job to the devs. Who's with me?

If you enjoyed airland you might like this a little better but stay as far away from the naval battles as possible. And as they are tied into so much that really ruins the game.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												Fairly nice sequel to Airland Battle, I'll say. It's definitely not any worse, at least. The way decks work was shaken up a bit, but all the core mechanics are there. You still have to keep your troops supplied, your troops ninjas when hiding in bushes, etc etc. Although, there are some pleasant surprises. For example, the campaigns have a lot more personality to them than WALB, with more story, and they have bits of dialogue, but you still can choose where to send battlegroups and what not like in WALB. Also, mountains are no longer considered cover for infantry, not unless there's a bit of forest on there. Also, recon infantry now can see from mountains to some extent, much better compared to before. Though not a surprise being a much touted feature, naval warfare is now available. And with it, you can use amphibious transports which open up new places to attack which you can exploit, if you're against a new player who doesn't realize you can go there. Also, useful for new players, hovering your mouse over rank selections in deck making lets you see the benefits of that rank.All in all, it adds a lot of fresh air to the series, I'd say. The mix of new features, new armies, and upgrades to how things work add up to make an improved game, though not without problems like some odd bugs that slipped through and things.EDIT: It's even better now that East Germany and Czechslovakia aren't more or less kind of crippled compared to their comrades, with DDR having Tunguskas, Wachregiment, and other nice toys, and CZ have new improved Ondavas, militiamen, paratroopers, and a Mig-29 that drops napalm.TL;DR buy for True Korea, boats, and more mentally degrading chat.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2016
												POSITIVE REVIEW FOR SINGLEPLAYER ONLY!!!!!!! 10/10If you want this game to play five really good campaigns against AI, then why the hell are you reading this and why haven't you started downloading it yet?The campaigns are great, challenging for a first time player and sometimes, it pisses you off to no end. There is easy 100 hours of game time on the campaigns alone. Otherwise, skirmish is fun. You can have massive tank battles or human wave battles if you wanted. NEGATIVE FOR ONLINE!!! 5/10If you want it to play online against other people, 50/50 chance you'll regret buying the game at full price. Online community is small but that’s not the issue. From experience, PACT forces massively outguns NATO.How you ask?Bigger, better, more cost effective artillery Better, more cost effective AA to the point where they can shoot down your SEAD aircraft before you can even get in range (and they get 5 of those bad boys in the deck) Better planes (to the point where it is almost impossible to bring them down, even by spamming jets) Tanks and anti-tank units that are way too overpowered when it comes to their pricing (Seriously, when pricing is compared to a Challenger 1 MBT, I’d take the PACT tank because I'll kill it with a missile from my tank before it gets in range -.-) Their only downside is the lack of infantry. But why the hell would you want infantry to storm the town when you can have a plane dump napalm on it or do a massive artillery spam and then send in tanks to kill severely damaged and panicked troops? Even then, just take SPETSNAZ and throw them into the town, they'll take down 2 times their points in either infantry or vehicles BEFORE THEY START TO TAKE DAMAGE!!!Furthermore, at least once every four games if you are playing as NATO, you'll go up against a person who loves spamming stuff. And not cheap bad stuff that you can bring down with one or two missiles either. And at least 1/10 games there will be a artillery spammer. Although you can have fun with NATO decks in online games, you will only get victory by being a a**hole and taking out their command forcing the game to end early.Online is fun though, that is if you like being PACT and can actually find someone willing to be NATO. 10/10 single player 5/10 multiplayer

												This game is absolutely amazing. It made huge improvements from EE and it only gets better. The only people that give this game a bad rating are the ones who think it's unfair when they for example tank rush thinking this is company of heroes and then they get slowed down with artillery barrage and wiped out by carefully timed air strikes.. You have to THINK a little bit and support your attack with many different types of units. So that's what I constantly read in the complaints. But that's typical of noobs. The only complaint I have is that the game needs some sort of award system in the form of unlockable content. There is a GREAT deal of units in this game that are all open to you, but leaves nothing to you to fight for and gain with your victories except some stats in the form of numbers.. Need a little bit of motivation for all of the great battles people have online. If that was in there I would give this game a 10/10 and shoot anyone who gives it lower. Buy the game it is amazing. Nothing else out there like this and I play all types of games

content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
												Edited after 200 Hrs.Edited after 400 Hrs.Edited after 500 Hrs + 2 new DLCs.On my third review, this is still mostly a negative experience. Which is a shame because this game has so much potential to be a GREAT game, rather than a mediocore experience.Let me keep it simple:-Small attempts have been made to balancing, but frankly it needs a complete overhaul, especially with Infantry and Prototype units (more so with DLC nations)-Power difference between Nations and Coalitions is shockingly poor.-Navy is officially dead.-Terrible gaming community full of pros and new players, leading to extremely one sided games.(great game tho to play if you have a group of friends to play locally).-Pointless Cat C and B decks/theme. Dont expect a Cold War game, this is now effecetive a fictional game of Cold War going into the mid 2000s.-Poor single player experience.If they fix these issues, this could be one of the best strategy games in my two decades of gaming. It could be up there in e-gaming with Starcraft, Company of Heroes.For a single player experience, I highly recommend World in Conflict which has a fantastic campaign. The multiplayer is good too, but I think given its age, its probably a empty scene.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												中国将越来越大If you're a fan of previous Wargame installations, Red Dragon is a must have. However, if you have no prior experience in the Wargame series but still insist on getting the game; be warned, the online learning curve is very steep.Wargame is a unique kind of Real-time Strategy game, differing from well-known RTS games like C&C or StarCraft in many aspects. Typical base building -- or rather, base building at all -- is absent, as are typical economic systems (i.e money, different resources and all that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t). The latter of which is replaced by a single, universal "resource", to which you use to bring units in from off screen. Wargame also incorporates more realistic mechanics into the game. Units will react to situations more realistically, for example, a tank company being bombarded by artillery or caught in a napalm strike will freak the ♥♥♥♥ out and try to escape from combat, disregarding orders in the process. Most units also have limited fuel and ammo, which will need to be resupplied to them. And projectiles act like projectiles would in real life, having chances to hit or miss a target, with factors like an obstructed line of sight coming into play.Now, as much as I love this game, I find that the naval combat -- one of the selling points of the game -- is unredeemably bland. As beautiful as it looks, there's almost no depth to it at all; it's a simple matter of "huck enough missiles at the bad guys to kill them". Unlike the aircraft mechanic which plays a pivotal role in the game, the naval combat's role is minor at best, but more commonly is downright trivial.Overall I give Wargame: Red Dragon a 8.5/10, Eugen definitely has not disappointed with the beautifully detailed battles that we've come to love from the Wargame series, but the not-so-subtle lack of depth from the naval combat is hard to overlook.Wargame: Red Dragon is a masochist's Cold War enthusiast's dream. A tough as hell RTS experience that somehow has you coming back for more. However, if you do plan on buying it, buy it for the multiplayer, singleplayer isn't even half the experience of the game.(P.S, this isn't a "meh C&C", think before you speak.)

content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												Great RTS, Realistic war strategy.Difficult to get used to if you are used to the classic "make the most expensive unit, roll in" crap of other rts games. If and when you do that (you will once if you are a fast learner, more than once if you are slow) you will watch all of your units die. tank vs infantry does not mean tank wins. helicopter vs infantry does not mean helicopter wins.  Unit composition is important to this game. Nothing is more satisfying than a 10 v 10 match where you and 1 friend take out an enemy navy that was created by 10 of the other teams player by yourselves with a much smaller navy. By use of islands, sea depth, coastal forces, and aircraft it is possible to do more with less. Which makes this game the Strategy game to play. Also. every time you don't buy this game an orphan has to watch someone else eat ice cream. You think about that. do you want that on your conscience?

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												I've been playing around in the Wargame franchise sinc European Escalation, and Air-Land Battle, and Wargame Red Dragon adds a whole new aspect of battle with the concept of Navy. In a smaller Multiplayer setting such as 4v4 or 3v3, Navy becomes a key role in winning matches, but in a 10v10 it is almost entirely useless as both teams will always have someone that maxes out their navy because they think it's a "good strategy". But in all fairness, gameplay of this game in almost identical to that of the previous version of WarGame and it is on the rather advanced side of RTS games. So if you don't have patience to play a multiplayer match that can take two hours, I suggest you don't buy the game, but if you like constant combat, in a large scale, fast paced enviroment, and you have patience as well as a love for blowing♥♥♥♥♥♥up with your friends, This is the game for you. I would give this game a 8.5-9/10. It is fun, but can be frustrating. Hope this helps :D

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												If you think of buying this game, realise that the game is inbalanced, so playing everyfaction to win is not going to work. The AI on higher difficulty simply cheats more points so when you have 1 yet the enemy allready has 1,5 yet on the hard difficulties. Also the AI knows where you placed your hidden command vehicles and maybe also your hidden units. Playing vs AI is only fun if you put it on lower difficulties or disable the reinforcement points (this makes the AI unable to exploit thier massive point gain advatage, and makes both players start of with 1 army where they have to fight the rest of the battle with).The campaign imo is not realy enjoyable, you will find yourself grinding out enemy waves of units which are moslty straightup counters to your regirments, so if you have only tanks and yets the enemy will spam helicopters and yets and then straigt up overrun you, the AI is able to do this because in every campaign the AI starts of with a massive unit advantage and deployment point advantage. So for the campaign you are mostly trying to keep as many units alive and killing as many enemy units as possible battle after battle in the same area with the same units.However the game is beautifull and remember to only play the most overpowerd factions because the game is not fun if youre losing as an underpowerd faction. The israeli faction pack is a must have you even want to set 1 step into multi player because this faction is absolutely overpowerd and not playing as israel is a certain loss.There is also a serious lack of indicators, for instance the following indicators are still missing:range indicator of weapons, you cant see how far your units can fire.vision indicator of your units, you cant see what you can see, you will have to judge what you can see by expecriance.and various other indicators such as minimum range of your artillerythere are also no help guides or such things, you will have to learn to understand the game through youtube videos or something.this game is worth about 10 euro's but no more in my opinion, its fun but the lack of help and tooltips and indicators make it extremely hard to play. The campaign is simply not enjoyable, and the inbalance of the diffrent factions is also very annoying. yet if you buy israel the game gets a whole lot more fun.i have played a total of 40 hours of this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												Wargame Red Dragon is an excellent game. I play it a lot and i will continue so.There are of course good and bad aspects of this Real Time Strategy game.This game requires time and a lot of frustration to master but it will be worth it.Strategic thinking is insanely is important.There are thousands of units and most of them have unique abilities and statistics. 2 Sides Nato And Redfor. A lot of countries and coalition to choose. What i really love that you can select a speciality for your Batallion Deck. Marines, Airborne, Mechanized, Motorized, Armored, Support. Or just a normal deck with no speciality. It really depends of your style of play. When you join a server, a server host can select 1 of many maps, starting points, points required to win and a gamemode. 3 Gamemodes: Destruction: Gain points for destroying enemy unitsConquest: Eventually qain points for capturing and keeping the zones. Economy: Having as much Political Points as possible. This game requires a lot of teamwork. At the start of the game you will have time to deploy units with political points. When everyone launches battle the game will start. Usually you have to be self dependant. The unit cateqories are: Logistics: Command units. Supply trucks, supply helicopters, or a Forward Operating Base which has a lot of supplies.Infantry: Line infantry, Special Forces, Surface to air teams, Long range anti-tank missile teams.Tanks: From cavalry to super heavy tanks.Recon: Special Reconnaissance Forces, Recon Infantry, Recon Helicopters and vehicles light and armored.Support: Gun air defences, missile air defences, mortar units and howitzers.Helicopters: Gunships, anti-tank helicopters. Anti-Air HelicoptersAirplanes: Air Superiority Fighters, Anti Tank Planes, Multiroles, and Supression Of Enemy Air Defences SEAD planes.Navy: Battleships, Destroyers, Patrol Boats, Frigattes, Anti-Ship helicopters and planes.What i dislike about this game that there are public statistics about players. Other players can view them in a game lobby. In my opinion it should not be public because players are literally judged because of level, or win precentage. If you have low stats you might aswell be banned by an ignorant host. Single player campaiqns are good time killers. Very well made. But this game is missing a Multiplayer Strategic map just like in campaiqns. It would be a cool addition.10 Versus 10 matches. I dont know does these even have moderation because its very rare but possible that your teammate will troll the match. Ex: Teamkilling or rejoining the game to prevent it to be started. Usually it does not happen. Reskins. As i mentioned that this game has thosands of units, yes it does. But most of them arent special. When you compare units you might see that a unit is completely similar to other nations unit. They just look different. But usually its only line infantry. Not a big problem though. Nations are a lot different than others and thats a good thing.Overall i love this game. I would recommend this to anyone who likes realistic modern stategy games.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												Okay, In short: This is a superb game.Okay, In long: You can gather hundreds of hours on this game. It has over 1000 lovingly crafted units. The maps and cover system is amazing. All the weapons and damage mechanics are un-matched in realism. The recon and air mechanics are amazing and it is the first RTS game I have seen to correctly implement fast air.This game is extremly difficult, it is nothing like other RTS games, it requires alot of learning and the tutorials are hopeless. I recommend reading the 200 page guide. The AI SUCK! They know where your units are and it ruins the game. This game is born for multi-player if you dont have a regular internet connection I dont recommend buying it.Overall I recon this is one of the best RTS games ever made. However if you are going to curse at the screen because you cant understand how your fighters were shot down by enemy AA.9.3/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23
												In this game, the user had a omniscient perspective. This means the user can see the battle field from above making the game like a board game. It allows you to make your own deck of infantry, support, tank, recon, air and naval units from many different countries around the world. The game is very detail because each unit is very unique. The game is semi-realistic  because units have a variety of accuracies and units are able to get stuck in mud, detracted, run out of fuel, ammo and can be repaired. The naval battles can be different each time and it's beautiful to watch the battle play out. You can see a missiles flying around the battle field, being intercepted by sea whiz, radar missiles and flares. The game is great for huge battles and great screenshots.     There are only a few problem is that the AI can sometimes be buggy and there should be more campaigns. Another  problem is that you can't close the hud during a battle so if you want beautiful screenshots you need to watch the battle on replay which is sometimes tedious and boring.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												Sent a swarm of missile carrying helicopters, and missile carrying jets against a naval force, and sat back watching as the enemy fleet desperately threw up gattling rounds and flare countermeasures against the spam of missiles, smiling as one by one the big soviet ships blew up and sent a blastwave to ring against the hulls of it's allies.Then I fired the combined guns of my artillery to blunt an enemy push down a vulnerable gap in our lines. The enemy forces came to their senses just quick enough to see the napalm bombs from my jets drop on their heads and create havok amongst their lines.The survivors, still shaken from the bombardment were just about to continue their advance against my ally's thin perimeter only to hear an ominous distant boom-boom-boom, before beholding the arc of an incoming barrrage of missiles to blanket the area in explosions and fire.The enemy retreated, to regroup and rethink. Their answer would shortly come and I wouldn't be so lucky to come off so unscathed. 10/10 would fight WW3 again.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												You can love it or hate it. Love Real Time Strategy? Buy it NOW...NO excuses. First person shooter or Turn Based Strategy? You'll get frustrated to no end. Been playing since the beginning of the series and I am a proud owner of each game. Wargame: European Escalation, Wargame: Airland Battle, and Wargame: Red Dragon are just simply the best modern RTS and has no competition. With satellite view straight down to bolts of a tank, the wargame series' focus on beautiful graphics aside from the truely inspiring game mechanics is what makes this series the best. The new Navy aspect introduced in Red Dragon gives endless options to attack the opposing enemy, but don't think the Navy will save you in every battle. You have the power to do whatever you want. Thinking from different perspectives during battle is what leads to victory. You got to love having a fresh experience each battle, and then replay the video capture to look at your mistakes and successes all while enjoy how beautiful the battle looks.This series keeps geting better with each year. W:EE - infantry,tanks, helocopters, and artillery. W:AB - intro to Airplanes. W:RD - intro to the Navy. Who knows what lies next. Do you have to buy all the games in the series? No, each new game adds to the old one and you don't miss anything jumping straight to Red Dragon. Its in the Cold War times and what could have happened. They keep adding to the game as the timeline gets closer to the 1990s which means bigger badder units and more choices. More opportunities.What are you waiting for? This is the best RTS on the market to date. If you think you are the best at conquering in Civ 5 then just try Wargame. No more thinking for 10 mins about moving to one space (which the campaign will cover that for those who like that) etc. Wargame is quick and new each time you go to a battle. You got to be quick, thoughtful, and strategic in Wargame battles. Time to play a real wargame. Wargame: Red Dragon

content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												     First off, let me get something straight. I reccomend that you purchase this game IF you are not only interested in tactical and strategic combat but also constructing decks by comparing long lists of numbers.  If you don't enjoy the latter, you can get away with copying others but you'll have difficulty if you want to construct your own deck of units.     As early as the game is, this game does need balancing so I don't think that it's fair to critisize what they've done on that front.  Be aware though that many units are subject to change in ability so you might want to wait awhile if you don't want to deal with that.     Of course the big question is naval combat and how much it offers. . I think that there will be groups who despise that new system and others who love it but Eugen has gotten around that by allowing you to play maps which offer all naval, combined and of course your standard ground maps.  The focus is a lot more on mobility than before, reflecting an era where the battefields would be massive and commanders needed to get their troops to the point of conflict as soon as possible.  This makes battles engaging and they rarely slow in to a stalemate or slugfest.

I have been on the losing side of a steam role in which the enemy units far over powered my units. I approached it as if I were playing as a rag tag coalition of worn out and over worked units.

												Wargame: Red Dragon is hands down the best strategy game out today. The maps are challenging, and interesting. There are over 1000 diffrent units to fight with. Each unit having real world statistics, and loadouts. Single player campaign is a challenge. But, the multiplayer is where this game truely shines. I am a huge fan of the series, and I highly recommend checking it out. There is a VERY steep learning curve, so be patient. The best part of this game, is watching Starcraft players get stomped because Zerging doesnt work in the real world.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												I think a friend of mine managed to summarize this game in a pretty clever way;This game is the ArmA of RTS games.And I wholeheartedly agree with the statement.IntroductionThis game is a very realistic RTS game based in a modern era(Though, it does have a few selections of WW2 assets, they don't do too well against modern assets. Who'd figure?).You'll be able to select between 2 factions; BLUFOR and REDFOR - but can also select a coalition within either faction. For example, you could play as the Commonwealth, NATO or even Scandinavia(Really appreciate the addition of Scandi!).One of the biggest aspects of this game is not only the sheer amount of units available at your disposal, but rather they way that you use them. Similar to card games, you'll need to build a deck.This Deck will consist of 9 categories;• Logistics (Supply and Command Vehicles)• Infantry• Support (Anti-Aircraft, Artillery and Mortars)• Tanks• Recon• Vehicles (Mostly consist of Jeeps, Light Armour - pretty much whatever isn't a MBT. Lots of TOW and ATGM)• Helo• Plane• NavalSo as you can see, you have a fair share of categories to build a deck out of. Of course you don't need to use all categories - but it is highly recommended. Because if you for example make a deck without anti-aircraft to support you, you'll be having a very, very bad time.When you create a deck, you'll also have the option to select bonuses. Basically what this does is limit the amount of cards you have, but in return for faster veterancy gain and availability.I won't go into detail on how this work, there's a very nicely written 200-page guide which cover each and every of your needs - while also having a little but of humour in it.First ImpressionsBeing a big fan of slow paced RTS games such as Total Annihilation, Supreme Commander and Command & Conquer, I wasn't quite sure what I was getting myself into. Honestly, I just bought the game cause it looked interesting and had some nice tanks I'm very fond of.My first impression of the game was something like; "Wtf, no base building? LAME!". This was one of my biggest complaints, but only since it was what I was used to. I then realized this isn't just like every other RTS game out there, this one is REALLY unique.I had a really hard time getting into the game, until now. Because of the other RTS games I had played, you grow this kind of habit to just spam the most powerful unit at your disposal and just overtake your enemy with brute force. You see, this does not work in this game - not at all.Every unit has something that counters that unit. The key of learning this game is something called Combined Arms. If you do not get used to Combined Arms, you will die. Horribly. Even by the Easy AI.That brings me to another topic; the AI.The AII usually find the AI to be a big disappointment in RTS games, especially since I'm not too fond of PvP in RTS games since mostly there's a select few tactics which are always the best way to go, and if you don't do either - you'll lose.I haven't really done any PvP in this game yet, since I'm still learning the basics against the AI. And I'll give credit where credit is due - the AI in this game isn't that bad.Especially for a game of such a scale, I find the AI to be rather competent. It's not the usual cheating AI you see in other RTS games where they get bonus income because they're an AI, they're not affected by fog of war because they're AI and so on. As far as I know, the AI doesn't have any handicaps(Correct me if I'm wrong!)[/i].Final VerdictAt first I'd probably rate this game a mere 4/10, simply because I couldn't get used to the fact it's extremely difficult to get into. But now that I've started to learn the basics, this game really does a great job at introducing a new kind of genre of RTS games - maybe I've missed some, but this is the only RTS game I've played which such a focus on realism.The interface is alright, there are some things that could be better. But the main menus for all W:ALB and W:RD look great and feel pretty immersive.You have a absolutely ridiculous amount of units available, you can fulfill whatever role you have ever wanted - either to great success or great failure - nonetheless, it's great fun to explore new things and build decks from scratch.I would highly recommend this game, but I'd also like to warn you;This game is extremely difficult to first get into. I would highly suggest you read the 200-page guide available BEFORE you play this game. Or else you'll with most likeliness end up not liking it, simply because you were a fool not to prepare.If I were to rate it, I'd give it a 9 out of 10. Losing 1 point because it does a♥♥♥♥♥♥poor job at introducing new players.The BadOf course, as with every game it does have its flaws here and there. Some of which in my opinion are;• TOW and ATGM can feel a bit overwhelming. Both when used against your enemy and used by your enemy.• The game does a poor job at showing how to bed use infantry. Garrisoned infantry is wunderbar!• Scandinavian troops are pretty outdated, hopefully they'll be updated with some DLC in the future!• Some sound effects are really bad, most notably the infantry's firearms sound absolutely dreadful. Where as vehicles can sound very satisfying.• The maps feel really repetitive, just different landscape but usually the same amount of spread sectors. Maps with bridges can be great fun, though! Bottlenecks ftw!The SuggestionsReally all I'd want for this game is Scandinavian troops to be updated, since there's plenty of 1990+ units in some nations. Sweden has plenty of modern equipment from 1990 and above.Other than that, some things I'd like to see;• A more unique variety of maps, some with a tight spread of sectors, some very open ones.• Some maps with a GREAT focus on urban warfare, where infantry and IFVs would really shine. With this I mean perhaps a most mostly consiting of a city, with some forested outskirts.• More satisfying sound effects for infantry! Sounds like paintball for crying out loud...

content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
												Got it during the open-beta, so far naval combat is promising but is still a work-in-progress. Ground warfare is top notch with more pronounced ground texturing and map design. With nearly 1,500 units, coalition unit decks, strong national doctrine (to a relatively high amount of authenticity though some aspects a little arcade like), you can command as much as a brigade in game, with many different tactics of war you can utilise to defeat your opponents. Graphics is at an all time high, though it could be expanded further (map wise), overall a top-notch strategy game. If you are someone who one day would like to be a military commander, whether it be army, navy, air force commander, you may like this. Don't let the hard-core oldtimers and strategist protoges downplay you as a noob at first, everyone eventually develops their game play to a respected level of tolerance.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												If, like me, you've always wondered if the F-15's perfect combat record is more of a product of its design or an indicator of the quality of the opposition it's been up against... if, like me, the thought of a horde of WW II era T-34 main battle tanks rushing a state-of-the-art Leopard 2A5 in a desperate attempt to land a lucky shot on its vulnerable rear armor makes you a little bit giddy... if, like me, a modern warfare RTS that models ammunition, fuel, and morale and supports up to 20 players in multiplayer each of which can specialize in roles from air support to infantry to artillery or any combination thereof sounds like the game you've waited your whole life to play:  buy this game.Just be aware that the community is small and always will be on account of the niche target audience of the game, and that for some reason the preferred gametype is a sitzkrieg-inducing extremely campy team deathmatch mode where artillery sniping usually carries the day.  Don't let that get to you though.  The fun in this game is seeing cool military hardware in action, it's not the best competitive RTS on the market.And let us not speak of the toxic chat community.  As that would be giving them exactly what they want.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												Great RTS, Realistic war strategy.Difficult to get used to if you are used to the classic "make the most expensive unit, roll in" crap of other rts games. If and when you do that (you will once if you are a fast learner, more than once if you are slow) you will watch all of your units die. tank vs infantry does not mean tank wins. helicopter vs infantry does not mean helicopter wins.  Unit composition is important to this game. Nothing is more satisfying than a 10 v 10 match where you and 1 friend take out an enemy navy that was created by 10 of the other teams player by yourselves with a much smaller navy. By use of islands, sea depth, coastal forces, and aircraft it is possible to do more with less. Which makes this game the Strategy game to play. Also. every time you don't buy this game an orphan has to watch someone else eat ice cream. You think about that. do you want that on your conscience?

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												Okay, In short: This is a superb game.Okay, In long: You can gather hundreds of hours on this game. It has over 1000 lovingly crafted units. The maps and cover system is amazing. All the weapons and damage mechanics are un-matched in realism. The recon and air mechanics are amazing and it is the first RTS game I have seen to correctly implement fast air.This game is extremly difficult, it is nothing like other RTS games, it requires alot of learning and the tutorials are hopeless. I recommend reading the 200 page guide. The AI SUCK! They know where your units are and it ruins the game. This game is born for multi-player if you dont have a regular internet connection I dont recommend buying it.Overall I recon this is one of the best RTS games ever made. However if you are going to curse at the screen because you cant understand how your fighters were shot down by enemy AA.9.3/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
Truely a WargameWargame: Red Dragon is a military enthusiast's dream. It places you in command of both Western and Eastern fighting forces in a series of hypothethical conflicts set in the 1990's with it's singleplayer campaign. With Red Dragon's multiplayer, you can also face off against other players in large scale, strategic battles with all sorts of military equipment. Artillery strikes will pound forests and towns into dusts as infantry companies are slaughtered in buildings. Tanks will crest hills only to be annihilated by airstrikes. Your army will be destroyed again, and again, and again in every circumstance.My biggest warning, and the ultimate reason why I do not recommend this game, is the mountain of a learning curve that it suffers from. The ingame tutorial is outright pointless, and user created guides for this game for newcomers are literally 200 pages long. You would face less difficulty in being a Soviet officer during the invasion of Finland than playing this game.My first experience in the beginner campaign was that of utter confusion. I have played one of Eugen Systems' earlier games, RUSE, which is very similar in style and presentation to this game, but I was still bumbling in the forest. You will see your units be destroyed again and again as you fumble with the UI and are subject to a hundred different game mechanics at once. Combined arms are the way to succeed in this game, but good luck figuring out how to even command your forces effectively, as you must study pages of statistics in order to decipher the barebones and lacking user interface.In this game, you must account for individual platoons taking towns while also making sure they are resupplied and well fed - but don't forget that you must also cover them with smoke at all times or else they will be vulnerable to enemy tank divisions. Hide your men in the forest - but wait, the enemy recon car spotted you! Now the forest is in flames as artillery barrages incinerate it. Quick, scramble your attack helicopters and jets to strike the enemy guns, but wait - the enemy has waves of anti aircraft weapons that will destroy your aircraft! It is a punishing experience in which you must act as the officer of every single element of an army. Even when in complete comprehension of the game mechanics, it is still a punishing and often frustrating experience nonetheless.I would only recommend this game to those who have played earlier installations of the Wargame franchise, or have the fortitude to withstand endless documentation and guidance on this game to learn it. For some, they will experience the enjoyment of a noble when playing this game - but for the rest of us, we will only toil as peasants to understand it.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2016
												As far as I'm concerned, this game is a very good one, simulating real time battles in modern warfare. There are virtually every unit you can find in today's military arsenal. Imaginary as the campaigns are, they are also reasonable enough and very likely to happen in that specific time period. For me, I enjoy the Second Korean War most for it provides much liberty and it is not very hard. All in all, if you are a fan of contemporary military equipment, or enjoy being in command of a modern army, this is definitely a game you want to try.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												TL;DR Looks good at first but devs don't really care and has many, many flaws. There is no competing game and devs milk you by generalizing  "realistic units and fiting them to a game that everyone can play".Nice game but if you pay attention you can see the flaws which are really big but masked from different many other elements.  First and foremost no recconect feature makes the game unplayable some times as it is plagued by random dcs(my connection is ok). Ships added at Red Dragon are a Fail cause of the 3 maximum weapons per unit. some have CIWS as a weapon some have it hidden Udaloy's CIWS fires missiles but not a single mention at the description.Tanks can fire to ships from woods about 2 Km inside land stay invisible and ships cannot counter them as they are blind. also ships are designed just for naval combat. Forget tomahawks and any other idea of supporting land units with ships. Line of sight is f@cked up as hell. ATGM plane fires TV guided missile enemy tank vanishes momentarily and missiles miss. What ? you have TOW,Hellfire and so many other toys in your infantry/tank/anyunitinthegame?? Sorry TOW is atgm only. u can't  fire it at enemy infantry. Also if you play Naval combat the win strategy is ---> REDFOR. I have never lost a single naval-only combat with redfor. NEVER. Scale is off when it comes to airplanes ships infantry and tanks.AI conserning airplanes and generally all units just sucks the UI is bad and there is no excuse for the DEVS cause this is not their first game. What they do is market the "OVER 1500 units and stuff" but in reality they re-use content. There are so many things that are broken and yet people play the game... why? cause there is no other similar alternative. The devs know it and the take advantage of it. Soon after Red Dragon came out,  Air Land Battle became obsolete and died. Why make red dragon a dlc when we can market the same units add some combinations and say that we worked hard and created a new game oh sooo fresh.Also that lvling/exp gain per match thingie is total bs cause u can just delete the .profile file in the pc and voiala all is gone.Why add leveling up when it has no use at ALL??? .Cause FU that's why.Graphics and explosions will blind you at the beggining but in the end the whole game is just scripts upon usless scripts. check naval combat. when a ship is hit it always gets the shot in the middle but when they miss all cannon shots against it fall infront or behind it. also for some reason some tanks seem to have some sort of invisible shield cause missiles aproch them and then are getting "deflected" for some reason.prolly infantry said "meh let him live " or "OMG he disapeared he totaly is not there any more just press the self-destruct don't guide the missile in that forest just to be sure....."Still the same Game with the same problems. 10v10 with plenty of points and it lags. Custom Servers with "skillful" ppl. Current Winning strategy for BLUEFOR naval combat ---> Don't play bluefor. And ofcourse Over 9000 units... just don't think   they are "unique". The only reason to play this is because there is nothing else in the same category worth of playing or even all togeather exists.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												If, like me, you've always wondered if the F-15's perfect combat record is more of a product of its design or an indicator of the quality of the opposition it's been up against... if, like me, the thought of a horde of WW II era T-34 main battle tanks rushing a state-of-the-art Leopard 2A5 in a desperate attempt to land a lucky shot on its vulnerable rear armor makes you a little bit giddy... if, like me, a modern warfare RTS that models ammunition, fuel, and morale and supports up to 20 players in multiplayer each of which can specialize in roles from air support to infantry to artillery or any combination thereof sounds like the game you've waited your whole life to play:  buy this game.Just be aware that the community is small and always will be on account of the niche target audience of the game, and that for some reason the preferred gametype is a sitzkrieg-inducing extremely campy team deathmatch mode where artillery sniping usually carries the day.  Don't let that get to you though.  The fun in this game is seeing cool military hardware in action, it's not the best competitive RTS on the market.And let us not speak of the toxic chat community.  As that would be giving them exactly what they want.

Posted: September 4, 2014
												Played some multiplayer before, often only with friends, tried the single player campaign. As always, step learning. Watched this game pretty much from day 1. Dident play Wargame: European Escalation at all, but i did play Wargame: Airland Battle and that was a great game. From what i understand alot of units from European Escalation was just ported into Wargame, so some units lacked detail.And here we are, with Red Dragon. Naval warfare galore it seems, but alas. No. I expected each country to have their own naval units, but instead each side shares their boats, so Blufor and opfor get their 15 or so boats, and every country can access all boats. That means that armies from like Scandinavia can use the Oliver Hazard Perry as their boat if they feel like it.There aren't alot of boats out there even, which sucks. For a game that boost about 1400 and something units it just feels... rushed. So it fails to deliver on that front. We do however get 4 new faction or so, and some alliance choices. You can now create decks of units from the commonwealth army or why not use scandinavian units et.c.Gameplay still feels like Airland Battle, nothing really new here. They told about terrain diffrences and that hills can block your line of sight and such, haven't really noticed anything diffrent from Airland Battle.And it might just be me but would'nt it be time to update the models abit. There are alot, and i mean alot of errors and problems in the models. Some examples are :Aircraft that are sunken abit into the ground when you create your decks (Landing gear clips through ground).Aircraft have payloads that are so large so they clip through the ground.Still uses models from European Escalation. Good examples are helicopters, some lack interiors all together. Some have interiors but no pilots, while newer helicopters have interiors and pilots.Many infantry units are portraited wrong ingame, sure you rarely play this game zoomed in but heres an example. The Swedish M90 uniform was formely introduced in the 1990, But was already in use since 1985. Wargame: Red Dragon is a game that spawns from 1970 to 1992 atleast. If we go after Eugen way of doing everything the easy way, why not butcher the U.S. Marine infantry model (They wear somewhat modern armor and BDU:s), arm them with the AK4 Rifle and just make a reskin so they use the M90 pattern? Easy as pie. (I know this might be slightly biased cause im from sweden, but as i see it, if i can find errors in a country representing my own, then others will do the same with their own countries)There are also some bugs here ande there, units that don't load in correctly, most units are just reskins of tanks from other nations et.c. Those skins are often portraited wrong, many of the nations camo dosen't even match (wasent there something called uniformity in the armed forces). I mean should'nt every nations unit look like they camed from the same place, instead of having some units colored in desert camo. Some in olive drab, some in digital camo et.c.These are mostly visual errors, the game has some bad problems with balancing. And suprise, suprise, the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ community from ALB has moved over to Red Dragon, new players will have an hard time getting help, bashing is to be expected and if thats not happening then theres always someone spamming the chat with flag emotes.And lastly, i find it hard to believe there are actully 1400+ diffrent units in the game. Most infantry can be ordered in diffrent transports. Are all those diffrent variations classed as a unit? I believe that's how they count. If someone actully counted all units (excluding their transport options) i'd bet there are alot fewer units to choose from.Can i recommend this game? No. Sorry, i really can't. It's nothing special, Airland Battle feelt like a more complete game all in all. At the time of writing this, the game was on -50% sale (19,99€). And i can't really tell if this is a reasonable price for this game... maybe, i guess? Get it if you feel like it for that price, or hope for an even better sale. Play it with friends, do not expect to much and well... maybe, just maybe you'll have a good time for a couple of games or two.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												I spent an evening drunk as I amassed an army of over 900 screaming Chinese and North Korean conscripts birthed for the sole purpose of giving their life for the Great Leader in a charge of glory across a 3km open field without any air defense. 600 meters in my glorious bulwark is buzzed by a pair of A10s, then followed up with a napalm strike from an F4. My army now stands at 700 flaming, incredibly♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off riflemen armed with little more than a scrap metal in the shape of a burp gun. The march continues.At 1400 meters we are in range of the bulk of enemy defenses. I am reduced to a mere 300 men in the span of four seconds, The march continues. At last we are in range, with 200 of the Great Leader's finest troops collectively decending upon a lone M1 Abrams tank as the capitalist pigs look on in shock and mild confusion. The tank operator is slightly worried, but otherwise unhindered in his task. This is good, now comes phase two. A turboprop bomber approaches from the south, dropping a 3000kg warhead dead on top of the command Abrams. My conscripts are collectively granted the sweet release of death, and I even managed to detred the lone tank. This all grants time for the two man anti-tank unit to garison a building opposite of the valley and singlehandedly decimate the enemy armored regement. 11/10, I have proven my honor.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2016
												Amazing successor to the already superb Airland Battle. The addition of a time-control feature is a godsend for people like me who struggle with very fast-paced RTS play. Slightly ambivalent about the addition of naval units, but overall this game still shines as a unique blend of fun, serious tactics, an absolutely amazing array of units and unit types, and for *many* different nations / alliances. A must-buy for anyone interested in modern-day combat. Even grogs who gravitate to the ultra-serious sims like Command: Modern Air / Naval Ops will find a lot to enjoy here.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2015
												Pros1)1500 units with real specifications2)Endless strategy3)The game finally has a slower button. It gets normal, slow, very slow and bullet time. No more battle frustration because of many things happening at once. You can now deply your strategy and lose fair and square.4)Active multiplayer5)Five campaigns6) you can now deploy ships, have naval battles and you can also invade through land7) Realism, which means everything you can imagine. Realistic damage, the units get battle hardened, each dead unit stays dead so you should preserve your units, enemy withdraws if you do extensive damage, realistic strategy, units need resupply and rearmingy, you win the map sector by sector, battles do not end in one day, there are political influences that can change the cause of war etc.Cons1)Steep learning curve, like all wargames. If you hate realism, do not play it.2)Poor tutorial3)Not being able to choose sides at campaigns4)So many units is wonderful for army freaks but can end up being frustrating for casual games. Then again, this game is not casual.OverallProbably the most realistic modern strategy simulator. If this is not enough for you, i do not know what else will be.

												This game can be brilliant - the tactical thinking required puts it way beyond most other modern RTS games - the graphics are great, the units are varied and 'real' and the campaigns are stretching and a brilliant mix between semi-strategic and full tactical. I love it and I've found myself going back to the campaigns again and again to try out different strategic plans and battlegroup / company / battalion combinations.Would I recommend it? NOIt is mainly a multiplayer game, this is fine, it has a strong multiplayer community  - all the wargames have had this, but there is no multiplayer campaign - which makes this a multiplayer skirmish game with a limited single payer bolt on - a wasted opportunity, and my advice would be don't waste your time. Particularly as, at the point of both pre-purchase and full publication the Eugen website was advertising this game as having a multiplayer campaign - either an honest mistake or a strong indication that something went very wrong in development. I won't be purchasing any more Eugen products unless full multi campaigns are an option. Don't bother with it unless all you want is sup com style skirmishing - otherwise buy Wargame Airland Battle - it's cheaper and has a multi campaign option, though it isn't quite as good. Eugen , you really missed a trick there.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												I'm not a fan of Wargame, nor Strategy games in general. But this one interested me. With all it's trailers of Jets, Explosions and Furious Hell-ish Combat. So when it came out, I quickly sprang for my wallet. One of the things that interested me was how many countries and vehicles were in this game. So not knowing how to play a Wargame title, wondering if this is like any of its predessesors, I went to the Campaign thinking, like most games, it would have a tutorial at the beginning. (And yes I did look at the tutorial that was in the menu, however hoping that there would be a ingame video, or picture or something, and finding nothing but text, I didn't look at it too long).When I got into the campaign, I was greeted with a cinematic with old camera footage from the 80s, after that it showed me a big map of North Korea and South Korea and I had to defend the Capital of South Korea. A Picture of a Man told me that I had an incoming transmission from a Soldier. It then showed me a South Korean Soldier telling me my Objective. With no voice acted dialog at all, I was getting flashbacks for some reason of a mobile game called Clash of Clans which I despise because of its F2P concept that plagues modern gaming.After those interactions it let me take control of the camera. Noticing that there was no tutorial, I was stunned. So I decided to take matters into my own hands. On the border of enemy and friendly territory, I saw a North Korean Tank Battalion, and on the other side, I saw a South Korean Tank Battalion. So I though, "Let them Fight" (Godzilla 2014 Reference) So I dragged the SK Tank onto the NK tank, and nothing happened. I clicked on the SK tank and nothing happened.Seeing how a Planetside 2 Event had been launched by the AJSA. I quit to desktop and haven't played it since. If a Wargame Veteran could help me. That would be great.In my (short) Experience with the game, I cannot recommend it. Not to newbies like me atleast.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												Micromanagement and spam. Thats covering about 90% of the experience youre gonna get from this game. But one thing after another.The core gameplay is good, really good. Building your own deck each with its own strengths and weaknesses is fun. And trying it out makes even more fun, at least most of the time or at the start of the game. But once you notice that there are serious balance issues it becomes a lot more frustrating. For example:"Heli rushes" (a "strategy" that means you invest all of your points into Helicopter and send them around corners of the map; attacking the enemy spawnpoint) are completly broken, because you are forced into a lose-lose situation. Either invest money at the start of the game into your base and risk not having enough in your front line (in case your opponent actually wants to play the game) or invest nothing and get instantly destroyed by the enemy if they decide to start a "Heli Rush". The worst of all is that it takes no talent or planning at all. Just spam one unit; send it to one location; win. You will encounter this ♥♥♥♥♥torm in almost every third ranked game. Almost none keeps playing ranked because of that♥♥♥♥♥♥ And if i say none i mean none. One person out of 1000 players per day start a ranked (and there are about 400-700 players per day activ).Air units become useless after the 10-20 minute mark, because all players build a relativ strong AA-Base at this point in the game. Tanks are a must have and easily the strongest units in the game. If you or your team dares to play without them they will have almost no chance at winning the game. This would be fine if it wasnt for the fact that this destroyes a huge part of the entire deck building. Aircraft based decks, infantry based decks, etc are just worse then the tank based decks. Of cource it depends also on the map your playing, but at the end of the day you will still have a significant advantge with the tank based decks every time. ---This could be accapteble. After all if the gameplay would have nothing besides balance issues you could easily play with friends or just ignore it (somehow), but sadly it dosent. The problem is (or cource) unreasonable and useless micromanagement. In 9 out of 10 cases the person with better "micro" will win no matter how stupid they might be.If you start a game you will get about 2-10 minutes of deploytime to select your units, try to think about your tactic, maybe talk with your team about a overall strategy and so on. However once the game starts you are forced to select each unit you deployed and send them to their location - *after* the game started. Its a annoying ♥♥♥♥ton of work every single time. Remembering the Typ, Plan, and position of about 20 (+/-15) units that are all called "KA-52a" "T80UM" or "T80A" is nearly impossible if you are new at the game and extremly difficult beyond that. And dont even get started about enemy Aircraft..."oh no there is an "F-15A Eagle" coming to Alpha" or "oh no there is an "F-15D Eagle" coming to Bravo". One of these Aircraft units is a AA-Superiority Jet and the other one a heavy bomber. Have fun learing the diffrence. (Just a funny side note: you cant rename your units)And it gets even worse. If you finally managed to send all of your units to their location they will refuse to stay at the *exact* location you have given to them. They will stand around an 10m radius of the order you have given to them. This is just cancer since there are many situations where you need your unit at a absolutly specific locations, but this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ just refuses to do so.But wait...it gets even worse. If you somehow managed to send your unit to the *exact* location (usually by just command them to go 50m beyond x and then just hit "stop" once they are 5m befor x), then they will not face the frontline...with their own frontline. For example i command my tank to x; he goes x (after that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t) and then reloactes his frontal armor to y, because 1500m away (and thats no joke) is a cheap transport thats just standing the open - making himself extremly vulnerable to the Tank-hunter at x. I lost already way too much high value units because of that♥♥♥♥♥♥and there is not a single way to disable this "feature". And dont fool yourself. This dosent happen once every 50 matches, but *every single match you will ever play*. All of these problems. It just kills all of the potential fun, desicion making and overall gameplay. Just spam, micro and abuse silly mechanics to win the day.Dont bother and buy yourself something that you will actually enjoy.

number of helpful: 30 of 63 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
												An inferior update to the venerable Wargame: Airland Battle. Red Dragon takes a lot of the worst aspects of W: ALB and magnifies them ten times - point & click artillery and airplanes are vastly superior to conventional ground forces, the maps are so large now that moving tanks and other ground vehicles across the map is impractical because they require micromanagement and extra resources just to ensure they have enough fuel to move halfway across, and the game is still missing many quality of life features like the ability to reconnect to a game (the netcode is even worse now than in ALB) or a ruler to measure distances. The community has devolved into nationalistic tribalism, and the developers do not take substantive and researched criticism into consideration.Red Dragon is a quick and dirty cashgrab compared to Airland Battle. If you want a modern RTS that isn't StarCraft, I heartily recommend ALB.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												This is what I first thought after an hour of playing it- Unplayably complicated with no tutorial, this game drops you into the fight straight at the deep end. The "tutorial" on the menu screen is basicly the manual, and you better read and understand it first go because you can't get to it ingame. If you want to spend two hours trying to figure out why you have no troops to command or lose thirty seconds in, buy this game. If you want a decent Real Time Stratery game, look elsewhere. I'm sorry I atually paid money for it.- UpdatedBecause I paid for it, I stuck with it. It took me about five hours of blundering around and re-reading the tutorial section, but I finally worked out the resource mechanics, how you have to secure sectors to call for reinforcements and the incredably complicated rock-paper-sissors system of weapons and counter weapons. I am, at last, enjoying it, although I still think it desperately needs some better introductions for new players. I have had some stabilty issues with crashing graphics, but infrequently, its not a massive problem. Overall, its a pretty decent, highly complex, combat simulator. Be prepared to sink a few hours into reading the online player guides, and more hours into learning the systems by losing repeatedly. This game will eat your time up.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												This game is a gem, a masterpiece. Eugen has fine-tuned every title in this serie, and in this the latest one put themselves in the absolute frontline of realistic RTS games.This is a deep game, with a massive amount of real world unit types which allows you to build your own combined force. The game mechanics are quite easy to learn but hard to master, but the pure amount of statistics of every single unit means you have to put in a great amount of time to learn how to use each unit the best way possible.You have to concentrate on your strategy and mastering the use of different unit combinations for the given situation and be prepared of your opponents units and how to counter them. The campaigns are not the strenght here, but the multiplayer are, and it is excellent. Eugen is continously and often updating the game and tweaking/correcting units, game balance etc to fine-tune the game according to the players response. DLC´s with new countries are continously beeing released.Prepare to loose sleep. The more you put into this game, the more it gives you back. It is timeless in many aspects.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
												One of the finest strategy games ive had the pleasure to play. punishing, realistic, steep learning curve for multiplayer. There are minor discrepancies in some of the units in how they should look vs how they are modelled ingame, but still worlds ahead in realism beyond any game ive played in the genre. I hope they continue to make more in the series. If they would just un**** their campaign mode and allow coop/competetive campaign, this would be my "total war" game covering the scope of the modern era 1960s-1990s. Your selection of units is so vast (over 1700 unique units last i checked) covering everything from warplanes to infantry to ships, tanks, helos, armored cav, air assault forces, AA, SAMs etc etc... that the people who inevitably cry: "That side is OP" "US too stronk" "new update makes game casul friendly" "USSR tank-rush new-meta" are missing the point. Modern militaries are simply unequal, not all technology held by one nation is comparable to that of others. Sometimes it is superior, sometimes downright inferior. But taken as an aggregate with so many advantages given to the various sides in DIFFERERENT ASPECTS of their forces (IE numerical advantage, accuracy, killing power, speed) It truly comes down to who is the better commander, something not easy to do in a HIGHLY assymetric RTS.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												As a long time fan of the series I have to say I am overall disappointed with Red Dragon. It looks great, and has a wealth of units from a range of nations and coalitions. Naval combat is a nice idea, but it fails really. But my biggest annoyance is now there is very little point in taking infrantry or setting up in depth defence. Cover or houses have very little effect against HE or bombs, and an inability to dig in leaves infrantry just sitting there waiting to get killed. The advantage in technology along with it being easy to see your opponents units with recce and air units makes taking an 80 or 85 era list rather pointless as well. You may as well just get the best units available and out range and out muscle your opponents, which is kind of what the western units do in the majority of games. Unless you are playing as part of a group of friends coordinating your moves winning as pact seems far to hard and far to rare. Personally I also think the game needs to be slowed down as the strategy side of it is diminshed by local area rushes which comes down to numbers and fire power rather than making defensive positions hard to crack they just get over run.
